story: At Wildflower Ecovillage, we are currently building the infrastructure for a sustainable and organic vision of the future. Our goals are to enrich not only the land we have available but also the lives of everyone who wants to work along side us to learn the benefits of nature. We grow food, build with compressed earth block and protect wildlife while storing, researching and conserving our valuable Texas water. Come join us and be part of a community that is dedicated to regenerating the natural landscape within and around us.

story:
Hi! We are Kellie and Tahlia! This summer we are interning with the Sierra Student Coalition on the Beyond Coal to Clean Energy campaign.  We are working on youth education and engagement, empowering young people around the state to take action, and developing groups to work for environmental causes. 

As part of the training for our internship there is an opportunity for us to go to a week-long grassroots organizing training, called Sprog, short for “summer program.” This summer’s Midwest program is being held in Indiana from July 14th to 21st where we will be joined by others from across the region.  It’s a unique training because it is run for young people by young people and teaches skills for running and winning strategic campaigns. It is a great chance for us to learn about leading and developing volunteers, organizing events, and planning a campaign, as well as a way to build our environmental action networks locally and regionally. 

The cost for the program is $1000 for two people. (Right now we have enough to put down the money but then afterward we will have no money left for other things essential to living.) This would fund lodging, food, transportation, and the program itself. This is a wonderful way for us learn about environmental campaigns and would be invaluable to our education on these issues, personal and professional growth, and will equip us with the tools to run campaigns in the future.

It would be much appreciated if you would consider donating to our cause. Also, if you are curious about our experience, we would be happy to keep you in the loop on our campaign progress after Sprog. Thank you so much for your time and interest!

 

P.S. If you are interested in learning more about the Sierra Student Coalition or Sprog please feel free to visit our website- ssc.org/sprog

story:
Short Summary

I am volunteering for 5 weeks this summer to assist the Earthship organization complete a start-to-finish construction project in Alberta, Canada. A radically sustainable home will be constructed with the help of approximately 50 volunteers who are donating their time, money, and extensive labor to make this happen. In addition to participating in the construction, I plan to create an inspiring and educational account of this project to share with all interested parties upon my return, in person and via electronic media so that others can make more impactful and broader-reaching contributions to community, society, and the environment.

For decades now, the Earthship organization has been building homes and other structures around the world out of recycled materials including automotive tires, bottles, and cans. They  are 100% self-sustaining and off-the-grid, from temperature control and electrical power to water management and year-round food production.  The need for such innovations is critical to lead us into relationship with our environment and away from reckless consumption and waste of its resources, in architecture and many other fields.  Solutions like this are appearing everywhere and are completely viable and practical, with applications in rural and urban environments, but education and awareness are slow to follow among the general public. The time is now to raise the volume.

I am seeking financial assistance to allow my participation and to develop a presentation of all aspects of this project and its significance.

What We Need & What You Get

My fundraising goal is $10,000. 

Perks:

Donors of any amount will receive heartfelt thanks from me via written letter and telephone, and named credit in any and all presentation media in appreciation for their support.

Donors of $100 or more will also receive a DVD with edited and narrated footage of the project.

Donors of $500 or more will receive a live presentation and Q&A with me for any audience in their community, in person or via Skype/Internet if located outside the San Francisco bay area.

If you donate $1000+, you will receive 3 live presentations for audiences of your choice, and dinner with me and your +1 at the restaurant of your choice.  I will travel anywhere if transportation and lodging costs are provided.

The Impact

I think most of us share the same vision for a nourishing life experience during our stay here and with hopes for those who follow us. It is more important now than ever to raise awareness and do our part as individuals to protect our planet and secure our future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The funding I'm seeking here is to help make this project possible, but there are many other ways to contribute in the near-term and strategically:

1) Outreach:  If you are encouraged by this project and know others who might be, please tell them about my campaign and encourage them to spread the word using the Indiegogo share tools on my campaign website.

2) Contacts:  If you know anyone involved with environmental issues, sustainable living and architecture, or any other topics related to this project, I would greatly appreciate their contact info or an email introduction.

3) Speaking Opportunities:   If you belong to or know of any organization that would welcome a presentation of this experience, please send me the contact info or make an email introduction

story:
In June 2014 students from the University of Birmingham will be attempting to complete the 3 Peaks Challenge. This involves climbing the 3 highest peaks in Scotland, England and Wales (Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon) in under 24 hours, including driving. 

They are undertaking this challenge in order to raise money for charity. 

'Kinvig' is the Geography Society at the University of Birmingham, and its 'Charity of the Year' is Ruby's Fat Cow Fund. The charity was set up in memory of Ruby who died from an aggressive brain tumour. Their aim is to raise as much money as possible that is then split between: The Brain Tumour Charity, CLIC Sargent, RMHC and CALM. More information can be found at: http://www.rubysfatcowfund.co.uk

Global Sunrise is a non-profit project which fundraises through an international network to provide electricity to some of the world's most deprived communities in a clean and sustainable manner. More information can be found at: http://www.globalsunrise.net

We're hoping to raise as much money as possible for these amazing causes, so any donation is much appreciated.

Thank you!

story:
***** I want to give a big Thank You to all of you incredible friends and potential gorilla honey customers who contributed to this campaign and helped support our project! To everyone who tweeted us, liked us on facebook, purchased a perk and even featured our campaign on their blogs and magazines! Thank you in deed! Even though we haven’t reached our goal, we plan to run another campaign soon! This is not the end of Gorilla Honey- We’ll keep pushing on until we make it! For those that purchased a perk, please send us your email and contact information to- hortense.mudenge@h2ovp.com and watch for updates and our progress on facebook @ www.facebook.com/GorillaHoney or on twitter @ https://twitter.com/GorillaHoney. Website coming soon!!

 What we are doing;

 

We are producing small limited edition jars of honey in support of mountain gorilla conservation in the great Virunga region! 

 

 *** We are currently only able to ship the jars to the US, but we hope to get into other countries as well, upon expansion of our business and upon the dutiful compliance of our country with other countries’ international honey regulations and standards. All the same, if you believe in us and want to see us grow, you can support us at the $10 level.

 

Why it matters;

 

There are only 880 mountain gorillas remaining in the world today, all living in protected national parks in the rainforests of the Virunga volcanic region. This makes them one of the critically endangered animals in the world. The biggest threat to these mountain gorillas is the destruction of the rainforest habitat caused in part by the ever increasing number of surrounding local smallholder farming and beekeeping communities that depend on the natural rainforest resources for their livelihood. The irony in this is that these same communities also depend on gorilla tourism for the development of their region and community.   

By producing these limited edition honey jars, we want to be able to conserve these beautiful mountain gorillas and their vulnerable rainforest habitat by;

  • Providing a sustainable livelihood for smallholder beekeepers living along the edge of the Virunga volcanic mountains in order to alleviate their dependence on the rainforest and reduce their competition for rainforest resources with mountain gorillas.

 

 

  • Funding the conservation work of the International Gorilla Conservation Program (IGCP) in Rwanda. Proceeds from the sale of the jars will go towards the direct protection of the mountain gorillas in the Volcanoes National Park, Rwanda.

 

 

Why we all love Gorilla Honey;

 

Beekeeping in the Virunga region has a rich history dating back thousands of years and the skilful and complex technique of harvesting unique to this region is a highly treasured tradition among the community, passed on from generation to generation.

Our unique limited edition jars of natural honey will be carefully harvested from traditionally crafted hives located at the base of the Virunga Mountains. The honey is completely 100% pure and all-natural; it does not contain artificial flavours, preservatives or industrial-strength flavour extracts of any kind. It also has a strong, distinctive taste of this mountainous rainforest region that is sure to tease your taste buds!

Our ambition is to preserve the identity of our honey through processing, so that we can tell you exactly which apiaries the honey was harvested from and the stories of the region, the farmers and their families.

 

 

 Why we need you;

 

Although honey processing is quite easy and simple to do, meeting international honey export and import standards is the complete opposite. We need to make sure we have the right harvesting gear, high quality processing equipment in place, proper and clearly labeled jars and packaging, a well defined international distribution network and all the necessary documentation and logistics paperwork required for shipping and distribution.

The funds we receive for our project will help us to raise the inital start-up capital for the business and will help us to;

  • Begin production of our first batch of limited edition honey jars; this entails working with the beekeepers to harvest and purchase from them a large supply of honey, as well as processing the honey into batches
  • Cover the costs for packaging and shipping the jars in a timely fashion following strict international health and food safety import standards.
  • Fund the conservation work of our partner, IGCP by committing 10% of the proceeds from the sale of the jars to the organization's park activities- tracking the family groups of mountain gorillas, securing and cleaning the park and educating the bee-keeping communities on gorilla conservation.
  • Make the business sustainable- building a local factory in Rwanda to process and package the jars following international standards, training the beekeepers on modern beekeeping techniques to increase production, establishing an online sales platform and retail network to facilitate the sale and export of jars to other countries. 

 

What you get;

 

 

* We are currently only able to ship the jars to the US, but we hope to get into other countries as well, upon expansion of our business and upon the dutiful compliance of our country with other countries’ international honey regulations and standards. All the same, if you believe in us and want to see us grow, you can support us at the $10 level. 

 

Our vision;

 

We dream of taking gorilla honey to other countries, of constructing our very own processing factory in Musanze, Rwanda, sourcing honey from other smallholder beekeepers living along the greater Virunga region in DRC and Uganda, exploring ways to create gorilla honey tours for well-wishers to come and see the apiaries and beekeeping communities and increasing our partnerships with other gorilla conservation organizations in facilitating the birth and growth of many new groups of mountain gorilla families.

But for now we are taking small baby steps! Help us get there! Back our project! 

 

 Risks & Challenges;

 

  • We have already established contracts with the beekeepers, processing, packaging and logistics companies, but there are always risks to delivering and shipping the jars internationally on time.
  • While we have already sourced our beekeepers and apiaries, unexpected events like heavy rains or cases of varroa mites and termites than can kill the bees may affect our production timelines.
  • We haven’t made packaging for the jars yet, so we may experience delays in production as we work with our partner company to get that done.

story:
Would you give up one soft drink a week to help people in developing countries?

The World Bank estimates that breathing kerosene fumes is the equivalent of smoking two packets of cigarettes a day and two-thirds of adult females with lung cancer in developing countries are non-smokers.

Indoor air pollution continues to ravage rural communities and poor urban dwellers. According to the UNDP, in rural Kenya more women die of fume-related illnesses than they do of malaria and tuberculosis.

The Problem: Kerosene Lanterns

1.5 billion people still use dangerous and expensive kerosene lanterns in developing countries. Kerosene lanterns - a century-old technology – are fire hazards.

According to the World Bank, $36 Billion is spent on kerosene per year in developing countries. Up to 25% of the income of a typical household is spent on kerosene.

Over one million people die each year from kerosene-related accidents.

The Solution: Solar Energy

The Earth receives more solar energy in one hour than the world population consumes in a year. Most developing countries have enormous solar power potential – for example, most of Africa has around 325 days of strong sunlight a year.

Solar lights do not have recurring costs and this will help to alleviate poverty.

Solar lights are environmentally friendly and they are 5 x brighter than kerosene lanterns. They are non-polluting and therefore clean and safe for health and the environment.

Our Work: Transforming Lives

The absence of electricity in many developing countries contributes substantially to building up barriers to health and education.

We are working with manufacturers and distributors to deliver quality, durable and affordable solar lanterns and lighting kits to consumers.

Solar lanterns and lighting kits will be given free of charge to those who cannot afford to pay for them.

Others will get the lanterns and lighting kits at a reduced price and will pay for them by instalments over one to two years.

Solar Lights: Key Benefits

Providing a safer, brighter, cheaper and more environmentally sustainable form of light.

We supply quality solar lights that are durable even in the most demanding rural environments.

High quality polycrystalline solar panels – 10 years’ life

Super bright LED bulbs – 10 years’ life

High quality lithium-ion battery – 5 years’ life

How can you help?

You can help in a number of ways:

You can make a small donation to cover the cost of solar lights. You will receive a free gift!

You can purchase a solar light and we will give one free of charge to someone in a developing country - Get One and Give One.

You can help to spread the message to your friends via social networking sites and blogs.


Just-World.Org


Solar Powered Lights

Providing a safer, brighter, cheaper and a more environmentally sustainable form of light.

Unlike the widely used kerosene lamps, whose smoke and soot pollute the environment and expose users to significant health risks, solar lights are non-polluting, and therefore clean and safe for health and the environment.

Our Products

We supply quality solar lights that are durable even in the most demanding rural environments. Our products range from single lanterns to lighting kits with multiple LED bulbs. The products are suitable for use in homes, hospitals, schools, etc.

Key Benefits

·  Save money on fuel

·  Save money on mobile charging

·  Improve health

·  Reduce CO2 emission

·  Eliminate fire risks and accidents

·  Free to run

·  Maintenance free

Solar Lantern

This heavy-duty solar lantern is ideal for indoor and outdoor use. It can be powered by the sunlight or AC electricity. It can charge mobile phones.

Key Features

·  High quality mono-crystalline silicon solar panels 1.5W – 10 years’ life

·  Super bright LED bulbs – 10 years’ life

·  Two Lithium-ion batteries 3.2V 1350mAh – 5 years’ life

·  5 x Brighter than kerosene lanterns

·  Up to 8 hours of light on a fully-charged battery

·  Built to last

·  Two-year warranty

·  Certification: CE, ROHS


Solar Lighting Kits

Our Lighting Kits are durable and they provide cost-effective, environmentally friendly power solutions.

Key Features

·  High quality polycrystalline solar panels – 10 years’ life

·  Super bright LED bulbs – 10 years’ life

·  High quality Lithium-ion battery – 5 years’ life

·  Up to 8 hours of light on a fully-charged battery

·  Mobile phone charger

·  Built to last

·  Two-year warranty

·  Certification: CE, ROHS

Model JW-100

Solar Panel: 5.5V 3W Solar Panel with 6m cable

Battery: One Rechargeable 3.7V, 4400mAh Lithium-ion battery

Lamp: One 3W SMD LED lamp

Model JW-200

Solar Panel: 9V 5W Solar Panel with 6m cable

Battery:  Two Rechargeable 3.7V, 4400mAh Lithium-ion batteries

Lamp: Two 3W SMD LED lamps

Model JW-300

Solar Panel: 9V 10W Solar Panel with 6m cable

Battery: Four Rechargeable 3.7V, 4400mAh Lithium-ion batteries

Lamp: Four 3W SMD LED lamps


Gifts

USB Stick 16 GB - USB 2.0

USB Stick  64 GB  - USB 2.0

World Travel Adapter with USB Charger

It can be used in 150 countries. 

AC: 3A 110-250V 

USB Output: 2100mA 5V       



Power Bank


Portable power for your smart phones, tablets and cameras.

Capacity: 10,000mAh

Voltage: 3.7V

Input: DC 5.0/1.8A

Output1: DC5V/2A

Output2: DC5V/1A

Over-current Protection

Short-Circuit Protection

Overcharging/Over-discharging Protection


Portable Solar Charger

It can charge your Mobile Phones, MP3 Players, Power Banks and Cameras on the go. 

Mono-crystalline silicon Solar panel 7W

Output voltage/current: 5V/0.8A

Waterproof and Portable

Opening Size: 470mm x 230mm

Folded Size:  170mm x 230mm

Net Weight: 450 grams 


FAQs


How does your programme work?

We will give solar lanterns and lighting kits free of charge to those who cannot afford to pay for them.

Others will get solar lanterns and lighting kits at a reduced price and they will pay by instalments over one to two years. The money received will be used to fund further supply of solar lanterns and lighting kits.

Do you employ people to distribute the lights?

We work with local NGOs and charities. We will also employ people in some countries.

Q: Are your prices for the solar lanterns and lighting kits lower than retail prices?

Our prices are very competitive and are likely to be lower than retail prices for products with the same specifications.

Q: Are all of the solar lanterns and lighting kits on the market same?

No! There are low quality and cheap products available.

You need to look at the type of solar panels, batteries and LED bulbs used. Our products come with the best specifications. Our products also carry CE and ROHS certifications.

Q: What type of solar panels do you use? 

We only use mono-crystalline and polycrystalline solar panels.

Q: What type of batteries do you use?

We use high quality Lithium-ion batteries. The same type used in most laptops and mobile phones.

Q: What type of LED bulbs do you use?

We use high-efficiency super bright LED bulbs that can last for up to 10 years.

Q: What do I do if I have further questions?

We will be happy to answer your questions. Please contact us.

be happy to answer your questions. Please contact us.

story:
We have re-opened our campaign for an additional ten days (hence XL Dissent 2.0). In our first campaign we raised $9,300, and we wanted people to be able to continue to donate during the action itself and the week after.

XL DISSENT is the vision of a group of young organizers to respond to one of the most pressing environmental decisions of our time. If approved, the Keystone XL pipeline would increase the economic viability of extraction in Alberta, exacerbate pollution and health risks from refining, and spell game over for the climate. As young people we must respond: our future is on the line. We believe that by orchestrating the largest youth climate civil disobedience in US history we can send a strong message to President Obama: Unlock us from a fossil fuel future. XL Dissent is a weekend event that will include a civil disobedience training and divestment campaign meeting on Saturday, and an action on Sunday.

What We Need 

This action will also bring together students from all across the United States to converge on a shared vision of our planet's future. The other cost for us is transportation-- we will be having buses come to DC from Minnesota, Maine, Wisconsin, Vermont, and others! Since this is a student-driven action, we want to be able to offset the cost to make it accessible to anyone who wants to be a part. If we do not reach our entire goal, the fundraised money will simply help to decrease the cost for students to be involved.


The Impact

Generations before have created the infrastructure that has led us to impending climate catastrophe. As young people who will be most impacted, we are standing up to say “enough”, and we need your support to speak truth to power.

We are working with 350.org, Energy Action Coalition, Greenpeace, and Chesapeake Climate Action Network to pull off this event. With their organizing assistance and the 75+ campuses that have already committed to attending, we know this will be a success.


Other Ways You Can Help

Check out our website and share it with your friends, families, lovers on Facebook, twitter, e-mail, and the longstanding options of in person conversation and snail mail.

  • www.xldissent.org

story:
Why Support Us?

We want to bring awareness to the continued disrespect of indigenous tribal land and acknowledge the importance of wild places that should remain untouched. Follow us as we ride 2,600+ miles across the desert though Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments to raise money for the Native American Rights Fund to protect these wild lands.

Photo: utahbusiness.com 

About Bears Ears + Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument

Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments are located in southern Utah on the Colorado Plateau, between Moab and Saint George. The area encompasses arid peaks, lush plateaus, deep canyons, slick-rock, and stunning mountains. The cultural, biological, geological and ecological significances are incomprehensible. This wild land is sacred to many peoples, animals, and plants. Oil and mining interests in the past have polluted and upturned these landscapes. Much of this pollution has and continues to enter the rivers that supply water to millions of people throughout the Southwest. The current administration has not learned from the past and seeks to make the same mistakes for short-term monetary gains. We need to let our voices be heard. We need to educate ourselves and others, and take action. Currently, many tribes are suing the state of Utah and the federal government, they need our help.

 

To learn more here are some links:

  • https://suwa.org/issues/bearsears/
  • https://www.narf.org/cases/protecting-bears-ears-national-monument-bears-ears/

 

About Our Trip

To raise awareness for Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments, we will be bikepacking from Denver, CO to Tucson, AZ, through the two monuments.

— The trip will take us about two months, October through November, 2018.

— We will ride 2,600+ miles, through the mountains and deserts of Colorado, Utah and, Arizona.

— Our route will consist of mostly dirt roads and 4x4 roads, some single track and minimal paved roads. The route will be rugged, isolated and challenging.

— We will be riding the Colorado Trail from Denver, CO to Durango, CO. Then the Plateau Passage from Durango, CO to Moab, UT then west, though Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante to Boulder City, UT. We will then hop on the Wild West Route south through Arizona to the Mexico border. 

— Here's our route: 

Image source: hillmaps.com

Meet The Riders

Maleea Ezekiel and Flynn McFarland are avid outdoor enthusiasts. They have a passion for mountain biking, rock climbing, and mountaineering. Their passions have helped them to foster a deep connection with the desert and mountain landscapes in which they spend their time. This has inspired them to care for these wild places, and to protect them for years to come. Maleea is an aspiring geologist who is drawn to landscapes by a desire to understand the surrounding world, how it forms, and changes over time. Flynn is an outdoor leader and educator with a strong desire to share his passions to help people connect to wild places.

Photo: Kurt Refsnider 2017 

Donation & Impact

  • $2,000 for transportation, food and other necessities for our trip.
  • All other proceeds will be donated to the Native American Rights Fund, to further their efforts to fight for Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante.
 

Want to follow our journey?

Instagram: @pedal2protect

Facebook: www.facebook.com/pedal2protect/ 

Email us/Email list: pedal2protect@gmail.com

story:
Who We Are

Fins and Fluke is an all-volunteer organization that was founded in November 2012 dedicated to educating our communities about ocean conservation. The group’s team is spread throughout the United States and is committed to saving marine life. Each member of the team remains loyal to one or more specific cause and are responsible for information pertaining to this. The group shares petitions, articles, local events and simple “actions” that they believe will aid them positively in their cause. They also use social media and the power of our ocean-loving community to create successful campaigns.

What We Need & What You Get

In our 2nd year of existence, Fins and Fluke would like to step things up a bit by becoming an official non-profit in the state of Texas.

To cover the cost of the filing fee, we need $425 to become an official non-profit and receive tax-exempt 501(c)(3) status. As the good folks at Indiegogo take 9% of funds we raise, we projected our cost a little higher to cover incidentals and the fund transfer costs.

But what do you get if you contribute?  We have a few perks to offer you

$50 - get a sheet of Fins and Fluke glossy stickers and fridge magnet

$100 - a Fins and Fluke logo t-shirt and glossy stickers

$200 - a Whale and Dolphin Conservation whale adoption kit, stickers, and a fridge magnet

$300 - a one of a kind hand painted piece of art work by board member Michelle Johnson, sticker and some magnets


The Impact

Your contribution will help us achieve our dream of becoming an official 501(c)(3) charity/non-profit. We will be able to fund more of our own projects and create a bigger impact. We are hoping to start larger campaigns to further educate communities, both small and large, that otherwise are usually unattainable without non-profit status. We will finally be able to accept donations that will be used to will fund educational materials, conferences, events and we will also be able to give grants to other organizations that desperately need them.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you may not be able to make a monetary contribution, but there are other ways to help us reach our goal!

  • Use the “email” tool to share with family and friends
  • Use the tools at the top of this page to share this campaign on social networks
  • Word-of-mouth, tell your family and friends about our campaign

If you have an questions or concerns please feel free to contact us: info@finsandfluke.org

story:
My name is Dustin Crawford and I am 15 years old. I am a Life Scout in Troop 565. I have chosen my Eagle Project to help remodel and upgrade the West Columbia Gorge Humane Society cat shelter. I am going to be installing a handicap accessible ramp to the entrance and replacing their small sign with a bigger one. Also plants are going to be add to the front and a bigger landing. The biggest expense is, they are in need of a storage shed to hold all of their animal crates. Right now the crates are just piled up on the side of the building.

I have 3 other scout mates also working on different Eagle Projects for the West Columbia Gorge Humane Society cat shelter. Any funds I do not use will go towards helping fund their projects.

story:
http://www.spitfireheritagetrust.com/

Perranporth Airfield was awarded National Heritage status in 2000 with two areas of the airfield protected as Scheduled Monuments by “English Heritage”.  

But it is still critically at risk:  The entire airfield is up for sale and in immediate danger of being sold off in parcels.  We need to keep the airfield intact. With your help the Spitfire Heritage Trust will secure Perranporth airfield and bring it back to life  for “General Aviation” and as  “living museum” for Spitfires.

We are already almost half way to the  £1,650,000 needed for an outright purchase. Our friends and supporters have risen to the challenge with pledges and loans.  If we can raise the remainder the airfield will be saved forever. 

The landscape survives virtually as it was during World War II  making it, visually, a uniquely valuable heritage site.  The airfield stands  on the high cliffs of the Atlantic Ocean in an area of outstanding natural beauty with a glorious wildlife habitat and stunning coastal walks.  A small, friendly flying club and flying school operates from the site used by the local community and popular with visitors. These  are at risk too. 

The protected areas include very rare fighter pens, an underground battle headquarters and air-raid shelters along with pillboxes,  anti-aircraft defences and the  footings of associated buildings. The three and a half  miles of   perimeter track are also scheduled along with fighter dispersals. Although scheduled:  these all need to be conserved and made available for people to visit.

We all understand how important it is to preserve iconic items for the future. Restoration of vintage aircraft is very well supported and we believe that preserving the environment in which they operated is just as important.  Surprisingly: the environment is at far greater risk of being fragmented and lost.

It’s very necessary  that we should carry the  Spitfire “story” forwards because the telling of stories (and myths)  are the foundations of culture: the “glue” that binds societies together and connects us with our shared history.  The Spitfire is entering the realm of folklore and is on the cusp of something new.  So we plan to do something fresh, innovative and exciting with the airfield: not just preserve it in aspic.

In stages; 

  • we want to restore the airfield to its original condition, 
  • to  preserve the authentic environment 
  • to see it used again by Spitfires

TO CREATE A UNIQUE "LIVING MUSEUM”. 

The Trust runs projects that bring people together through an interest in the Spitfire.  When recently we parked a replica Spitfires in one of the fighter pens  the effect was electrifying;  illustrating the potential and the ease of dressing part of the airfield as it would have been in its heyday. 

The folk behind  the Trust are historians, pilots, teachers, and enthusiasts – all  volunteers of a non-profit organization  trying to find a way to save this  fabulous place for future generations. 

So this is where you could make a real difference:

·  If you make a donation this would be wonderful

·  If you visit and “Like” our facebook 

·  Share the campaign with your friends

PLEASE  HELP US TO SAVE THE  SPITFIRE AIRFIELD AND 

PROMOTE THE SPITFIRE STORY.

This IndieGoGo account is linked directly to the Spitfire Heritage Trust’s bank account and all the funds will go directly there.


More details about the campaign and a link to our Facebook page can be found on  www.spitfireheritagetrust.com

story:
SED develops community-scale solar and wind projects, ranging from large commercial installations that power towns and businesses with cost-effective renewable energy to smaller residential projects that generate clean electricity for your home.  SED installs projects throughout the Northeastern United States, with a specific focus on our local community in The Greater Rochester Area.  As part of our ongoing efforts to spread the benefits of solar and wind in our own backyards, SED is donating 5kW of solar equipment to a local nonprofit that can use the free electricity to focus their hard raised funding on their missions rather than their energy bills. 

Here's a link to a story on SED announcing ROC the SUN - http://www.rochesterhomepage.net/story/d/story/company-giving-away-solar-project-to-nonprofit/37705/pWq0rwrtSk2QyqIdugWrRA

SED selected Providence Housing Development Corporation (Providence Housing) as the recipient of the first ROC the SUN Solar Giveaway. Since 1994, Providence Housing has created more than 900 units of affordable housing in the Rochester area for seniors, individuals with special needs, and families. Providence Housing's mission is to strengthen families and communities by creating and providing access to quality affordable housing enriched by the availability of supportive services. Providence Housing develops, finances, and manages affordable housing in affiliation with the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester, NY. 

SED’s goal is to aid non-profit organizations by providing them with their own renewable energy generators.  These projects supply long term benefits and remove a significant operating cost so that the nonprofits can focus their funds on their noble, community supporting missions.  Crowdfunding renewable energy projects for local nonprofits is a tremendous opportunity to support the local institutions that are working to rebuild and support our communities.

SED has committed to donating the solar panels, design and installation labor for this project.  However, there are remaining funds that need to be raised in order to complete the project, totaling $3,500.  These additional funds are needed to pay for the electrical balance of system, racking, permit fees, and an inverter. 

The solar project will be installed at Providence Housing's Son House Apartments located at 539 Joseph Avenue in the City Rochester, NY. Son House provides 21 affordable one-bedroom apartments of permanent supportive housing for homeless individuals and helps people achieve stability through housing and case management services.

from large commercial installations that power towns and businesses with
cost-effective renewable energy to smaller residential projects that generate
clean electricity for your home.  SED
installs projects throughout the Northeastern United States, with a specific
focus on our local community in The Greater Rochester Area.  As part of our ongoing efforts to spread the
benefits of solar and wind in our own backyards, SED is donating 5kW of solar
equipment to a local nonprofit that can use the free electricity to focus their
hard raised funding on their missions rather than their energy bills. 
Here's a link to a story on SED announcing ROC the SUN - http://www.rochesterhomepage.net/story/d/story/company-giving-away-solar-project-to-nonprofit/37705/pWq0rwrtSk2QyqIdugWrRA

families. Providence Housing's mission is to strengthen families and

story:
Hi, we are the Leaffing Team.

We’ve come up with a system that allows you to shop online and care for the planet at the same time!

Why? 

Did you know that home deliveries from online shopping generate a massive output of CO2 into the air? It’s tons, literally! 


Like you, we love the web and we buy all sorts of things online. So we decided to see if we could come up with some solution. And we did, it’s Leaffing!

What is Leaffing?

  • Leaffing is a software that calculates the CO2 emissions of home deliveries from online shopping and tells you how much it costs to neutralize those emissions by contributing to an offset project, such as reforestation.
  • In addition, Leaffing is a website where you can look up an item and find it in all the online shops that use the Leaffing software.
  • Leaffing is also a community network: all e-shops that use the Leaffing software are linked to the network of offset project that became part of the Leaffing System. 
  • Last but not least, Leaffing is a feedback mechanism, in which one single contribution can actually trigger many more! 

Why is Leaffing a Solution  

With our system everybody wins:

  1. offset projects get to be financed,
  2. e-shops gain new customers
  3. and people are an active part of the solution!

What We Need Your Help For

CO2 emissions are on the rise and the situation in getting worse by the minute, so we want to develop the Leaffing System quickly

  • we need to continue developing the Leaffing System
  • we have to expand the network of offset projects and e-shops;
  •  and , most importantly, we need to make sure people know about Leaffing, which means a lot of marketing.

What You Will Get Out of This

First of all, we hope, your satisfaction! 
To all those that participate, we will be eternally grateful: we have been working on this very hard and will continue do so! 
They will be Leaffing Founding Participants and each will be featured on our wall.
Our rewards range from an invitation to the official Leaffing One Year Celebration Party to special organic cotton T-shirts all the way to a fantastic city bike!

Other Ways You can Help Leaffing

Leaffing is based on people,
  • their willingness to be active participants instead of passive spectators
  • their power to talk to friends and family, to tell them a story of a more sustainable world for everyone:

So, basically, Leaffing needs you to spread the word! You can use the sharing tools provided here, but, hey, you can be creative, too! 

Why not write about it, sing it, paint it, make comics out of it... whatever you do, DO tell us about it, and we will feature you and your idea on all our social media!!

                            

 
For more info and detail

Come visit our website at www.leaffing.com ! You will find more info and videos, and various ways to get in touch. Even more insights you will find in our blog 'LeaffingPost'. 

That's it from us. If you have any question, comment or suggestion, please do get in touch!! Thank you!

story:
20/20 Vision:  Summary of Campaign

Replenish is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization specifically created to provide clean water resources to developing countries.  Our purpose through the 20/20 Vision Campaign is to give others the opportunity to be a part of our mission to specifically provide clean water to schools in Homa Bay and the surrounding areas around Nairobi, Kenya.  As our mission includes a long-term commitment to specific communities, we are following up our successful campaign in October, 2014 with our Strategic Partner – Rotary Water Projects, Fort Lauderdale.  The 20/20 Vision Campaign builds on that initial launch which provided clean water for 3-5 years by providing purification filters and training for 82 schools and a Children’s Home.

What We Need & the Impact of Your Contribution

The 20/20 Vision Campaign is seeking to raise $20,000 to provide clean water for an additional 20 schools as well as support a mission trip for the leadership team to be a part of the distribution and training as well as follow up with the schools receiving the clean water last October to personally build relationship. 

The priority in raising funds will be the clean water resources first, the mission trip second.  Once the 20 schools are funded through purchasing the filters, plans will be finalized for the mission trip to Kenya in June, 2015.  Through our established partners and relationships in-country, the cost of the trip may decrease based on the offers for support by our hosting partners.  Any savings for trip expense will be directly used to purchase additional purification resources for additional schools.

The specifics for the $20,000 include:

Opportunity:

Investment:

Results/Impact:

Adopt a School

through a donation towards 

LifeStraw Community Filters (LSC)

$275 per 70 children (less than $4 per child)

Goal:

Total  $13,750  (3,500 students)

or any portion designated for use toward purchase of LSC filters

Clean water for 3-5 years for students and staff in designated schools  

Current Focus: 

Homa Bay and Nairobi, Kenya

Missions

$6,250  

or any portion designated for use toward missions:

Airfare:  $4,200  ($2,100 x 2)

Lodging:   $950 

Transportation:   $600

($300 x 2 including airfare from Nairobi to Kisumu, to Homa Bay, ferry  to Mfangano Island, etc):  

Food:   $500  ($250 x 2)

Missions to Kenya: Summer, 2015

for Replenish leadership team (2)

Mission Goals:

LifeStraw distribution, education and training, evangelism, projects

Photo:   Phase One of Clean Water Initiative

Homa Bay, Kenya, October, 2014

Risks & Challenges

We believe our risk is minimal in traveling to Kenya as we are confident in our established relationships with locals, schools, and churches in the Nairobi and Homa Bay area.  In addition, as the warehouse for LifeStraw distribution is in Nairobi, there will be no risk associated with transporting the filters across the country or between countries.  In the unexpected case that a travel restriction is enforced that results in cancelling the trip, ALL refunded amounts will be redirected to purchase additional purification resources for additional schools.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider your part in sharing our mission by:

Making a donation (see previous table for specific needs)

Sharing the 20/20 Vision and the mission of Replenish with others through social media:

 www.replenishwater.org 

@replenishwater

 https://instagram.com/replenish_water/

 www.facebook.com/ReplenishWater 

  and the Indiegogo share tools

Praying for the mission and for those receiving the clean water.

story:
Voici que je prépare un nouveau départ !

C'est dans  les Pyrénées que j'ai passé mes 25 dernières années.......J'ai élevé mes enfants, j'ai été à plusieurs reprises commerçante dans une contrée où créer son activité était une alternative à la rareté de l'emploi. Mes enfants devenus indépendants, alors passionnée par le Moyen-âge,  j'ai monté une compagnie de spectacle médiévale, avec laquelle j'ai voyagé à travers la France. Au fil des ans et de mes expériences, mon intérêt pour l'épanouissement de l'être est devenu primordial..........En marche vers moi-même, je choisis de répondre à l'appel d'une Terre qui me parle depuis longtemps : la Bretagne ! Voici plusieurs mois que je monte régulièrement en Finistère (voir photo d'un lieu où je vais me ressourcer), afin de faire connaissance avec cette région. Oui, c'est bien là que je désire passer mes prochaines années. Un projet professionnel se dessine également, mais à l'instant ou j'écris ces lignes, rien n'est encore fait. Ma volonté et ma détermination me pousse aujourd'hui à utiliser Indiego : en effet, si mon abondance me permet d'avoir toujours des rêves et des projets en cours et l'enthousiasme de les poursuivre, j'ai besoin de 1000€ pour les mener à bien.

Cette somme me permettrait de payer mon voyage (carburant et péage), la caution d'un appartement en arrivant, et la nourriture et frais durant le mois de mon arrivée, le temps que je m'occupe de tous mes dossiers administratifs (dossier allocation logement, dossier assédic (demande d'ass) et si celui-ci m'est refusé, ma demande de RSA. Comme vous le voyez, je pars "à vide", matériellement et financièrement. Ce n'est la première fois et je connais mon aptitude à "rebondir". C'est aussi pourquoi, je passe à l'acte plutôt que rester figée par le manque ou la peur. Car je suis une habituée des "sauts du haut de la falaise " et cette fois ci encore, je suis fidèle à moi-même !

Tout ce que j'expose ici ne sont que les faits de l'instant présent et que peut-être une autre solution à ma demande sur Indiego se présentera..........mais c'est en posant des actes maintenant que la Vie me répondra tout à l'heure ! Alors, je commence par m'aider tout de suite !

Merci à vous de m'avoir lu jusqu'ici et de votre soutien quel qu'il soit, financier, énergétique, ou en passant l'info ! Bon chemin à vous, portez vous bien et que la Vie vous porte !

story:
The Facts 

Kinder Morgan, a huge Texas based transnational oil corporation, plans to build a new pipeline to ship almost 1 million barrels of heavy crude oil (dilbit) a day from the tar sands in Alberta to the B.C. coast. The pipeline will go through conservation lands, seismically active areas and unceded Coast Salish territory. 

In response, people began mobilizing on the Burnaby Mountain Conservation area when Kinder Morgan crews started clear cutting trees to install drill-testing equipment. As many as 800 people at a time showed up to protest Kinder Morgan expansion. But five people were soon charged with a $5.6 million civil suit to stop them from organizing the protests. 

It was argued that the civil suit to prevent protests was in fact a SLAPP suit, or strategic litigation against public participation. The whole point of a SLAPP suit is to bring a lawsuit to make little guys spend lots of time, energy and money, and then drop it before it can come before a court of law where, in this case, the transnational would have to prove the allegations of conspiracy, etc.. The transnational then drops the SLAPP suit before it can go to court so that the threat of reviving the lawsuit continues to hang over the little guy. The transnational has to pay a portion (usually very small) of their funds to keep the suit "alive," but it's a small investment. As a portion of the little guy's funds, however, it is huge. This is why anti-SLAPP legislation is so important in a democratic country like Canada. Anti-SLAPP suit legislation is the way big guys can be penalized for using the law in this way to silence their critics and stop protests. 

Alan Dutton is leading the fight against Big Oil. He was charged personally and as a representative of the Burnaby Residents Opposing Kinder Morgan Expansion, or BROKE. That non-profit group has been organizing town halls and community events for the past two years since Kinder Morgan announced plans to expand.

Alan has argued in court that Kinder Morgan's civil suit is nothing more than a SLAPP suit. Now he's working to organize a petition against SLAPP suits and he's building a coalition to develop legal remedies against SLAPP suits. He has the support of the West Coast Environmental Law Foundation, but he needs your help.

These are the facts:

• Kinder Morgan's project is opposed by BROKE, the City of Burnaby and 70% of local residents.

 • Kinder Morgan is claiming $5.6 million in damages against five individuals named in a civil suit. Two quietly settled while three continued to fight back. 

 • Alan Dutton is leading the fight for anti-SLAPP legislation.

This is a case that affects everyone's democratic rights. Alan needs help to win in court so we can continue supporting our community against big oil. Maneuvering 400 supertankers a year through the narrows of beautiful Burrard Inlet will bring spills that foul the shores of Burnaby, Vancouver, and many other municipalities. Kinder Morgan's plan makes no sense.

We Need

Fighting legal battles against a huge corporation takes incredible resolve and it's expensive: Alan needs to raise $10,000 to pay legal fees. Any funds in excess of legal fees will go to anti-SLAPP legislation. Please donate using the Paypal link.    

The Impact

Our homes, schools, and parks will face increased danger from pipeline spills like the Kinder Morgan spill in Burnaby in 2007.  We're standing up for our public lands, for the rights of First Nations who have not been properly consulted, for the rights of our local government to decide what happens in our public parks and for the right to protest large transnational corporations.
Kinder-Morgan has launched a SLAPP suit against Alan in an attempt to curtail genuine and legitimate participation by ordinary people. It is anti-democratic and we must not let people be silenced by threats of lawsuits for peaceful political activities. 
• Your support will help us continue our opposition to the proposed Kinder Morgan Pipeline Expansion Project. 
• This suit is about the democratic rights we all take for granted. We have a right to express our selves and protest in lawful non-violent ways.  
• We have legitimate concerns about local impacts and stopping global climate change.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks don't have the funds to donate. We understand! You can still help us by:

• Sharing this page with your contacts in social media and by writing letters to the editors of news papers in your community.
• Visiting our website at http://brokepipeline.org/
• Joining us on on Facebook and "like" and "share" https://www.facebook.com/BurnabyPipelineWatch 
• Follow information about SLAPP suits in the media and news about our continuing legal battle with Kinder Morgan:  
Getting ‘slapped’ by big oil
Kinder Morgan Lawsuit Renews Anti-slapp Calls
 Fighting for the right to protest: Burnaby resident takes- Kinder Morgan to courts


Every little thing helps!

•	Sharing this page with your contacts in social media and by writing letters to the editors of news papers in your community.•	Visiting our website at http://brokepipeline.org/•	Joining us on on Facebook and "like" and "share" https://www.facebook.com/BurnabyPipelineWatch •	Follow information about SLAPP suits in the media and news about our continuing legal battle with Kinder Morgan:  
Getting ‘slapped’ by big oilKinder Morgan Lawsuit Renews Anti-slapp Calls Fighting for the right to protest: Burnaby resident takes- Kinder Morgan to courtsEvery little thing helps!

story:
Every year 2.2 billion gallons of gasoline are used to maintain lawns alone in the United States, notes Dr. Leonard Perry of the University of Vermont. 

The EPA estimates that 17 million gallons of gasoline are spilled each year refueling lawn care equipment. This means we are drizzling more fuel on the ground than the Exxon Valdez oil spill, every single year. 

The EPA also estimates that a single gasoline powered mower contributes eleven times the amount of pollution of that of a new car, per hour of operation. 

Like many, I find these numbers disturbing. To address these issues I have built a landscape maintenance truck that runs on biodiesel and charges battery powered equipment as it drives. I have a basic set up that is functional and currently reducing the consumption of fossil fuels. 

Drop by drop, I am making a difference.

Two years ago I had an opportunity to rethink not what I want to do with my life but how to do it. I was at square one. I started by purchasing the best truck I could afford. It cost $750. Imagine if you will, a 1994 F250, missing a couple of windows, the dash ripped apart with wires coming out of places there ought not be wires, the steering column disassembled with a hammer, no keys or straight body panels, and a load of decaying trash in the bed. Most people would never consider buying such a vehicle for obvious and understandable reasons. But I am not most people, I could see past the ugly exterior of the vehicle. Beneath the skin of this monstrosity was a rare, factory turbo diesel engine. The perfect platform to build a company and mobile power source upon. I pieced the ignition back together, put some fresh batteries in it and had it running within an hour. The engine fired up without struggle and made known the power that had been asleep under the hood. I shook the previous owners hand, did the appropriate paper work, gave him cash and drove off with a load of garbage and my new rescued work truck. 

I immediately began piecing it back together and building upon my idea. I imagined combining multiple varieties of sustainable technologies and demonstrating responsible stewardship in the yards of homeowners, schools, and parks. In May of 2014 I completed an operational and functional base of my dream. I had created Ecos Landscaping and maintained its first gasoline-free account. 

Now that I have a working model of operation, I would like to share my project in the hopes of both gaining support and inspiring others to pursue sustainable enterprise. 

I nicknamed my project "The PROTO-HYPE" based on its experimental and promotional nature. It is a custom, heavy duty turbo diesel work truck, loaded with tools and capability. The PROTO-HYPE is fueled by B100 that comes from a local biodiesel manufacturer. A charge isolator allows me to maintain a secondary bank of batteries that is independent from the primary truck batteries . The secondary battery bank powers a DC to AC inverter creating your standard household outlet. From there, I plug in lithium-ion chargers to charge the batteries that run my landscape equipment. I have a basic set of battery tools that includes a small mower, hedger, string trimmer and blower. This is enough to get me through about three small residential accounts or one small apartment complex per day.  

My goal for this campaign is to acquire top of the line equipment as well as demonstrate the true potential of my vision. I will help establish a new standard of business within my industry and provide an easily duplicable model of operation to follow. 

I prioritize environmental impact over the cost of doing business. It is not cheap to purchase cutting edge power equipment nor is it to experiment with new fuels but this is something I truly believe will make a positive difference in the world and therefore worth the added costs. The more that people support alternative fuel, energy, and sustainable business the more they will become readily available and competitive. My plan is to evolve with the introduction of new technologies and take reasonable risks to advance their use. 

After all, if you don't want to go out on a limb, you probably shouldn't be a landscaper! 

What I Need 


The plan is to upgrade my existing battery bank and inverter, expand the tool arsenal, add some decent image and marketing to the mix and go to town.  

These are the needed components:

  • Four heavy duty 435 amp hour 6 volt batteries (as soon as organic based flow batteries are available I will upgrade)                                   $2,500
  • 10,000 Watt DC to AC Inverter                                               $1,200
  • Solar Panel                                                                                      $250
  • Charge Controller                                                                             $75
  • Lithium Ion Rapid Charger                                                           $175
  • 36 Volt Lithium Ion Battery Pack                                              $200
  • 2-36 Volt Backpack Batteries                                                $2,200 
  • 36 Volt Blower                                                                               $300
  • 2-20" Lithium-Ion Mowers, Batteries and Chargers           $2,200
  • 36 Volt Lithium-Ion Extended Hedger                                     $400
  • 6x12 Enclosed Trailer                                                                $3,500
  • In Bed Transfer Fuel Tank and Pump                                    $1,000
  • Advertisement                                                                            $3,000
  • Perks                                                                                              $2,500
  • Potential Indigogo Fees for $25,000 at 9%                          $2,250  ______________________________________________________
                                                                                        TOTAL          $21,750

This leaves me with a cushion of $3,250, about 15%, to cover unexpected expenses. 


What you get:

Aside from the humble perks I am offering, the main thing contributors will receive from this campaign is cleaner air, decreased noise pollution and the satisfaction of knowing you helped support a better environment for all.


This Campaign will accomplish the following:

  • Demonstrate ways to help eliminate the use of petroleum within landscape maintenance and other industries
  • Strengthen the local economy through purchasing locally-produced fuel
  • Promote innovative and progressive technologies
  • Demonstrate competitive sustainable business
  • Increase consumer confidence in alternative energy and sustainability 

Risks & Challenges


Risk # 1  -  Funding goal not met

This is more than a campaign for me. I am very dedicated to pursuing this dream and will continue to be so regardless. I have chosen the flexible funding platform and will be able to receive the funds generated by this campaign, whether I make my goal of $25,000 or not. In the event that I do not reach this sum, the money I acquire will still be put toward my ongoing efforts to drive the sustainable energy hype. After fees and perks are taken care of, I will apply the remaining funds to acquiring what tools I can and continue to push forward with passion. 


Risk # 2 Truck and Tools are Damaged, Lost or Stolen

After being in business for myself for over seven years, I have acquired the skill of keeping the tools I rely on to make a living, safe. However, this project will also be insured. 


Risk #3 Unforeseen Technical Difficulties

With any project it is reasonable to assume your going to run into an unanticipated obstacle. I have also adapted a skill to resolve things of this nature. First, tell yourself that something unexpected is bound to happen before you start and when it does, welcome it as a challenge. Step two is to identify what kind of an obstacle it is and decide if you have adequate resources to resolve the issue. If not, go get the necessary resources. Step three, keep an open mind and start the trial and error process. There have been many times I have found myself broke down in the mountains or the side of a remote highway by myself.  Many times I have been able to repair my vehicle to a varying degree and make it home safe. Over the years I have found the thing that makes the most difference in solving a problem is to stay creative and calm. It's okay to be bummed when things happen but it is essential to continue brainstorming and solving problems.  


Risk #4 Project is over funded

In the event that this campaign is more than successful, additional funds will be applied toward expanding this business model-- more trucks and a sustainable garden supply store. I feel a great sense of responsibility to improve the way we live and work. While much of the world is suffering harsh consequences of inequality, I am free to pursue my dreams. This thought has instilled in me a sense of obligation-- an obligation to make the most of the resources available to me and to let the rest of the world know that California cares and wants to improve life for all. Despite my struggles, I just happen to of been born in an area where food is inexpensive (if you don't eat overpriced garbage), housing is available and there is a market for hard work. I feel that I owe the world something tangible, in return, for providing me with a beautiful and relatively peaceful life. I realized that because most industries value profits over health, the environment is being destroyed and species of all kinds are suffering unmentionable pain. My motivation in doing this is that the thing which brings me the most joy in life is knowing that I tried my hardest to make an honorable difference in the world. The responsible dispersion of an exceptionally successful campaign would be an honor.  


Other Ways You Can Help

The overall objective of this project is to increase the use of sustainable technology through increasing consumer confidence in alternative energy and fuel. What this campaign needs, in addition to funding, is HYPE! We are fighting not only to establish that it is possible to use alternative energy, but that it leaves fossil fuels in the dark. Talk about how badass your battery powered motorcycle is going to be --build a bio-diesel hot rod --support competitive green businesses --tell your landscaper to look this up and duplicate it  --boast about the food you bought from a small farmer --STOP USING PESTICIDES --tell your children that taking care of the earth and each other is the most important thing we need to do --take the time to tell people that you give a damn about doing things better!   

Please help FUND and SHARE this campaign to help Drive the Sustainability Hype!
