story:
IF  YOU'RE READING THIS... 

...you know Sissy. And you know that this year marks her 40th birthday. And you know that she loves her book club. And you know she loves to sit outside and light a fire and drink wine. And she has always, always had a dream to build a "treehouse" (on the ground) in her backyard, where people can gather to do all these things.

What are friends for if not for making crazy dreams come true? 

LET'S MAKE IT HAPPEN

Sissy's Birthday Treehouse will be built safely, by someone who knows what they're doing, to last for years and years. After initial talks with a builder, we think it's going to take about $10K to make this thing not only real, but awesome. 

However much we can raise here will go toward the project. 

The rest will have to be raised by book club members selling their organs on the black market. Please, don't let that happen.

WHAT YOU GET!

- All sorts of fabulous perks, ranging from fun prizes to an invitation to the treehouse blueprint unveiling party to your name on a plaque of contributors on the treehouse wall to personalized art to your very own CHAIR in the treehouse! (It all depends on how much you give.) 

And hey, no pressure. If you're not rolling around on piles of cash every night before you fall asleep, we still love you. You absolutely don't have to give. Just enjoy the video, eat a cookie on Sissy's behalf this month, and wish Sissy a very happy birthday next time you see her!

story:
Help us preserve this primeval cloud forest with the indigenous Maya!

Deep in the Guatemalan highlands where the Quiche forest Maya  live, an incredible discovery was recently made: Cerro el Amay. 

This mist-shrouded paradise is the largest unprotected virgin (old growth) cloud forest in northern Central America.  Amazingly, this forest was completely unknown to science until recently, and exploration has only just begun.  This rich and unique forest has already yielded many species potentially new to science in our first explorations.  Cerro el Amay contains vast systems of caves with underground streams, stalactites, stalagmites and other cave formations.  Massive sinkholes harbor unique ecosystems with unique fauna and flora.   With the rich and ancient history of these Mayan lands, there is no telling what mysteries and adventures will unfold in our February-March 2015 Eco-Adventure into the heart of the forest, sinkholes and caves!  You can be a part of this adventure; see the perks below!

Under the duress of economic pressure, the Quiché Maya, who have held the forest communally for generations, are beginning to not only harvest the ancient trees but survey and sell parcels of the land to support their needs.  Loggers and speculators are lining up to buy, but we are fighting on behalf of the forest and wildlife. We work with indigenous communities to plant food trees, creating economic independence, and helping them to conserve and protect their sacred forest.  As land rights come up for sale we are stepping in to purchase them to establish the new Cerro el Amay Cloud Forest Preserve. This will preserve the ancient forest for generations to come.  

Are you ready to join us on the adventure of a lifetime?  

Time is of the essence.  We need your help to make this Preserve a reality.

Welcome to the team!

The CFCI Board


Who we are:

The Cloud Forest Conservation Initiative (CFCI) is a nonprofit organization, based in the US and Guatemala, working with US-based, Conservation Imaging Inc. (CI), a 501(c)3 nonprofit, for the preservation and conservation of the largest unprotected Tropical Montane Cloud Forest in northern Central America.  This forested jewel, Cerro el Amay, is located in Quiché Department, in the karstic Guatemalan highlands, specifically in the Sierra de Chama, and contains more than 19,000 hectares (46,950 acres) of ancient, pristine cloud forest and nearly 3,000 hectares (7,415 acres) of undeveloped, second growth.  This unique and sensitive habitat is home to multiple threatened and endangered species, as well as species new to science, and is home to several communities of indigenous Maya. 


Current Threats: 

The integrity and pristine quality of Cerro el Amay is threatened by numerous environmental and physical impacts.  These include but are not limited to illegal logging, poaching, encroaching slash-and-burn agriculture, road building, climate change, and unsustainable development. 


Objectives:

  • Establish a majestic cloud forest preserve in the heart of the Guatemalan highlands through direct acquisitions, land agreements, and conservation easements.
  • Work in concert with indigenous communities to create sustainable economic and ecologically-sensitive development projects that will enable the communities to thrive.
  • Spearhead reforestation through our Macadamia Conservation Exchange (MCE) program.
  • Create a center for biological & environmental research, eco-tourism, and cultural heritage.
  • Conduct biological inventories and karst/cave surveys.


What We Need 

Ads by PassShowAd Options

Money and people.  Our crowd-sourcing campaign funds will help CFCI:

  • Identify and target parcels for reforestation.
  • Collaborate with indigenous partners to implement the Macadamia-Conservation Exchange.
  • Train local Mayan guides to lead their own eco-adventures in the cloud forest.
  • Install greywater (domestic effluent) treatment in headwater villages.
  • Conduct threatened and endangered species surveys.
  • Inventory the cave system.
  • Negotiate the protection and purchase of land rights.
Specifically, $12,000 USD will pay for materials to train Mayan guides in climbing/rappelling, safety training, greywater systems, environmental monitoring, trail maintenance/design, macadamia trees, hand tools, and personnel transportation costs.  Any funding received in excess of our goal will be applied directly towards land preservation through purchase of land rights.  We also want to see you in the cloud forest.  Come and join us!



What You Get (Perks):

$15 ~ We will give you an awesome virtual high-five and plant a tree in your honor (personalized with your name on a metal name tag) at Cerro el Amay restoration sites.

$25 ~ Yes! Another virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a copy of board member Rob Lenfestey's new CD of world music.

$50 ~ Stepping it up! Now you get a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a CFCI tea/coffee mug.

$100 ~ A round figure! You'll receive a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a cotton canvas CFCI shopping bag.

$150 ~ Thanks! For this level of contribution you get a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a signed and glass/oak framed high resolution photograph from the cloud forest.  Choices will be emailed to you.

$200 ~ Take the next step! This will award you with a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a unique Mayan weave (table runner or wall hanging). The image below is just an example of a table runner.

$350 ~ May the forest be with you!  This level of gift wins you a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a Mayan basket set made of mimbre root fibers, a species of arboreal Monstera plant that can only be found growing in the cloud forest. We are the only source of these baskets, which are hand made by Juan Chivalan and his wife, Maria at one of our Conservation Communities in the cloud forest!

$2,500 ~ Making things happen!  For this level of donation, you'll receive a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a seat on the February 27 - March 11, 2015 cloud forest eco-adventure with board members and indigenous Mayan guides.  This perk can be gifted to another person in your honor.

http://inchantedjourneys.com/portfolio/guatemala-2015/

$10,000 ~ World changer!  For this level of donation, we will provide, a dozen trees planted in your honor with personalized metal name tags, and an all-expenses paid trip to the Cerro el Amay cloud forest led by one or two of our board members, as well as our friends in the indigenous communities.  This trip comes with expert interpretation of the cloud forest environment.

$14,500 ~ A gift that will endure by conserving 111 acres of virgin cloud forest!  With this level of donation, not only do you receive two virtual high-fives, but we will also plant fifty trees in your name, with metal name tags on each one, but more importantly, we will be able to purchase a derecho (111 acres) to add to the cloud forest preserve now being managed by CFCI.

http://www.forestprimeval.org/land_purchase_program.xhtml

All donations will be acknowledged on our website.  All donations are tax-deductible, and all donations over $50 will receive a vellum-parchment letter of thanks from the Executive Director of CFCI.  All funds raised in this crowd-sourcing campaign will go towards CFCI and the preservation of Cerro el Amay.

The Impact

CFCI is creating a primal cloud forest preserve which is not only a biological haven, but also serves as a headwaters region for many communities and municipalities. Some lands have already been preserved through philanthropic donations, biological studies, and conservation agreements.  Cerro el Amay contains many endangered and threatened species.  Some of the rare species known to exist there include; 

  • Black-handed spider monkey, 
  • Guatemalan black howler monkey, 
  • Resplendent Quetzal, among the most beautiful birds in the world.
  • Highland Guan (Penelopina nigra), and 
  • The Guatemalan spike-thumb frog.  
  • A terrestrial crab that may be new to science, living in the mountains.

CFCI's efforts will also help improve the indigenous Mayan communities, by providing the people with ecologically-sensitive economic developments.  Our current developments include:

  • Planting specialty crops that curb poverty--especially macadamia and cacao trees.
  • Helping the Maya enroll their lands into the Forestry Incentives Program whereby they can receive a cash incentive for every year they conserve the forest.
  • Improving water quality with domestic greywater treatment systems.
  • Increasing local revenue from indigenous craft sales through direct marketing.
  • Facilitating eco-tourism via cloud forest tours for international travelers.

Risks & Challenges

This project requires a multi-tiered effort on the behalf of the cloud forest and the indigenous people.  We have to move quickly and effectively because chain saws are running, and most of Cerro el Amay remains unprotected.  Together we can work to establish this region as a preserve.

Since establishing the Cloud Forest Conservation Initiative in 2009, we have made exciting progress working with communities to create new sources of income that protect and restore the endangered forests and watersheds.  By focusing international attention on cloud forest concerns, we provide material and logistical force at local and regional levels and help local leaders protect the cloud forest.  Our successful strategy in the management planning of Cerro el Amay includes engaging:

  • Local communities and schools, 
  • Community organizations,  
  • Government agencies,
  • Guatemalan universities,
  • Other nonprofits and NGO's,
  • Philanthropists, and
  • People like you who care!  
While focusing specifically on this primal cloud forest in Guatemala, it is essential to recognize that CI board members have many years of experience with successfully implementing conservation and sustainable development strategies around the world.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Organize a music, yoga, or arts event in a city near you to help raise awareness. Initiate one in your community, or plug into an existing fund-raising events.  
  • Send out emails to friends and family.  
  • Share our campaign and video on Facebook.
  • Help us find philanthropists and other donors to underwrite specific projects or purchase land in the cloud forest on CFCI's behalf.
  • Visit the cloud forest with us:  http://inchantedjourneys.com/portfolio/guatemala-2015/
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.
  • Support our teaming partners and their businesses, because they have been underwriting this project so far with private funds and micro grants.

Teaming Partners:

Conservation Imaging, Inc.; Clif Bar Family Foundation; Unaka Environmental, LLC; Norcross Wildlife Foundation, Valhalla Macadamia Experiment Station; University of Guatemala San Carlos; Guatemala Valley University; Guatemalan Protected Areas Council; Chimel Development Association; La Gloria Integrated Development Association; Inchanted Journeys; Mandala Chocolates; and, Divinitree Yoga. 

Video & Image Credits:

Music:  Alex Caruso & Rob Lenfestey                                                                                         Video Editing:  Alex Caruso                                                                                                               Film Crew:  Jeremy Schewe & Rob Lenfestey                                                                             Still Shots:  Philip Tanimoto, Rob Lenfestey & Jeremy Schewe                                           Voice/Narration:  Diane Gardner

Learn more at:

WWW.FORESTPRIMEVAL.ORG
story_txt:
Help us preserve this primeval cloud forest with the indigenous Maya!




Deep in the Guatemalan highlands where the Quiche forest Maya  live, an incredible discovery was recently made: Cerro el Amay. 

This mist-shrouded paradise is the largest unprotected virgin (old growth) cloud forest in northern Central America.  Amazingly, this forest was completely unknown to science until recently, and exploration has only just begun.  This rich and unique forest has already yielded many species potentially new to science in our first explorations.  Cerro el Amay contains vast systems of caves with underground streams, stalactites, stalagmites and other cave formations.  Massive sinkholes harbor unique ecosystems with unique fauna and flora.   With the rich and ancient history of these Mayan lands, there is no telling what mysteries and adventures will unfold in our February-March 2015 Eco-Adventure into the heart of the forest, sinkholes and caves!  You can be a part of this adventure; see the perks below!
Under the duress of economic pressure, the Quiché Maya, who have held the forest communally for generations, are beginning to not only harvest the ancient trees but survey and sell parcels of the land to support their needs.  Loggers and speculators are lining up to buy, but we are fighting on behalf of the forest and wildlife. We work with indigenous communities to plant food trees, creating economic independence, and helping them to conserve and protect their sacred forest.  As land rights come up for sale we are stepping in to purchase them to establish the new Cerro el Amay Cloud Forest Preserve. This will preserve the ancient forest for generations to come.  
Are you ready to join us on the adventure of a lifetime?  
Time is of the essence.  We need your help to make this Preserve a reality.

Welcome to the team!

The CFCI Board


Who we are:


The
Cloud Forest Conservation Initiative (CFCI) is a nonprofit organization, based in the US and Guatemala, working with US-based, Conservation Imaging Inc. (CI),
a 501(c)3 nonprofit, for the preservation and conservation of the largest
unprotected Tropical Montane Cloud Forest in northern Central America.  This forested jewel, Cerro el Amay, is
located in Quiché Department, in the karstic Guatemalan highlands, specifically
in the Sierra de Chama, and contains
more than 19,000 hectares (46,950 acres) of ancient, pristine cloud forest and nearly
3,000 hectares (7,415 acres) of undeveloped, second growth.  This unique and sensitive habitat is home to
multiple threatened and endangered species, as well as species new to science,
and is home to several communities of indigenous Maya.  





Current Threats: 

The integrity and pristine quality
of Cerro el Amay is threatened by
numerous environmental and physical impacts. 
These include but are not limited to illegal logging, poaching,
encroaching slash-and-burn agriculture, road building, climate change, and
unsustainable development.  



Objectives:

Establish a majestic cloud forest preserve in the heart of the Guatemalan highlands through direct acquisitions, land agreements, and conservation easements.
Work in concert with indigenous communities to create sustainable economic and ecologically-sensitive development projects that will enable the communities to thrive.
Spearhead reforestation through our Macadamia Conservation Exchange (MCE) program.
Create a center for biological & environmental research, eco-tourism, and cultural heritage.
Conduct biological inventories and karst/cave surveys.  



What We Need 






Ads by PassShowAd Options

 Money and people.  Our crowd-sourcing campaign funds will help CFCI:



Identify and target parcels for reforestation.
Collaborate with indigenous partners to implement the Macadamia-Conservation Exchange.
Train local Mayan guides to lead their own eco-adventures in the cloud forest.
Install greywater (domestic effluent) treatment in headwater villages.
Conduct threatened and endangered species surveys.
Inventory the cave system.
Negotiate the protection and purchase of land rights.

Specifically, $12,000 USD will pay for materials to train Mayan guides in climbing/rappelling, safety training, greywater systems, environmental monitoring, trail maintenance/design, macadamia trees, hand tools, and personnel transportation costs.  Any funding received in excess of our goal will be applied directly towards land preservation through purchase of land rights.  We also want to see you in the cloud forest.  Come and join us! 




What You Get (Perks):
$15 ~ We will give you an awesome virtual high-five and plant a tree in your honor (personalized with your name on a metal name tag) at Cerro el Amay restoration sites.
$25 ~ Yes! Another virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a copy of board member Rob Lenfestey's new CD of world music.
$50 ~ Stepping it up! Now you get a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a CFCI tea/coffee mug.



$100 ~ A round figure! You'll receive a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a cotton canvas CFCI shopping bag.



$150 ~ Thanks! For this level of contribution you get a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a signed and glass/oak framed high resolution photograph from the cloud forest.  Choices will be emailed to you.
$200 ~ Take the next step! This will award you with a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a unique Mayan weave (table runner or wall hanging). The image below is just an example of a table runner.



$350 ~ May the forest be with you!  This level of gift wins you a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a Mayan basket set made of mimbre root fibers, a species of arboreal Monstera plant that can only be found growing in the cloud forest. We are the only source of these baskets, which are hand made by Juan Chivalan and his wife, Maria at one of our Conservation Communities in the cloud forest!



$2,500 ~ Making things happen!  For this level of donation, you'll receive a virtual high-five, a tree planted in your honor with a metal name tag, and a seat on the February 27 - March 11, 2015 cloud forest eco-adventure with board members and indigenous Mayan guides.  This perk can be gifted to another person in your honor.
http://inchantedjourneys.com/portfolio/guatemala-2015/



$10,000 ~ World changer!  For this level of donation, we will provide, a dozen trees planted in your honor with personalized metal name tags, and an all-expenses paid trip to the Cerro el Amay cloud forest led by one or two of our board members, as well as our friends in the indigenous communities.  This trip comes with expert interpretation of the cloud forest environment.



$14,500 ~ A gift that will endure by conserving 111 acres of virgin cloud forest!  With this level of donation, not only do you receive two virtual high-fives, but we will also plant fifty trees in your name, with metal name tags on each one, but more importantly, we will be able to purchase a derecho (111 acres) to add to the cloud forest preserve now being managed by CFCI.
http://www.forestprimeval.org/land_purchase_program.xhtml


All donations will be acknowledged on our website.  All donations are tax-deductible, and all donations over $50 will receive
a vellum-parchment letter of thanks from the Executive Director of CFCI.  All funds raised in this crowd-sourcing campaign will go towards CFCI and the preservation of Cerro el Amay.   The Impact CFCI is creating a primal cloud forest preserve which is not only a biological haven, but also serves as a headwaters region for many communities and municipalities. Some lands have already been preserved through philanthropic donations, biological studies, and conservation agreements.  Cerro el Amay contains many endangered and threatened species.  Some of the rare species known to exist there include;  
Black-handed spider monkey, 
Guatemalan black howler monkey, 
Resplendent Quetzal, among the most beautiful birds in the world.
Highland Guan (Penelopina nigra), and 
The Guatemalan spike-thumb frog.  
A terrestrial crab that may be new to science, living in the mountains.


CFCI's efforts will also help improve the indigenous Mayan communities, by providing the people with ecologically-sensitive economic developments.  Our current developments include:

Planting specialty crops that curb poverty--especially macadamia and cacao trees.
Helping the Maya enroll their lands into the Forestry Incentives Program whereby they can receive a cash incentive for every year they conserve the forest.
Improving water quality with domestic greywater treatment systems.

Increasing local revenue from indigenous craft sales through direct marketing.
Facilitating eco-tourism via cloud forest tours for international travelers.

Risks & Challenges  This project requires a multi-tiered effort on the behalf of the cloud forest and the indigenous people.  We have to move quickly and effectively because chain saws are running, and most of Cerro el Amay remains unprotected.  Together we can work to establish this region as a preserve.
Since establishing the Cloud Forest Conservation Initiative in 2009, we have made exciting progress working with communities to create new sources of income that protect and restore the endangered forests and watersheds.  By focusing international attention on cloud forest concerns, we provide material and logistical force at local and regional levels and help local leaders protect the cloud forest.  Our successful strategy in the management planning of Cerro el Amay includes engaging:


Local communities and schools, 
Community organizations,  
Government agencies,
Guatemalan universities,
Other nonprofits and NGO's,
Philanthropists, and
People like you who care!  

While focusing specifically on this primal cloud forest in Guatemala, it is essential to recognize that CI board members have many years of experience with successfully implementing conservation and sustainable development strategies around the world.      Other Ways You Can Help 
Organize a music, yoga, or arts event in a city near you to help raise awareness. Initiate one in your community, or plug into an existing fund-raising events.  
Send out emails to friends and family.  
Share our campaign and video on Facebook.
Help us find philanthropists and other donors to underwrite specific projects or purchase land in the cloud forest on CFCI's behalf.
Visit the cloud forest with us:  http://inchantedjourneys.com/portfolio/guatemala-2015/
 Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.
Support our teaming partners and their businesses, because they have been underwriting this project so far with private funds and micro grants.   Teaming Partners:
Conservation Imaging, Inc.; Clif Bar Family Foundation; Unaka Environmental, LLC; Norcross Wildlife Foundation, Valhalla Macadamia Experiment Station; University of Guatemala San Carlos; Guatemala Valley University; Guatemalan Protected Areas Council; Chimel Development Association; La Gloria Integrated Development Association; Inchanted Journeys; Mandala Chocolates; and, Divinitree Yoga. Video & Image Credits:
Music:  Alex Caruso & Rob Lenfestey                                                                                         Video Editing:  Alex Caruso                                                                                                               Film Crew:  Jeremy Schewe & Rob Lenfestey                                                                             Still Shots:  Philip Tanimoto, Rob Lenfestey & Jeremy Schewe                                           Voice/Narration:  Diane GardnerLearn more at:
WWW.FORESTPRIMEVAL.ORG

story:
Walking For Water

Water is life.  Plain and simple.  You cannot possibly have one without the other, and right now, we don’t have enough to go around.  We are at a nexus.  We are a time of our lives where, if we care about the future, we need to make some changes…some damn serious changes.  If we don’t, you see, we will grow thirstier and thirstier…just as the mountains themselves, until we are stripped of any and all means of life. 

That is more or less the blurb I am going to shape this campaign on.  Water is life…and we need to protect it as such.  We need to have some conversations on our future…mainly, where the hell is our water…where the hell is our life…going to come from? 

No longer is it sustainable to imagine Los Angeles County can continue to rape the watersheds of the Eastern Sierra for another 101 years.  No longer can we stand idly by as we watch cities and counties grow and grow, while watching our water stores, our natural water stores, diminish with each and every passing year.  And no longer can we stand idly by as we watch legislatures create ‘long term solutions’ that will flood parts of the Sierra that will never be seen again.  We need change and we need it now! 

The Great Western Loop

First and foremost, my goal (besides not-dying), is to create an awareness of the water crisis.  I figure that such a lofty goal, in a world filled with soundbites and attention spans of 140 characters, will require drastic measures just to gain a platform.  So, I am going big...I am hiking the Great Western Loop.  

First hiked in 2006 by Andrew Skurka, the nearly 7,000 mile hike is a behemoth of unrivaled proportions.  The trek itself combines portions of 5 major trails to form the loop.  The trails that make-up the Great Western Loop are: the Pacific Crest Trail, the Pacific Northwest Trail, the Continental Divide Trail, New Mexico's Grand Enchantment Trail, and the Arizona Trail.  

Second, I want to give back to the trails.  Think about it...you just can't get into these areas, into the wild landscapes of this great nation, without our network of trails.  You see, I want to help the trails...but I know that I don't know how to build a trail, or maintain a trail, or anything of the like.  Because of that, it only makes sense to help give back to them.  

After all, they are the ones that have pick-and-shovel ready projects, but funding is always a consideration in what work gets done when.  Add to that the fact that each of us that have ever spent any time in the back-country know the value of a well-maintained trail, this provides a great chance to give-back to the 5 long-trails listed above.

The Water Crisis

Sit beneath the trees, they will impart unto you their wisdom.  Walk amongst the granite, hear it cry out with thirst.

On one of my fall trips in the Sierra this year I came away with that line.  If you have spent any time in the mountains over the past several years, I have a feeling that you will know how right that statement feels, and moreover, how it holds true.

It is no secret that we are in the midst of an incredibly elongated drought in the west, but people tend to forget...the mountains need water too.  With an increase in overall temperatures and years of below-normal snow-pack, the mountains are thirsty.

It speaks to our overall disconnect with the land...we have forgotten where our water really comes from.  I have news for you, it doesn't come from the damned tap.  Water, the very essence of life, is quite literally born in the mountains.  Until we recognize this, until we see the water crisis for what it truly is, until we start turning on the taps and nothing comes out, well, we are pretty much screwed.  

Think about it, while more and more water can always be 'tapped' and taken away from the mountains, it can hardly be replaced by anything but the forces of nature. Given the recent history, and the years of drought, it's time to start hedging our bet...  If our mountains are to stand up to the test of time, the test of our time that is, well, it's time we stand up for them.  

My Background

Roughly 4 years ago, I walked into the Superstition mountains on my very first backpacking trip.  It sucked...I was way out of my league.  Hell, I even had to carry my 6-month old puppy a solid 2 miles, if not more, just to get out of the mountains. On that same trip, I walked out of the mountains a changed man. The seeds of wanderlust were planted...I was in love.  

It would be almost another full year before setting out into the wild again, but when I did...I found that the pull and overall allure of the outdoors were no longer the same. The affinities I had with the mountains had grown...much more than I could have imagined.

I made the decision that I was going to arrange my life around backpacking on the weekends.  In the early days, this meant undergoing such extreme measures as running a clothesline inside my apartment just so I could spend the electricity savings on gear, or food, or gas just to get to a trip.  I was hooked...like the truest addict that ever was.  I was addicted to the mountains.

Since then, I have walked, traversed, slid-down, and/or otherwise experienced many more mountain ranges throughout the west.  As I experienced and witnessed more, my wanderlust only grew.  I had to see more. I had to experience more.  To do this, I even created my own backpacking group on meetup.com (see http://meetup.com/Arizona-Epic-Adventures-Backpacking/) right about a year and half ago.  In the past 52 weeks alone, I have racked up more than 1,000 miles...and more than 700 miles the year before that.  

It is those very experiences that have since shaped me and my mission.


The Money

I would love to be able to start out on this journey on my own terms, with my own means.  Unfortunately, that just isn’t possible.  Back in early October I lost my job in corporate America.  I had contracted pneumonia during an almost 50 mile loop in the Sierra near Mt. Whitney.  Unluckily for me, I did not have the sick-time and I was subsequently canned. 

Although it hasn’t been exactly easy, I know I am on the right path.  I can only describe it as a feeling of being called on to hike, a feeling of being chosen, rightly or not, to give voice to the mountains. Help me raise my voice!

Where the Money Goes – The Trails

                         

Giving back from the get-go…  A secondary, but no-less important aspect of my campaign, is doing whatever I can to support those who already make things happen...giving back to those who already promote or otherwise work to engage people.

To support the organizations that do the work that literally supports my boots on the ground by creating, developing, and maintaining the trails I will travel, 50%  will be donated directly to the trail organizations.  For each dollar raised by the campaign,

  • $0.10 will be donated to the Pacific Crest Trail Association
  • $0.10 will be donated to the Arizona Trail Association
  • $0.10 will be donated to the Pacific Northwest Trail Association
  • $0.10 will be donated to the Grand Enchantment Trail
  • $0.10 will be donated to the Continental Divide Trail Coalition

Only $0.50 of every dollar will actually go to the "me" component of this Walking for Water epic itself.  It means that if we hit our goal of $30,000, I will have the $15,000 needed to complete the journey...the remaining $15,000 goes directly to the beneficiaries outlined above.  *As a side-note, the trails are already all in the loop and have granted me use of the applicable logos to use in this campaign.


Where the Money Goes - Gear

With a touch under 7,000 miles to trek, gear and food will be my main expenses. While I am more-or-less geared up to my friggin' ears, on a trip like this I am going to absolutely consume gear.  Think of the Great Western Loop as the greatest endurance-testing stage that has ever been set.  That said, if there are any gear companies that would like to participate, and if you think your gear is up to such rigors (or at least better than the other guys), well, let's do it!  ***Hint-hint Asolo, Big Agnes, Black Diamond, Osprey, etc...  Given the fact that I have most of my initial gear, I am going to allow for $2,000 for replacing gear as I go.

Where the Money Goes - Food

Food by far will be my absolute largest expenditure...  I am going to need to consume roughly 5,000 - 5,500 calories per day...every day...and that's in non-freezing, 'good' weather.  For times that I encounter snow, I'm going to need to bump up my caloric intake up to 7,000 calories per day.  So if I err on the side of caution and anticipate 1/3 of my time will be in cold, snowy conditions (God I hope not), then I have 104 days of 7,000 calories and 208 days of 5,000 calories (going on the low-end on this assumption), add some math to the 728,000 'cold-day calories' and 1,020,000 calories for 'normal-day calories', and there you have it...just under 1.75 million calories...or right under $8,000 in food expenses alone.

Where the Money Goes – Technology

Throughout the journey, I will be maintaining a daily blog...  While there will undoubtedly be periods of 4, 5, or even 7 days with no reception to sync the posts, entries will be completed daily, even if only extremely brief...without fail. 

In addition to the blog, I'm going to try and have a real-time tracker setup...  This way you can meet me out on the trail, hopefully with some ice-cold beer!  ***Hint-hint to the two breweries I am seeking sponsorship from - Sierra Nevada and the Arizona Wilderness Brewing Co. After all, it just isn't possible to have great beer without great water, it's only a natural fit!

Besides the blog I will be maintaining, I will be taking photographs...good ones, and for that I need a good camera.  After a visit to Tempe Camera a few weeks back, it looks like the FujiFilm X-T1 is going to be the camera of choice.  The camera and two lenses is going to cost $2200 (think that should include tax!)...  This camera is pretty damned important to this trip, as I will be documenting this trip as thoroughly and comprehensively as possible.  Plus, it's going to allow me to sell prints as perks!

Where the Money Goes – Other

After the above expense allocations have been made, the remaining portions will go to overall trip execution…meaning everything from gas money for hitches into towns, shipping & logistical expenses, cell-phone service (to allow the blog syncing when in areas of reception), dog care expenses, etc.


Risks, Challenges, Contingencies, & Bonus Goals...

The challenge for us, well, the biggest challenge, is getting people to see how important the land actually is and creating the "GAS" factor.  If we fail to create the GAS factor then this is all for naught.  And no the GAS factor is not some fancy-dancy new metric designed to analyze fracking efficiency, no it is something much simpler...it is the Give-A-Shit factor.  

Bottom line...if people don't or won't care (read: if people don't Give-A-Shit) about the mountains and the waters that flow through them, then we're all screwed.  That is why our biggest challenge is getting people to give a shit.

As far as contingencies go, I don't have anything else...  I'm 34 years old, I'm unemployed, I have no savings, and once I begin this journey, I will have nowhere to come back to, yet...I believe in this.  I am literally giving myself to this cause...there is no plan B.    

That said, if you guys can help me give people GAS, and we reach our goals, well, I will take care of the rest.  You see, this is going to work...I just know it is.  If we do not reach the full fundraising goal, I will go through a taking-stock phase and see what, if anything can be done to proceed.  The split between the monies the trails receive and monies to finance the trip applies in this case as well. 

Ok, ok...there is always a plan B.  If we don't reach our goal, but still have a successful fundraiser,  we will push forward...just scaled back.  Chances are we will be able to do at least one of the trails.  Bottom line, even if we can't fund the full Great Western Loop, if we are to get our message out, if we are to help advocate for the mountains, we need to start somewhere.

........

If we surpass all fundraising goals, the trail-organization and trip expenditures will stay the same...yet there will be a bonus.  You see, there is a chance for real, lasting, significant change here.  So what's the bonus?!?  Well, any trip monies raised in excess of the needed $15,000 will go towards our incorporation.  That's right, the birth of The Wanderlust Objective non-profit.  Because this component is dependent on surpassing our funding goals, I'm not going to divulge too much information on it...yet.  

What I can say is that the organization I want to create will  give voice to the mountains, it will advocate for them on their behalf, it will foster a sense of re-connection and re-engagement with the land, and (with work) will be almost entirely self-supporting.  Now...who wouldn't want to be a part of that?  


Trip Completion Timeline 

While I am well, well into the mapping phase of my trip, I still have a lot of work to do.  That said, I do have a rough time-frame of how long this trip will take.  Allowing myself an overall, average pace of 22 miles per day, I am expecting to complete the Great Western Loop in 312 days.  Yes, that's right...right around 10.5 months on the trail.  For comparison's sake, Andrew Skurka's pace often exceeded 32 miles a day. If it can be done at a blazing pace in under 7 months, in can certainly be done in a longer time-frame, albeit with potential weather/seasonality issues.



Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the Word

We need to make this big…that’s the only way we can really make this work.  With the hyper-connected world that we live in, this is something that truly everyone can do.  Tell your friends…tell your momma…tell your friend’s brother’s sister’s cousin... 

Indiegogo has some great sharing tools…anything you can do to help get the word out on this campaign will be greatly appreciated.  Remember, I can’t do this without you.  Help me start the conversations we need to have to ensure our mountains maintain the water they need.  We can do this.

Sponsorships

I have reached out to a couple of companies regarding sponsorship potentiality, again, I need all the help that I can get.  If you represent a company that would like to work with me in Walking for Water, then please, by all means do.  I am accepting sponsorships of both cash (which will adhere to the same 50/50 split as all monies) and/or gear…and/or both. Feel free to reach out to me through the campaign. 



In Closing

While our goals may indeed be lofty, our objective is wanderlust.  With your help, we can stand up for the mountains, together, by creating, spreading, and promoting awareness of the critical water issues that we are facing...the unseen water issues that take place far from the cities and municipalities that consume it.  

If we can save the mountains and their watersheds, from our own destructive habits, we can change the world.  We owe it to ourselves…but even more-so, we owe it to the mountains.

I'm just a guy...I got some ideas...and with your help, I believe we can change the world.

slid-down, and/or otherwise experienced many more mountain ranges throughout
the west.  As I experienced and witnessed
more, my wanderlust only grew.  I had to see more. I had to experience
more.  To do this, I even created my own backpacking group on meetup.com
(see http://meetup.com/Arizona-Epic-Adventures-Backpacking/)
right about a year and half ago.  In the
past 52 weeks alone, I have racked up more than 1,000 miles...and more than 700
miles the year before that.  
It is those very experiences that have since shaped me and my mission.


The Money 
I would love to be able to start out
on this journey on my own terms, with my own means.  Unfortunately, that just isn’t possible.  Back in early October I lost my job in
corporate America.  I had contracted
pneumonia during an almost 50 mile loop in the Sierra near Mt. Whitney.  Unluckily for me, I did not have the
sick-time and I was subsequently canned. 

Although it hasn’t been exactly
easy, I know I am on the right path.  I
can only describe it as a feeling of being called on to hike, a feeling of
being chosen, rightly or not, to give voice to the mountains. Help me raise my
voice!
Where the Money Goes –
The Trails
                         
Giving back from the get-go…  A secondary, but no-less important aspect of
my campaign, is doing whatever I can to support those who already make things
happen...giving back to those who already promote or otherwise work to engage
people. 
To support the organizations that do
the work that literally supports my boots on the ground by creating,
developing, and maintaining the trails I will travel, 50%  will be donated directly to the trail organizations. 
For each dollar raised by the campaign, 

$0.10 will be donated to the Pacific Crest Trail
     Association
$0.10 will be donated to the Arizona Trail Association
$0.10 will be donated to the Pacific Northwest Trail
     Association
$0.10 will be donated to the Grand Enchantment Trail
$0.10 will be donated to the Continental Divide Trail
     Coalition

Only $0.50 of every dollar will
actually go to the "me" component of this Walking for Water epic
itself.  It means that if we hit our goal of $30,000, I will have the
$15,000 needed to complete the journey...the remaining $15,000 goes
directly to the beneficiaries outlined above.  *As a side-note, the trails
are already all in the loop and have granted me use of the applicable logos to
use in this campaign.

Where the Money Goes - Gear
With a touch under 7,000 miles to
trek, gear and food will be my main expenses. While I am more-or-less geared up
to my friggin' ears, on a trip like this I am going to absolutely consume gear.
 Think of the Great Western Loop as the greatest endurance-testing stage
that has ever been set.  That said, if there are any gear companies that
would like to participate, and if you think your gear is up to such rigors (or
at least better than the other guys), well, let's do it!  ***Hint-hint
Asolo, Big Agnes, Black Diamond, Osprey, etc...  Given the fact that I
have most of my initial gear, I am going to allow for $2,000 for replacing gear
as I go.

Where the Money Goes - Food
Food by far will be my absolute
largest expenditure...  I am going to need to consume roughly 5,000 -
5,500 calories per day...every day...and that's in non-freezing, 'good'
weather.  For times that I encounter snow, I'm going to need to bump up my
caloric intake up to 7,000 calories per day.  So if I err on the side of
caution and anticipate 1/3 of my time will be in cold, snowy conditions (God I
hope not), then I have 104 days of 7,000 calories and 208 days of 5,000
calories (going on the low-end on this assumption), add some math to the
728,000 'cold-day calories' and 1,020,000 calories for 'normal-day calories',
and there you have it...just under 1.75 million calories...or right under $8,000
in food expenses alone. 
Where the Money Goes – Technology
Throughout the journey, I will be
maintaining a daily blog...  While there will undoubtedly be periods of 4,
5, or even 7 days with no reception to sync the posts, entries will be
completed daily, even if only extremely brief...without fail. 
In addition to the blog, I'm going
to try and have a real-time tracker setup...  This way you can meet me out
on the trail, hopefully with some ice-cold beer!  ***Hint-hint to the two
breweries I am seeking sponsorship from - Sierra Nevada and the Arizona
Wilderness Brewing Co. After all, it just isn't possible to have great beer
without great water, it's only a natural fit!
Besides the blog I will be
maintaining, I will be taking photographs...good ones, and for that I need a good
camera.  After a visit to Tempe Camera a few weeks back, it looks like the
FujiFilm X-T1 is going to be the camera of choice.  The camera and two
lenses is going to cost $2200 (think that should include tax!)...  This
camera is pretty damned important to this trip, as I will be documenting this
trip as thoroughly and comprehensively as possible.  Plus, it's going to
allow me to sell prints as perks!
Where the Money Goes – Other
After the above expense allocations
have been made, the remaining portions will go to overall trip execution…meaning
everything from gas money for hitches into towns, shipping & logistical
expenses, cell-phone service (to allow the blog syncing when in areas of
reception), dog care expenses, etc. 



Risks, Challenges, Contingencies, & Bonus Goals...
The challenge
for us, well, the biggest challenge, is getting people to see how important the
land actually is and creating the "GAS" factor.  If we fail to
create the GAS factor then this is all for naught.  And no the GAS factor
is not some fancy-dancy new metric designed to analyze fracking efficiency, no
it is something much simpler...it is the Give-A-Shit factor.  
Bottom
line...if people don't or won't care (read: if people don't Give-A-Shit) about
the mountains and the waters that flow through them, then we're all screwed.
 That is why our biggest challenge is getting people to give a shit.
As far as
contingencies go, I don't have anything else...  I'm 34 years old, I'm
unemployed, I have no savings, and once I begin this journey, I will have
nowhere to come back to, yet...I believe in this.  I am literally giving
myself to this cause...there is no plan B.    
That said, if
you guys can help me give people GAS, and we reach our goals, well, I will take
care of the rest.  You see, this is going to work...I just know it is.
 If we do not reach the full fundraising goal, I will go through a
taking-stock phase and see what, if anything can be done to proceed.  The
split between the monies the trails receive and monies to finance the trip
applies in this case as well. 
Ok, ok...there is always a plan B.  If we don't reach our goal, but still have a successful fundraiser,  we will push forward...just scaled back.  Chances are we will be able to do at least one of the trails.  Bottom line, even if we can't fund the full Great Western Loop, if we are to get our message out, if we are to help advocate for the mountains, we need to start somewhere.
........
If we surpass
all fundraising goals, the trail-organization and trip expenditures will stay
the same...yet there will be a bonus.  You see, there is a chance for
real, lasting, significant change here.  So what's the bonus?!?
 Well, any trip monies raised in excess of the needed $15,000 will go
towards our incorporation.  That's right, the birth of The Wanderlust
Objective non-profit.  Because this component is dependent on surpassing
our funding goals, I'm not going to divulge too much information on it...yet.
 
What I can say
is that the organization I want to create will  give voice to the
mountains, it will advocate for them on their behalf, it will foster a sense of
re-connection and re-engagement with the land, and (with work) will be almost
entirely self-supporting.  Now...who wouldn't want to be a part of that?
 

Trip
Completion Timeline 
While I am well, well into the
mapping phase of my trip, I still have a lot of work to do.  That said, I
do have a rough time-frame of how long this trip will take.  Allowing
myself an overall, average pace of 22 miles per day, I am expecting to complete
the Great Western Loop in 312 days.  Yes, that's right...right around 10.5
months on the trail.  For comparison's sake, Andrew Skurka's pace often
exceeded 32 miles a day. If it can be done at a blazing pace in under 7 months,
in can certainly be done in a longer time-frame, albeit with potential
weather/seasonality issues.




Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the Word
We need to make this big…that’s
the only way we can really make this work. 
With the hyper-connected world that we live in, this is something that
truly everyone can do.  Tell your friends…tell
your momma…tell your friend’s brother’s sister’s cousin...  
Indiegogo has some great sharing
tools…anything you can do to help get the word out on this campaign will be
greatly appreciated.  Remember, I can’t
do this without you.  Help me start the
conversations we need to have to ensure our mountains maintain the water they
need.  We can do this.
Sponsorships
I have reached out to a couple of
companies regarding sponsorship potentiality, again, I need all the help that I
can get.  If you represent a company that
would like to work with me in Walking for Water, then please, by all means
do.  I am accepting sponsorships of both
cash (which will adhere to the same 50/50 split as all monies) and/or gear…and/or
both. Feel free to reach out to me through the campaign.  




In Closing
While our goals may indeed be lofty,
our objective is wanderlust.  With your
help, we can stand up for the mountains, together, by creating, spreading, and
promoting awareness of the critical water issues that we are facing...the
unseen water issues that take place far from the cities and municipalities that
consume it.  
If we can save the mountains and their watersheds, from our
own destructive habits, we can change the world.  We owe it to ourselves…but even
more-so, we owe it to the mountains.
I'm just a guy...I got some ideas...and with your help, I believe we can change the world.

story:
MICROPLASTICS, A SILENT CANCER SPREADING RAPIDLY IN OUR OCEANS

ARCHIPELAGOS INSTITUTE OF MARINE CONSERVATION WAS THE FIRST ORGANISATION IN GREECE TO RESEARCH THE SPREAD OF MICROPLASTICS IN OUR SEAS

In today’s world plastics are everywhere. The global production of plastics has skyrocketed in recent decades, and so have the piles of plastic waste throughout the world. 

Many animals, including birds, mammals (terrestrial and marine) and reptiles, confuse plastic litter for food. As microplastics accumulate in our food chain, we are also affected by them, a product of our own doing.

Since 1998, Archipelagos Institute of Marine Conservation has been contributing towards the protection of the unique Mediterranean ecosystem. Since 2010 Archipelagos' research has shown that high levels of microplastics are found in fish and other wildlife of the Aegean Sea. Through bioaccumulation and feeding, dangerous microplastics find their way into fish, dolphins, whales, sea turtles and seals, some of whom are threatened species. Microplastics have even been found in plankton.

WE AIM TO


UNDERSTAND the spread of microplastics in our seas

PUBLISH scientific papers

Initiate a media CAMPAIGN

URGE the Greek & the EU authorities to take measures limiting plastic contamination


> OUR PURPOSE

In order to address the problem of microplastics spreading across our seas, our action plan mainly focuses on the monitoring of microplastics in the Aegean Sea and other parts of the North-East Mediterranean. This will allow us to create public engagement and political pressure concerning its impacts.

We wish to:

  • Carry out scientific research and monitor the quantity of microplastics
  • Initiate and/or improve the co-operation with other countries
  • Lobby on national and EU scales that will allow the European actions to evolve
  • Organize public awareness, education and information to improve public knowledge


> WHO WE ARE?

Archipelagos is an environmental, non-profit organization, committed to protecting the marine and island biodiversity of the North-East Mediterranean. Our main actions are:

  • Contributing to scientific work on biodiversity conservation
  • Working in close collaboration with local fishermen
  • Reporting actions to national and EU authorities
  • Developing realistic and sustainable management measures

Come back regularly and check out our updates for news, pictures and publications from the Archipelagos Institute of Marine Conservation!

> WHAT DO WE NEED ?

1. Details of the main equipment 

- FTIR Microscope Imager

Currently, the microplastics in our samples can only be identified by sight. And although strict guidelines are being followed, it is possible that only 70% of these fragments would be confirmed as plastic through FTIR Spectroscopy. FTIR spectroscopy stands for Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy, and it is able to determine the chemical composition of plastic fragments very confidently. With this information, not only will we be able to accurately investigate the abundance of microplastics in the Aegean Sea, but also we will be able to ascertain the original source of the plastic. This will provide strong evidence to help convince the Greek government to exert pressure on the industries responsible for the influx of plastic into our sea.

- High Speed Centrifuge

A centrifuge is a piece of equipment that aids the mixing of solutions. The use of a centrifuge within the method, will significantly speed up the process of separating the sample from the plastic. We would therefore be able to analyse a much greater number of samples resulting in a much more accurate conclusion.

- Stereomicroscope

Sometimes referred to as a dissecting microscope. This will aid the sampling process by providing visual aid and will be used in our on-going research.

- Lyophilizer

This machine will enable us to freeze dry our samples. Freeze drying will preserve the perishable sample material for much longer, making it more manageable and accessible to sample over long periods of time.

- Continuous Plankton Recorder

A continuous plankton recorder would be extremely valuable to our research. We would be able to take samples over long periods of time and monitor the occurrence of microplastics consistently and indefinitely. We will be able to determine any significant increase in plastic over time, and also any patterns or changes in distribution.


2. Other requirements

In addition to the equipment mentioned above, we also require laboratory consumables (such as sample containers, glassware etc.) and fuel for sampling surveys.


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! 

Let us work hand in hand for PLASTIC FREE SEAS

story:
This is a continuation of our original campaign, which may be found at www.indiegogo.com/lakotalanguage.

In that campaign, we were able to raise $13,300...falling short of the total we had hoped to raise, but giving us a good start nevertheless.

We are planning to open the daycare at the end of October. The funds we raised through Indiegogo and elsewhere (about $17,500 total) are a tremendous boost, but ONLY ENOUGH TO LAST US ABOUT SIX MONTHS. In order to keep our doors open, and make our venture sustainable in the long run, we will need much more.

A big thank you in advance to everyone who supports us through contributions, or by helping us spread the word! Also a reminder that due to a fiscal sponsorship by a local non-profit, all contributions are tax-deductible.

Finally, If you have any questions, our website gives much more in-depth information on our program, in both the short- and long-term. Go to www.lakotalearners.com.

We are so excited to be opening our doors to children, and keeping the beautiful Lakota language alive!

story:
At San Rafael High School is the Green Team, a club of students that are dedicated to making the world a better place environmentally that have devoted themselves to this whole project that is independent from any administration or faculty help. My name specifically is Sam Curtis and I am a senior at San Rafael, majoring in Environmental Science next year with hopes that i can continue my love for nature and the environment on a grander scale once I graduate. Alongside me is Linot Vierke, another senior from San Rafael, who is going to study Mechanical Engineering next year. You could say that together we make a pretty decent duo, with him on the engineering side and me on the policy and environmental side. I can find the ideas, and he can carry them out. 

Over the past years, we've had quite a few projects that we carried out. We got recycling cans all over our school, created educational videos to show the kids within our school how to be mindful towards the environment, did an energy audit of our schools electricity, a solar audit in hopes of getting solar panels, and compost bins that are used to decompose our lunch foods! But, we have a new goal that we are reaching for in our final months at San Rafael High School.

Our goal from this fund is to replace all of the wasteful paper towel dispensers in our school with energy efficient and zero waste hand dryers, the Dyson Airblade dBs. Our school spends a surmountable amount of money on these paper towels every year, more than $400 a month, and most of them are simply crumbled up into balls, thrown in toilets, stuck to the walls, or torn up in the trash can. With the Dyson, we could stop the waste that we are producing while putting in a cost effective replacement. The cost of each hand dryer would be met with just 12 months in a bathroom that has two hand dryers while they use minimal electricity and produce zero carbon emissions. 

Linot and I barraged the district enough that they let us have a meeting with them to discuss our plans, see if they were viable, and maybe even for support and funds to help us carry it out. We created a presentation, came to the meeting, and got the district office on our side. But, were not there yet. The district doesn't have enough money to install all of the electrical in the bathrooms and to buy enough Airblades to fill the bathrooms all at one instant. So, we agreed on some terms to fulfill this goal of ours. The District will pay half of our costs for the project if we can come up with the money to pay the other half. That's where you come in to support us. If we can raise this money we can stop all of the waste that comes out of our bathrooms and while it doesn't make our school go completely eco-friendly, it can definitely get the balls rolling to make our school a more sustainable and conscientious campus. We can save our school from vandalism in the bathrooms, give the environment a helping hand by producing less CO2 emissions from the production of paper, clean our school with less waste being produced, and finally save our school almost $4000 a year that they spend on paper towels in the bathrooms. 

In the US we produce more than 70 million tons of paper and cut down 4 billion trees just for the production of paper worldwide each year, and you help us do what we can to stop it. If other school and businesses can see that our plan is cost-effective and beneficial to both the environment and their business, maybe we, as a community, can put a damper in the amount of harm we do to the environment around us and slow the amount of pollution that comes from paper production.

We may just be two high schoolers leading a group of kids, but that doesn't mean we can't do what ever is in our power to give back to the world that we live on. We have the school at our shoulder and the district and community at our back, now all we need is everyone out there, you, to give us a helping hand. So, give us a push forwards by donating to our cause and tell your friends that we have a goal to make our community and the people within it a greener, more eco-friendly place to live in.

So, give us a push forwards by donating to our cause and tell your friends that we have a goal to make our community and the people within it a greener, more eco-friendly place to live in.

story:
Short Summary

One’s typical image of Hawaii would probably consist of beautiful beaches, golf courses and hotel resorts. However, a hidden gem of native forests that evolved over millions of years in isolation rests just beyond our sights. Kokee, Kauai, is one of those great treasures that still flourishes on the island of Kauai; the forest is home to hundreds of native plant species, 90% of which are endemic and grow nowhere else on the planet, including over 140 rare and endangered plants. This degree of endemism is higher than anywhere else in the world.  

The Kokee forests nurture plants that are precious to Hawaiian culture. While being famous for being a biodiversity hotspot of global significance, Kokee also provides a wide range of ecosystem services, plays a role in the preservation of Hawaiian tradition and culture, and gives a unique platform for education and recreation.

Today, this dynamic diversity in Hawaiian ecosystems is increasingly threatened by invasive non-native weeds that have been rapidly displacing native vegetation.  Hawaii has become known as the "endangered species capital of the world" and the "extinction capital of the world" because of the many plants, and particularly beautiful birds, that have become extinct. Invasive weed control has been identified as a high priority by the US Fish & Wildlife Service in their recovery plans for nearly all the endangered species on Kauai.  Unless there is a strategic and sustained effort to control these weeds, the core native forests will be irreversible converted to non-native vegetation.

The survival of Kokee's native forests relies on passionate volunteers who tread lightly across the steep canyon range and fragile native forest to weed out invasives and plant native species.

The Kokee Resource Conservation Program engages and educates volunteers through hands-on work in one of the world's most endangered and biodiverse hot-spots. We propagate land stewardship and create helpful access to Kauai's mountain forests for locals and visitors.

Each donated dollar and volunteer hour is an investment in Kauai’s rich, rare, endangered native paradise.

$700 preserves one acre on average, and we average 600 acres annually. Costs include volunteers, interns, staff, facilities, and field equipment. Help preserve an acre this year!

$4500 supports one full-time on-site volunteer equivalent (2080 hours per year). We benefit from 8500 total volunteer hours annually.  Four 10-hour days of guided conservation work in the far reaches of the rain forest includes a 7-day stay in our historic state park-owned facility. Help sustain our volunteers this year!

$17,000 supports our intern program annually. To date, over a dozen of our interns now work for conservation agencies around the state. Help grow a  conservationist this year!

$20,000 covers our annual helicopter rental expense. We target remote locations to increase efficacy such as the line where the most pristine forest meets the invaded forest. We know why birds and butterflies don't wear hiking boots. Help push back time and keep Kauai Jurassic-like!

As environmental funding shrinks, so grows the non-native invasion on Kauai's terrain.  These forests stay healthy from volunteer energy. We know many more people care about preserving biodiversity than are able to make it to this special part of the world, to strap on boots and machetes, to nurture native species, to wade through thickets and walk through clouds. We hope this campaign creates opportunities for many more nature lovers to directly impact preservation work with donations that enable old and young from near and far to leave a good footprint here and going forward.
 

Volunteers, staff and funding are only part of the story. The natural world is the true treasure and Kauai is a jewel. You can also contribute by keeping your eyes open and keeping your hands dirty wherever you are. And please share our campaign with others in your social media circle and in your backyard. The Indiegogo share tools make it easy.
story_txt:
Short Summary
One’s typical image of Hawaii would probably consist of beautiful beaches, golf courses and hotel resorts. However, a hidden gem of native forests that evolved over millions of years in isolation rests just beyond our sights. Kokee, Kauai, is one of those great treasures that still flourishes on the island of Kauai; the forest is home to hundreds of native plant species, 90% of which are endemic and grow nowhere else on the planet, including over 140 rare and endangered plants. This degree of endemism is higher than anywhere else in the world.  
The Kokee forests nurture plants that are precious to Hawaiian culture. While being famous for being a biodiversity hotspot of global significance, Kokee also provides a wide range of ecosystem services, plays a role in the preservation of Hawaiian tradition and culture, and gives a unique platform for education and recreation.
Today, this dynamic diversity in Hawaiian ecosystems is increasingly threatened by invasive non-native weeds that have been rapidly displacing native vegetation.  Hawaii has become known as the "endangered species capital of the world" and the "extinction capital of the world" because of the many plants, and particularly beautiful birds, that have become extinct. Invasive weed control has been identified as a high priority by the US Fish & Wildlife Service in their recovery plans for nearly all the endangered species on Kauai.  Unless there is a strategic and sustained effort to control these weeds, the core native forests will be irreversible converted to non-native vegetation.
The survival of Kokee's native forests relies on passionate volunteers who tread lightly across the steep canyon range and fragile native forest to weed out invasives and plant native species.
The Kokee Resource Conservation Program engages and educates volunteers through hands-on work in one of the world's most endangered and biodiverse hot-spots. We propagate land stewardship and create helpful access to Kauai's mountain forests for locals and visitors.
Each donated dollar and volunteer hour is an investment in Kauai’s rich, rare, endangered native paradise.

$700 preserves one acre on average, and we average 600 acres annually. Costs include volunteers, interns, staff, facilities, and field equipment. Help preserve an acre this year!
$4500 supports one full-time on-site volunteer equivalent (2080 hours per year). We benefit from 8500 total volunteer hours annually.  Four 10-hour days of guided conservation work in the far reaches of the rain forest includes a 7-day stay in our historic state park-owned facility. Help sustain our volunteers this year!
$17,000 supports our intern program annually. To date, over a dozen of our interns now work for conservation agencies around the state. Help grow a  conservationist this year!
$20,000 covers our annual helicopter rental expense. We target remote locations to increase efficacy such as the line where the most pristine forest meets the invaded forest. We know why birds and butterflies don't wear hiking boots. Help push back time and keep Kauai Jurassic-like!
As environmental funding shrinks, so grows the non-native invasion on Kauai's terrain.  These forests stay healthy from volunteer energy. We know many more people care about preserving biodiversity than are able to make it to this special part of the world, to strap on boots and machetes, to nurture native species, to wade through thickets and walk through clouds. We hope this campaign creates opportunities for many more nature lovers to directly impact preservation work with donations that enable old and young from near and far to leave a good footprint here and going forward. Volunteers, staff and funding are only part of the story. The natural world is the true treasure and Kauai is a jewel. You can also contribute by keeping your eyes open and keeping your hands dirty wherever you are. And please share our campaign with others in your social media circle and in your backyard. The Indiegogo share tools make it easy.

story:
The Blue Economy of Plastic Fuel.

Hello,

My name is José Luis Gutiérrez-García, I have a Master Certificate in Corporate and Environmental Sustainability and in 2011, I held the Chair of the Sustainability Committee at a remote gold mining operation in the Arctic.

Upcycling is the practice of taking waste and transforming it into something of similar or greater use and value. In other words, upcycling uses waste materials to provide us with valuable products.

The Upcycle the Gyres Society works to upcycle the floating plastic waste from the ocean currents into diesel, gasoline, kerosene and/or light crude oil.

In order to accomplish this, the Society will facilitate the design, construction, operation, management, and maintenance of the first ever: self-sufficient, Deep Sea Mining, Eco-floating production, storage, and offloading (DSM-FPSO) research facility.

This DSMFPSO will provide year round research facilities to marine institutes, foundations and coalitions in order to implement breakthrough solutions for Ocean restoration and Marine Plastic Mining in the next three years.

Marine Plastic Mining is the process of recovering plastic wealth from deposits on the surface and on the seabed, and upcycling it into fuel at sea.

The money fueling the cleanup and upcycling operations will come from investors who are attracted to the idea of making a return on their investment while helping to keep the oceans clean and healthy.

To that end, I am starting the environmental not-for profit Upcycle the Gyres Society (UGS) based in Vancouver, Canada.

Your financial investment will help the UGS achieve its immediate goals:

  • Fund the Society’s registration expenses and campaign fees
  • Create and launch the UGS website

Advance the efforts of establishing an accurate baseline on plastic pollution density, and remove the pollution from the marine ecosystem

  • Seed funding to cover the board of Directors expenses to conduct the Society’s work
    • The Board of Directors of the UGS does not receive monetary compensation for being directors; however, the board is entitled to reimbursements for expenses incurred to do their job

Seeking

$22,000.00 will provide the UGS with exposure. Get us on the radar.

We will use your investment to attend specific events where this idea-solution can be pitched to socially responsible investors, industry, and politicians.

The funds will also be used to participate in an expedition(s) with research institutes to understand how to better design, construct, operate, manage and maintain the first eco-floating, self-sufficient, production, storage, and offloading (FPSO) research-upcycling facility. 

The vision is to have a revenue neutral and self-funding FPSO eco-resort.

By deriving an income from travelers focused on sustainable living, the environment, social justice, personal development, and health, this Floating Eco Research Upcycling Resort will support researchers in numerous ways, while  the eco tourists would contribute funding, spread the word, and learn new skills.

By connecting research data and information to solutions providers faster; industry will be able to implement breakthrough solutions for Marine Plastic Mining and Ocean plastic pollution restoration that will get the oceans cleaner and healthier sooner.

The eco-research-upcycling resort is upscalable. As the technology and collection methodology improves, and the operation and amounts of recoverable plastic grow, the eco-FPSO-resort will be able to sell the upcycled plastic as fuel to fund its operations and expansion to other areas that need clean up.


Immediate Goals

  • Secure funding to register the Society in Vancouver, Canada
  • Secure funding to create and launch The Upcycle the Gyres website
  • Secure funding to attend conferences to find investors and partners


What You Get

Your investment on the Upcycle the Gyres Society will provide you with:

A cleaner marine environment: non-polluted beaches,healthy seafood and all that that entails


The Importance of your Investment

Today, marine research expeditions take a long time to complete. First they must physically reach the oceanic plastic convergence zone. They are limited to the time they can spend at sea collecting data and samples. Then they spend time getting back to land to continue their work figuring out how to best rehabilitate the marine eco-system.

The technology to convert plastic to fuel is available and already in use in Japan, and it is starting to catch on in the U.S.

The technology to manage the collection, processing, storage and offloading of plastic fuel already exists in the form of offshore oil and gas rigs and marine diamond mining vessels.

Our strategy is to combine, adapt, transfer and customize these solutions to manage the plastc debris in the oceans. and by extension, improve the health of our seafood chain.

The Upcycle the Gyres Society suggests that time matters. The sooner research provides practical solutions, and the sooner individuals, governments, and industry implement these breakthroughs in research and technology, the greater the benefits we all stand to gain.

I am a highly motivated professional. I have a proven record of proposing and implementing measures, programs, and systems solutions that minimize our environmental footprint.

For example, I authored a study-report about transforming gold mine mill waste (tailings) into building materials to help safe water bodies from becoming tailings ponds.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Get involved!!!

This is a brand new organization.  

The Upcycle the Gyres Society is looking for energetic, ‘can do’ individuals to join our board of Directors and create a steering committee. We’d love a multinational team drawn from areas such as marine biology, the sciences, ecology, eco-tourism, hospitality, mining, IT, design, engineering, research and marketing, education, sustainable business development, investing, fundraising, writing, the arts, innovation, and from other fields.

People who will guide the UG Society's actions to achieve its goals effectively and in a timely manner are invited.

The steering committee will meet regularly with the board of Directors in person or virtually through Skype or other long distance conferencing means.

We will partner with organizations encouraging the production and use of ‘cradle to grave’ alternatives to plastics and with organizations working to educate the public across the globe on the damage done by plastics in the oceans.

 

Connect!!

This is an invitation to contact me to find the role you would like to take.

José Luis Gutiérrez-García

604 243 9890

joseluis@upcycle-the-gyres.net

http://www.upcycle-the-gyres.net

http://ca.linkedin.com/in/gutierrezjoseluis

Looking forward to talking with you soon.

 

Pass it forward!!

If you believe this is a bold, innovative, timely, and workable initiative and idea then:

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Like us on Ozoshare and Facebook. Talk about marine plastic mining on  LinkedIn. Follow us on Twitter and post encouragment, constructive criticism, and well wishes on the UGS Indiegogo comments section.

Help in beach cleanups. 

Ask your favourite restaurant, pub and bar to stop using single-use plastic straws and cups.

Stop drinking from plastic water bottles. Use reusable stainless steel or glass ones instead.

Don't litter.

Recylce your plastics.

Support plastic legislation.

Experience one day at a time and keep an eye on the Future.
