story:
Trashion?
In case that's not obvious, that's trash + fashion.  Junk to Funk (J2F) uses Avant-garde Trashion as art for social change to get people to think differently about waste.  It's not about getting people to wear trash, that would be ridiculous don't you think?  We use Trashion as an artistic expression to addresses the serious impacts that our consumer culture has on social and ecological health.

We use our Trashion as the focal point in event entertainment, public installations, youth programs and soon to be launched "flashmob" style guerrilla outreach campaigns.  We think the best way to inspire change is to make it beautiful, to make it cool and and to make it FUN!


So letâ€™s make the trash talk short and sweet.  We are at a pivotal juncture in our development and we think the facts below will give you a pretty good idea of why your support is so crucial to our success; our goals, our projects, our inspiration, where your funds will go and why the issues we are addressing are so important. 


Two Quick Notes! 

* Please help us spread the word through your networks by sharing our campaign through email, facebook and twitter by using the appropriate links above.

* Unlike KickStarter, IndieGoGo allows us to keep any funds we raise!  So even if we don't reach our goal, every little bit helps with projects planned for 2012.


Top 5 things your donation will fund in 2012

  1. We need to raise $1500 to complete our fundraising goals for a public installation in downtown Portland featuring garments created out of the most thrown away single use disposables products in the world; coffee cups, plastic bags and plastic beverage bottles.  These products are typically used for about an hour and then thrown away, pretty wasteful and unnecessary right?  Let's get rid of em!
  2. We need to raise $1000 to complete our fundraising goals to launch our interactive guerilla â€œflashmobâ€ event series that will take place in populated public areas and events throughout the summer.  We'll be using the same single use disposables as mentioned above but this time it will become an interactive memorable experience for those lucky enough to be captured in the participation!
  3. We need more Trashion!  Your funds will help generate the creation of new, mind blowing, gorgeous, outrageous Trashion garments.  The value of one garment alone can be between several hundred to several thousands of dollars; they don't just manifest themselves out of a dumpster you know.
  4. We need up to $7,500 to fund our efforts to expand our activities beyond Portland; weâ€™ll continue to do cool projects in our favorite city but we need to move our sustainability message beyond the choir.
  5. We need up to $7,500 to fund our efforts to expand our volunteer program so that we can establish collaborations that will strengthen our efforts.



Top 5 reasons to give

  1. If you care about people and the planet then why not support one of the most creative groups working to solve this social and environmental issue? 
  2. Junk to Funk is part of what makes Portland unique.  What would Portland be without Junk to Funk?!? 
  3. Support the hard working artists that are creating these amazing Avant-garde Trashion artworks. 
  4. Nearly all of what weâ€™ve accomplished has been done on a grassroots level and through the dedication of rockstar volunteers; we can only be successful when sustainable and we need seed funding to grow.
  5. You can support art, the environment and a social innovation all at the same time with one click of a button! (that button is to your upper left if you are already inspired to contribute)








Top 5 proud moments of 2011

  1. We were recently accepted into PSUâ€™s Impact Entrepreneurâ€™s Social Innovation Incubator program for 2012.
  2. We were just awarded a grant from the Regional Arts and Culture Council that will in large, fund a public installation in downtown Portland (as mentioned above in the top 5 things your donation will fund in 2012...we still need to raise $1500!).
  3. From the generosity of the PDX Storefront program we created two public installations in downtown Portland last year, catching the attention of a few hundred thousand passersby. 
  4. House of Trashion designer Jen LaMastra was commissioned by Vitaminwater to create a garment out of recycled bottles and star in an online web series for a recycling project marketing campaign.
  5. The Oregonian featured Junk to Funk in a 3-page article on the front of the Sunday â€œOâ€ section last spring.

     











Top 5 reasons why our work is so important
  1. According to EPA reports, while our recycling rates have increased so, too, have our landfill disposal rates. This means we are buying and throwing away more stuff than ever, in fact about twice as much as we where 30 years ago. 
  2. If everyone in the world consumed like Americanâ€™s weâ€™d need about four planets to satisfy those needs.  We donâ€™t think thatâ€™s going to happen anytime soon.
  3. For everyone one can of garbage that you throw out on the curb for pick up, 70 cans of waste were created in making of the stuff that you just threw away.  Wonder whoâ€™s paying that bill? 
  4. 99% of our stuff ends up either recycled or in the landfill in just 6 months.  Seriously, thatâ€™s pretty unnecessary donâ€™t you think?
  5. Inspiring individuals to change consumer-related behaviors has the potential to yield a twenty-five per cent diversion of municipal waste away from our landfills. So all we have to do is get people to think differently about wasteâ€¦cool, we are on it.










Our top 5 goals for using Trashion as a powerful tool for behavior change

  1. To captivate audiences through visually striking artwork.
  2. Use artistic expression and entertainment as the means to tell stories that will generate awareness about the impacts of our consumption habits.
  3. Use the methodologies of the â€˜Fun Theoryâ€™, â€˜Social Marketingâ€™ and â€˜Guerrilla Marketingâ€™ to engage participants in hands-on activities that will generate a message that will stick.
  4. Deliver an experience that is so unique, positive and fun that it sparks new ideas, creates new dreams and inspires new actions.
  5. Provide resources and alternative solutions to pave the way toward monumental consumer-related behavior change.










Top 5 reasons weâ€™re so passionate about this issue

  1. Weâ€™ve done a ton of research on the impacts our materials economy.  We are repulsed to find that such ecological and social adversities can come from our countryâ€™s addiction to stuff.
  2. Itâ€™s not just about getting recycling right.  The biggest waste-related impacts come from the creation, shipping and use of our stuff.   There needs to be an entire paradigm shift in our consumer behaviors and our relationships to stuff.
  3. While weâ€™re not the only group trying to solve waste related issues, we do think that there needs to be a larger focus on using creativity, art, humor,and FUN to generate experiences that will inspire behavior change for social good.
  4. There are tens of thousands of organizations working on environmental issues so why one more?  We believe that the more groups that are working towards this common goal, the more quickly and efficiently we can create the world that we all wish to see.
  5. We canâ€™t wait for government, technology and green products to solve our problems.  Itâ€™s all of our responsibilities to be mindful as individual consumers, with what we buy, who we buy it from, impacts of use and end of life considerations.

                   


Top 5 positive thoughts for creating a new way of thinking

  1. Imagine a world in which there was no such thing as trash; that everything that we â€œthrew awayâ€ was perceived as a valuable resource, used to create something new or as a nutrient for the earth.  
  2. What if long-lasting and repairable purchases ruled over cheap prices?
  3. What if durable was more convenient than disposables, and we valued doing stuff instead of buying stuff?
  4. Consider that low-impact doesnâ€™t mean sacrifice, but is a means to reclaim our time, money and pursuit of happiness.
  5. What if the ultimate measure of coolness was how little you bought, how much you shared and how much you creatively reused?










Top 5 ways you can help (whether you can donate or not)

  1. Share our IndieGoGo link with otherâ€™s that you think will be in to what weâ€™re doing; you can do this right here at the top of the campaign page through email, facebook and twitter.  
  2. Weâ€™re always looking for folks to help out; check out our website for specifics.
  3. We also have a few things on our wish list including things like dress forms, office space, storage space, garment racks.  Again, check our website for details.
  4. Hire us or sponsor our projects; check out our programs get in touch to learn how our surprise and delight â€œeco entertainmentâ€™ can be used to engage customers, attendees, employees and more.
  5. Introduce us to your network of people that you think would be interested in our work; event producers, conference organizers, sustainability centric companies and organizations, HR and marketing personnel.  These are the types folks that can help us get our message out to a wider and more diverse audience.


Top 5 groups that inspire us

  1. The Story of Stuff
  2. The Center for a New American Dream
  3. Founders of â€œThe Fun Theoryâ€
  4. Haute Trash and  
  5. Recycled Runway (two other great groups using trashion to change the world)

 

A personal note from the Founder and "Chief Instigator"
Many of you know us as the Junk to Funk Recycled Fashion Show Contest; the annual runway shows in Portland that have collectively featured over 100 Trashion (thatâ€™s trash fashion) garments as seen in our last show in the featured video above.  Many donâ€™t know that we had to bring to an end the event because of the recession; the economy crashed and we lost nearly all of our sponsors.  With no other financial backing and limited resources, it made it impossible to move forward with the big production that cost about $40,000 to operate on top of the $50,000 in in-kind support we received.  


I see this as a blessing in disguise.  I started Junk to Funk because I thought it would be a fun, very "Portland" event; mixing art, fashion and sustainability.  After selling out our shows and receiving notable media attention, even with the economic crash, many of us knew that Junk to Funk had the opportunity to create a much larger impact by expanding our activities beyond an annual runway show.  


We changed our model in 2010 to establish the "collective" and to develop several new activities that now operate throughout the year; you can learn more about these on our website,  www.junktofunk.org.  Weâ€™ve brought our work to literally hundreds of thousands of viewers with extremely limited resources and through the commitment from some very talented rock star volunteers.  


We want to continue this creative and pioneering work but it requires your support. 

We need to demonstrate that all of you, the Junk to Funk enthusiasts, want to see us THRIVE!  Thank you!

about four planets to satisfy those needs.  We donâ€™t think thatâ€™s going to happen anytime soon.


For everyone one can of garbage that you throw out on the
curb for pick up, 70 cans of waste were created in making of the stuff that you
just threw away.  Wonder whoâ€™s
paying that bill? 

99% of our stuff ends up either recycled or in the landfill
in just 6 months.  Seriously, thatâ€™s pretty unnecessary donâ€™t you think?
Inspiring individuals to change consumer-related behaviors
has the potential to yield a twenty-five per cent diversion of municipal waste
away from our landfills. So all we
have to do is get people to think differently about wasteâ€¦cool, we are on it.











Our top 5 goals for using Trashion as a powerful tool for
behavior change

To captivate audiences through visually striking artwork.
Use artistic expression and entertainment as the means to
tell stories that will generate awareness about the impacts of our consumption
habits.
Use the methodologies of the â€˜Fun Theoryâ€™, â€˜Social Marketingâ€™
and â€˜Guerrilla Marketingâ€™ to engage participants in hands-on activities that will
generate a message that will stick.
Deliver an experience that is so unique, positive and fun
that it sparks new ideas, creates new dreams and inspires new actions.
Provide resources and alternative solutions to pave the way
toward monumental consumer-related behavior change.











Top 5 reasons weâ€™re so passionate about this issue


Weâ€™ve done a ton of research on the impacts our materials
economy.  We are repulsed to find
that such ecological and social adversities can come from our countryâ€™s
addiction to stuff.


Itâ€™s not just about getting recycling right.  The biggest waste-related impacts come
from the creation, shipping and use of our stuff.   There needs to be an entire paradigm shift in our
consumer behaviors and our relationships to stuff.

While weâ€™re not the only group trying to solve waste related
issues, we do think that there needs to be a larger focus on using creativity,
art, humor,and FUN to generate experiences that will inspire
behavior change for social good.

There are tens of thousands of organizations working on environmental
issues so why one more?  We believe
that the more groups that are working towards this common goal, the more
quickly and efficiently we can create the world that we all wish to see.

We canâ€™t wait for government, technology and green products
to solve our problems.  Itâ€™s all of
our responsibilities to be mindful as individual consumers, with what we buy, who we buy
it from, impacts of use and end of life considerations.


                   

Top 5 positive thoughts for creating a new way of thinking

Imagine a world in which there was no such thing as trash;
that everything that we â€œthrew awayâ€ was perceived as a valuable resource, used
to create something new or as a nutrient for the earth.  
What if long-lasting and repairable purchases ruled over
cheap prices?
What if durable was more convenient than disposables, and we
valued doing stuff instead of buying stuff?
Consider that low-impact doesnâ€™t mean sacrifice, but is a
means to reclaim our time, money and pursuit of happiness.
What if the ultimate measure of coolness was how little you
bought, how much you shared and how much you creatively reused?











Top 5 ways you can help (whether you can donate or not)


Share our IndieGoGo link with otherâ€™s that you think will be
in to what weâ€™re doing; you can do this right here at the top of the campaign
page through email, facebook and twitter.  


Weâ€™re always looking for folks to help out; check out our
website for specifics.

We also have a few things on our wish list including things
like dress forms, office space, storage space, garment racks.  Again, check our website for details.
Hire us or sponsor our projects; check out our programs get in touch to learn how our surprise and
delight â€œeco entertainmentâ€™ can be used to engage customers, attendees,
employees and more.
Introduce us to your network of people that you think would
be interested in our work; event producers, conference organizers,
sustainability centric companies and organizations, HR and marketing
personnel.  These are the types
folks that can help us get our message out to a wider and more diverse
audience.


Top 5 groups that inspire us

The Story of Stuff
The Center for a New American Dream
Founders of â€œThe Fun Theoryâ€
Haute Trash and  
Recycled Runway (two other great groups
using trashion to change the world)


 

A personal note from the Founder and "Chief Instigator"
Many of you know us as the Junk to Funk Recycled Fashion Show Contest; the annual runway shows in Portland that have collectively featured over 100 Trashion (thatâ€™s trash fashion) garments as seen in our last show in the featured video above.  Many donâ€™t know that we had to bring to an end the event because of the recession; the economy crashed and we lost nearly all of our sponsors.  With no other financial backing and limited resources, it made it impossible to move forward with the big production that cost about $40,000 to operate on top of the $50,000 in in-kind support we received.  

I see this as a blessing in disguise.  I started Junk to Funk because I thought it would be a fun, very "Portland" event; mixing art, fashion and sustainability.  After selling out our shows and receiving notable media attention, even with the economic crash, many of us knew that Junk to Funk had the opportunity to create a much larger impact by expanding our activities beyond an annual runway show.  

We changed our model in 2010 to establish the "collective" and to develop several new activities that now operate throughout the year; you can learn more about these on our website,  www.junktofunk.org.  Weâ€™ve brought our work to literally hundreds of thousands of viewers with extremely limited resources and through the commitment from some very talented rock star volunteers.  





We want to
continue this creative and pioneering work but it requires your support. 
We need to
demonstrate that all of you, the Junk to Funk enthusiasts, want to see us THRIVE!  Thank you!

story:
Für Informationen auf Deutsch      A los que hablan Español: 

Info in Japanese/Nihongo            Aux francophones 

nijongo jimaku http://youtu.be/b6JLZ-1VnO8

Per informazioni in italiano  visitate http://www.greenheartproject.org/it/

 

-CHECK NEW PERKS -

FAIR TRADE SHOPPING VOUCHERS

        $25 Perk - Add a $10 Shopping voucher
    $50 & $75 Perk - Add a $20 Shopping voucher

Supported by Haiti Projects, Global Exchange, AlterEco, Hope, Rapanui and more...


What if we had sea transportation that caused no environmental harm AND allowed many millions of underprivileged people to access profitable markets and fisheries?

How about a ship that produces electrical power, instead of just consuming fuel?

Gavin:  Well, a few years ago, we came up with an idea for just such a ship.  While we've been refining the idea and consulting with communities and relevant experts, we've confirmed that there is a large, and growing need for this kind of innovation. Large scale, high-volume ocean shipping is relatively efficient and adequate for the big players in globalization.  But for the hundreds of millions of poor that live along the world's coastlines, there is no cheap, safe way to get their products to global markets, or access fisheries that are just over the horizon.  This means that no matter how hard they work, they cannot get a fair price for their products.  For people who can earn only a few dollars per day, this kind of competitive edge makes the difference between misery and a decent lifestyle.

Pat:  Since these impoverished coastal and island communities will be the principal end-users of our ship, we designed her specifically with universally available materials, very low cost to build and maintain, operable along undeveloped shorelines, simple to run with minimal training & formal education, and of course, zero-fuel.

What we have is an elegant, simple, leapfrog technology, that can even the playing field a little for those coastal and riverbank peoples who live in poverty.  And one that may well lead the way towards cleaner technologies for all of us.

A Sail-Solar Hybrid Ship 

Pat: Meet Sailing Vessel (S/V) Greenheart, a small industrial ship that uses only sails and solar-electric for power.

Displacement 220 tons                    Length 31.5m (103ft)

Beam 7.8m (25.5ft)                         Draught 2.2m (7ft)

Sail: 300 m² (3230 ft²)                    Solar (PV) array:125 m² (1313 ft²)

DC motors: 100kW x 2                   Battery: Lead/Acid traction

Hull speed: 10~11 kn                     Cargo: 3 x 20ft shipping containers

 
Jen: With your help the first ship, S/V Greenheart, will be launched in the middle of next year. The first ship shares it's name with our organisation, the Greenheart project. We are a registered non-profit staffed by a diverse group of small ship designers, avid sailors, sustainable development advocates and passionate volunteers working to make sail and sail-solar hybrids a sustainable sea transport solution for the future.

Pat: Here's what's attractive about a sail-solar hybrid vs. a conventional diesel vessel:

* No fuel.  That means no fuel costs, no CO2 or other emissions , and no need for refueling stops.  It means your primary operating cost is labor - a cost that varies appropriately with local economies, as opposed to fuel which is tied directly to a global market.

* Low maintenance.  Removing reliance on combustion-based engines means maintenance becomes infrequent and inexpensive.

* No range limits.  Combined with no fuel costs ticking away every minute of your time makes for considerable flexibility in operations.

Why small?

Gavin: Well, present-day solar photovoltaic (PV) panels are clean & efficient, but limited in power output.  They can provide the auxiliary power needs of a ship this size.  Not bigger.  Not yet. The main propulsion power is from the wind, and the solar-charged electricity is used to run the motors, the winches and capstans, the electronic communications and navigational equipment, and the 'house' power -- lights, refrigerator, watermakers.

It turns out that smaller ships make up most of the world's fleet and answer the needs of developing communities nicely.

Pat: Serving areas with minimal (or zero) infrastructure was a design priority:

* Purposefully shallow hull for beach landing and river system access.

* A tailgate-like roll-on, roll-off capability via a sort of drawbridge in the stern allows interesting cargo, fishing, and eco-tourism applications.

* Innovative combination mast-crane design that allows loading even when there are no port facilities at all  and especially low clearance (under low bridges and power lines)

* Cargo flexibility accommodating anything from burlap sacks to standard shipping containers.

 

We've also focused on durability, repairability, and relative simplicity to operate and learn. ...and affordability. It doesn't matter how great your solution is if people can't afford to acquire one for themselves and make it their own.

Jen: We have devised a tool that screams out for innovative, entrepreneurial uses -- one that empowers local people and helps them become more resilient.

Trade between developing regions that skips the developed world entirely.  All kinds of ferry and mail services.  Fishing, ecotourism, floating machinist shops... The ships could even function as solar power stations when docked.  We anticipate not being able to anticipate all the uses creative people will find for them. 

Satoshi:  In case you haven't guessed -- this is an open source project, too.  We want people to take our designs, modify them to suit their own purposes, and run with it.  Just let us know how you're doing, what's working well, and what can be improved.  The best way to find a better future is to look for it together. 

(For more project and technical information, check out our project PDF and our design pages.)

Greenheart's Plan - How you can help

Jen: We've spent the last few years thinking, planning, designing.  

Now we're ready to bring our ship from the naval architect's office to the water.

Our plan is to take the first one on a voyage around the world, testing the sail/solar hybrid concept in several different applications, including a good deal of time in the marginalized areas where a Greenheart ship will be most useful.

Gavin: We have a growing community of partners who want to work with us on our first trial applications. One such example is a groundbreaking project in Fiji to create a sustainable local shipping network in collaboration with leading NGO's (IUCN-Oceania Programme , World Wildlife Fund (WWF)- South Pacific Programme), local sailing groups (Fiji islands Voyaging Society , Sailing for Sustainability), academia (University of South Pacific) regional bodies (Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) , Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP) and shipping (B9 Shipping)

Many South Pacific island groups are faced with long blue ocean distances between them, limited resources of fossil fuel and existing shipping that is worn out, unreliable, polluting, dangerous and expensive to operate. The project involves locally trained crews from coastal communities on the Lau and Kadavu islands in Fiji. They will operate a number of smaller cargo catamarans along with a larger Greenheart ship that will service the larger island groups. This type of network will make communities more resilient in the face of climate change and be a model for the entire region.

Michele: We need your help to get started.

It is time to build the first ship.  One ship sounds like a small thing - but it will have an impact on thousands of lives.  And, it won’t be just one ship - it will be the first of dozens, hundreds, or even thousands of ships like it all over the world.

We start with one. This first one -- S/V Greenheart -- we will sail around the world on a 60,000 mile voyage.  Take a look at the route map;  It's epic.  

 

Jen: The idea is to test the ship in a wide variety of conditions, and in various applications.  We will be carrying freight for NGOs, buying and selling our own goods, experimenting with fishing under sail, visiting remote and impoverished communities to get input and feedback on the ship.  There will also be high-profile visits to our partners, port-of-call cities like Hamburg, Seattle, and Vancouver, for festive events and to show off the ship.  We will have scientists aboard, conducting experiments and we'll be doing our own trials as an eco-tour boat - visiting pristine regions.

 

More than just Perks -- Shares

Gavin: This Indiegogo campaign asks you to support us, and we have something special in mind for the Perks.  We are offering Shares in the maiden voyage of the first ship.   You will actually be purchasing a portion of the adventure - one that you can participate in, not just follow on a blog.  In the tradition of the great merchant/adventure/discovery voyages of the past, we will form a 'company' of partners in this first round-the-world odyssey. We already have cities and NGOs, scientists and equipment sponsors aboard. (see supporters pages in the gallery)  Now we want to crowdsource some of the crew, the supporters, and the stakeholders.

All supporters will get official invitations and discounts on the shipped goods for sale...

And for those who purchased the Shares, there will be something extra. These Shares are in the Maiden Voyage. 

 

Gavin: Redeem these at any time during the two-year trip. You can:

  • Sail for a Day - Meet the Greenheart ship when she sails into a port near you and come out aboard her for the day (1 share) If you can't afford much time, but still want a taste of life aboard the ship, this is for you.

  • Join us on the Voyage - Each share is roughly equivalent to one day at sea, 3 shares ($250) allows you to join us as crew on a short hop while 7 shares ($500) will give you one week aboard and you can travel between many neighboring countries (or significant distances along the coasts of larger ones). At 15 shares ($1000) you get a fortnight that can take you across a continent or for the really adventurous join us for a month-long epic ocean crossing. Read more... (Details, route examples etc.)

  • Trading - Perhaps you will use your Share to trade a bit on your own (for example, buy paprika in Zanzibar, and have it delivered to you in Hamburg, or Boston). You can hand your Share over to our ship's bursar with your request on the goods you want to trade. We'll give you regular updates, product information and advice along the way.

  • Ship with Us – Got a cargo you want to send from one part of the world to another? Don't want to worry about any fossil fuel miles? You've come to the right place. These products will get our “Blue Sea Miles” zero-carbon label and we'll deliver it straight into your hands at one of our ports of call. You could even sell at our port events if you'd like. Alternately, if you’re not in a big hurry, we’re also happy to do things like help ship your bicycle overseas. One share is the equivalent of shipping 100kg, 500 nautical miles (nm) (exludes port fees, taxes etc.)

  • Donate - Some people might decide to donate their Shares to an NGO to help with their shipping needs. We will match every donation with an additional share. Just let us know which organisation you would like to give those to, and we will send them the shares and give them a chance to thank you in person.

Jen: Everyone will be part of the ship's Company and help make it a success -- twice. Once when you click to pay, and again when you redeem your Share however you like.

Satoshi: The Greenheart Project has always been open-source. By that we mean that we are not patenting any innovations, nor protecting any intellectual property. Our principal goal is to get the idea into practice as soon and as much as possible.

Now, we are opening the exciting first voyage of the first ship to the public, too. If this IndieGoGo campaign reaches our goal, we will do more in other languages, in other markets along our route. The optimal scenario is to have the first ship and her voyages entirely funded by Greeenheart supporters. All additional funds and trading revenue will be used to establish a non-profit, cooperative fund to help build subsequent ships worldwide.

 

Our Indiegogo Funding Goal is $120,000*

THE ASTERISK

Gavin: $120,000 may seem like a suprisingly small amount to build a ship. So, here's a little detail on what we can do with that amount.

First, she is a remarkably low cost ship to build. Remember that we designed her for use by the people in the least-developed regions of the world. This is where our technology is most sorely needed. And where people can least afford it.

The S/V Greenheart can be built and fitted out for $500,000. ( We expect the cost of ships to trend downward as we increase production.) We are working with a shipyard in Bangladesh, and along with the funds and equipment/service support we already have, we are a fair way down the road to financing the ship. This $120,000 will help to push us over the top in getting the steel hull work done. Our designers, volunteers & crew will then be going to Bangladesh to complete the job. This way, we will all be well-acquainted with her details when it comes to sea trials.

Michele: If we can get additional funds, then outfitting the ship and getting her sea tested and prepared for her worldwide journey becomes a whole lot easier. With your support we can get construction under way with our goal to launch the ship in the middle of next year.


--CHECK NEW PERKS -- FAIR TRADE SHOPPING VOUCHERS --
               $25 Perk - Add a $10 Shopping voucher
           $50 & $75 Perk - Add a $20 Shopping voucher

 

- NEW Perks -

Fair Trade and Ethical Shopping Vouchers

 

We'll send you a $10 or $20 voucher to buy any goods at the retailers listed below. There are no restrictions on what you buy with the vouchers, all we ask is you try to shop as locally as possible.

$25 Perk - Add a $10 Shopping voucher $50 & $75 Perk - Add a $20 Shopping voucher

We would like to thank the following Fair Trade stores and companies for their generous support.

We are planning to have more shops, as close as possible to everyone who has made a donation and we encourage you to take the voucher in and support your local Fairtrade and Ethical companies.

The vouchers will be sent out at the end of the campaign in November, in time for the holidays.

 

United States

Global Exchange [2 stores in San Francisco, Wash. D.C., Virginia]


Haiti Projects [Boston + Online Shop]


Traditions Café and World Folk Art [Olympia, Washington]

Europe

Rapanui Clothing (UK) [Isle of Wight Shop + Online Shop]

Tres Hombres [Netherlands – Rum and Madeira ]

 

Australia & New Zealand COMING SOON
 Asia COMING SOON
 Canada COMING SOON


Perk Alternatives

Gavin: You can have your name aboard the ship. We will be flying flags at every port.  Each port call will be an event - a festive event where interested locals, supporters, and media can come down, see the ship, talk to the crew, browse through the zero carbon goods people have shipped with us, meet other people interested in sail as serious transport, enjoy good music, food, and drink, etc.  Your flag can be among the many that festoon the ship.

Throughout this campaign we will also offer some additional perk options for you to use your donations and share certificates on if you so wish. These can be sent to you straight away, and we will find a way to offset the carbon, you can collect them yourselves, preferably by bicycle or under sail – decreasing that footprint or you can wait and have them delivered by us.
Some of these perk options are available now:

($50+) Masi Cloth from Moce, Fiji This is a gift set of beautifully handwoven cloth directly from the women making it in the village of Korova.  The village, a squatter encampment on the edge of Suva, is recognised as the cultural home of this craft in Fiji.  In addition to weaving, the Moce community living there is one of the last still keeping camakau sailing alive in Fiji. Many in the village are unemployed and sales by the women of Masi is one of the staple income earners they have. Read more...

($100+) A Cache of Zero-Carbon Rum and Wine - Our friends at Fair Transport have been sailing artisanal rum from the Dominican Republic and Madeira to Europe aboard their merchant brigantine, the Tres Hombres, for several years now. This is no grog we're talking about - it's the good stuff that belongs in a place of pride in the captain's quarters.  Though they have traveled thousands miles, these bottles have generated not a single ounce of CO2 - have the sea miles nurtured their flavor and character? It's up to you to find out. Read more..

($2500) A Handcrafted Bangladeshi Traditional Sail Boat Model - Our freinds at the Friendship Association and Taratari Shipyard in Chittagong, Bangladesh want to present to you two hand crafted, museum quality, 2-4ft long traditional sail boat models. A number of these beautifully made models are on exhibition in Paris Museum and the construction of these helps to pay local master boat builders and keep their traditions alive. A one-of-a-kind treasure, to be sure. Read more...

We will be posting a few more perk options as these become available during the campaign. When you make a donation, just let us know if you would prefer to take one of the options available and we will arrange that.


*Build & Sailing Schedule Changes

Pat: Building a ship is a major undertaking, and there can be unforeseen delays and departures from schedule. You will have to be flexible when it comes to redeeming your share certificates, and we will continue to do our best to keep on schedule.

In addition, shipping cargo and joining the vessel will be on a schedule that is dependent upon wind and other conditions. Our good friends at Fair Transport have agreed to back us up and supply a limited number of berths and cargo space on their cargo/sail brigantine, the Tres Hombres. These would be made available on their regular Europe-Caribbean-US-Europe route.

Jen: The idea is to test the ship in a wide variety of conditions, and in various applications.  We will be carrying freight for NGOs, buying and selling our own goods, experimenting with fishing under sail, visiting remote and impoverished communities to get input and feedback on the ship.  There will also be high-profile visits to our partners, port-of-call cities like Hamburg, Seattle, and Vancouver, for festive events and to show off the ship.  We will have scientists aboard, conducting experiments and we'll be doing our own trials as an eco-tour boat - visiting pristine regions. 

 
More than just Perks -- Shares
Gavin: This Indiegogo campaign asks you to support us, and we have something special in mind for the Perks.  We are offering Shares in the maiden voyage of the first ship.   You will actually be purchasing a portion of the adventure - one that you can participate in, not just follow on a blog.  In the tradition of the great merchant/adventure/discovery voyages of the past, we will form a 'company' of partners in this first round-the-world odyssey. We already have cities and NGOs, scientists and equipment sponsors aboard. (see supporters pages in the gallery)  Now we want to crowdsource some of the crew, the supporters, and the stakeholders.
All supporters will get official invitations and discounts on the shipped goods for sale...
And for those who purchased the Shares, there will be something extra. These Shares are in the Maiden Voyage. 
 
Gavin: Redeem these at any time during the two-year trip. You can:


Sail for a Day - Meet the Greenheart ship when she sails into a port near you and come out aboard her for the day (1 share) If you can't afford much time, but still want a taste of life aboard the ship, this is for you.


Join us on the Voyage - Each share is roughly equivalent to one day at sea, 3 shares ($250) allows you to join us as crew on a short hop while 7 shares ($500) will give you one week aboard and you can travel between many neighboring countries (or significant distances along the coasts of larger ones). At 15 shares ($1000) you get a fortnight that can take you across a continent or for the really adventurous join us for a month-long epic ocean crossing. Read more... (Details, route examples etc.) 


Trading - Perhaps you will use your Share to trade a bit on your own (for example, buy paprika in Zanzibar, and have it delivered to you in Hamburg, or Boston). You can hand your Share over to our ship's bursar with your request on the goods you want to trade. We'll give you regular updates, product information and advice along the way.


Ship with Us – Got a cargo you want to send from one part of the world to another? Don't want to worry about any fossil fuel miles? You've come to the right place. These products will get our “Blue Sea Miles” zero-carbon label and we'll deliver it straight into your hands at one of our ports of call. You could even sell at our port events if you'd like. Alternately, if you’re not in a big hurry, we’re also happy to do things like help ship your bicycle overseas. One share is the equivalent of shipping 100kg, 500 nautical miles (nm) (exludes port fees, taxes etc.)


Donate - Some people might decide to donate their Shares to an NGO to help with their shipping needs. We will match every donation with an additional share. Just let us know which organisation you would like to give those to, and we will send them the shares and give them a chance to thank you in person.

Jen: Everyone will be part of the ship's Company and help make it a success -- twice. Once when you click to pay, and again when you redeem your Share however you like.
Satoshi: The Greenheart Project has always been open-source. By that we mean that we are not patenting any innovations, nor protecting any intellectual property. Our principal goal is to get the idea into practice as soon and as much as possible. 
Now, we are opening the exciting first voyage of the first ship to the public, too. If this IndieGoGo campaign reaches our goal, we will do more in other languages, in other markets along our route. The optimal scenario is to have the first ship and her voyages entirely funded by Greeenheart supporters. All additional funds and trading revenue will be used to establish a non-profit, cooperative fund to help build subsequent ships worldwide.
 
Our Indiegogo Funding Goal is $120,000*
THE ASTERISK
Gavin: $120,000 may seem like a suprisingly small amount to build a ship. So, here's a little detail on what we can do with that amount. 
First, she is a remarkably low cost ship to build. Remember that we designed her for use by the people in the least-developed regions of the world. This is where our technology is most sorely needed. And where people can least afford it. 
The S/V Greenheart can be built and fitted out for $500,000. ( We expect the cost of ships to trend downward as we increase production.) We are working with a shipyard in Bangladesh, and along with the funds and equipment/service support we already have, we are a fair way down the road to financing the ship. This $120,000 will help to push us over the top in getting the steel hull work done. Our designers, volunteers & crew will then be going to Bangladesh to complete the job. This way, we will all be well-acquainted with her details when it comes to sea trials.
Michele: If we can get additional funds, then outfitting the ship and getting her sea tested and prepared for her worldwide journey becomes a whole lot easier. With your support we can get construction under way with our goal to launch the ship in the middle of next year.

--CHECK NEW PERKS -- FAIR TRADE SHOPPING VOUCHERS --               $25 Perk - Add a $10 Shopping voucher           $50 & $75 Perk - Add a $20 Shopping voucher 

 
- NEW Perks -
Fair Trade and Ethical Shopping Vouchers
 
We'll send you a $10 or $20 voucher to buy any goods at the retailers listed below. There are no restrictions on what you buy with the vouchers, all we ask is you try to shop as locally as possible.
$25 Perk - Add a $10 Shopping voucher $50 & $75 Perk - Add a $20 Shopping voucher 
We would like to thank the following Fair Trade stores and companies for their generous support. 
We are planning to have more shops, as close as possible to everyone who has made a donation and we encourage you to take the voucher in and support your local Fairtrade and Ethical companies. 
The vouchers will be sent out at the end of the campaign in November, in time for the holidays.
 
United States

Global Exchange [2 stores in San Francisco, Wash. D.C., Virginia] 
Haiti Projects [Boston + Online Shop] 
Traditions Café and World Folk Art [Olympia, Washington] Europe

Rapanui Clothing (UK) [Isle of Wight Shop + Online Shop] 

Tres Hombres [Netherlands – Rum and Madeira ]
 
Australia & New Zealand     COMING SOON
Asia        COMING SOON
Canada     COMING SOON

Perk Alternatives

Gavin: You can have your name aboard the ship. We will be flying flags at every port.  Each port call will be an event - a festive event where interested locals, supporters, and media can come down, see the ship, talk to the crew, browse through the zero carbon goods people have shipped with us, meet other people interested in sail as serious transport, enjoy good music, food, and drink, etc.  Your flag can be among the many that festoon the ship.
Throughout this campaign we will also offer some additional perk options for you to use your donations and share certificates on if you so wish. These can be sent to you straight away, and we will find a way to offset the carbon, you can collect them yourselves, preferably by bicycle or under sail – decreasing that footprint or you can wait and have them delivered by us.Some of these perk options are available now:
($50+) Masi Cloth from Moce, Fiji This is a gift set of beautifully handwoven cloth directly from the women making it in the village of Korova.  The village, a squatter encampment on the edge of Suva, is recognised as the cultural home of this craft in Fiji.  In addition to weaving, the Moce community living there is one of the last still keeping camakau sailing alive in Fiji. Many in the village are unemployed and sales by the women of Masi is one of the staple income earners they have. Read more...
($100+) A Cache of Zero-Carbon Rum and Wine - Our friends at Fair Transport have been sailing artisanal rum from the Dominican Republic and Madeira to Europe aboard their merchant brigantine, the Tres Hombres, for several years now. This is no grog we're talking about - it's the good stuff that belongs in a place of pride in the captain's quarters.  Though they have traveled thousands miles, these bottles have generated not a single ounce of CO2 - have the sea miles nurtured their flavor and character? It's up to you to find out. Read more..
($2500) A Handcrafted Bangladeshi Traditional Sail Boat Model - Our freinds at the Friendship Association and Taratari Shipyard in Chittagong, Bangladesh want to present to you two hand crafted, museum quality, 2-4ft long traditional sail boat models. A number of these beautifully made models are on exhibition in Paris Museum and the construction of these helps to pay local master boat builders and keep their traditions alive. A one-of-a-kind treasure, to be sure. Read more...
We will be posting a few more perk options as these become available during the campaign. When you make a donation, just let us know if you would prefer to take one of the options available and we will arrange that.
*Build & Sailing Schedule Changes
Pat: Building a ship is a major undertaking, and there can be unforeseen delays and departures from schedule. You will have to be flexible when it comes to redeeming your share certificates, and we will continue to do our best to keep on schedule.
In addition, shipping cargo and joining the vessel will be on a schedule that is dependent upon wind and other conditions. Our good friends at Fair Transport have agreed to back us up and supply a limited number of berths and cargo space on their cargo/sail brigantine, the Tres Hombres. These would be made available on their regular Europe-Caribbean-US-Europe route.

story:
The Uluwatu Project

We are passionate about saving Uluwatu. Your support and donations will be put to good use here in Indonesia. All donations through this site deposite directly to the Project Clean Uluwatu (PCU) bank account safely within the notable and registered non-profit organization GUS Foundation.

Who is Involved:

The brainchild of two residents, Jon and Ollie, PCU was formed when local NGOs teamed up with the surf industry, local businesses and residents.

Active members of the committee include:

Paola Cannucciari (ecoBali Recycling)

James Hendy (Rip Curl Asia)

Ollie Crowell and Tim Russo (Uluwatu Surf Villas)

Curtis Lowe 

Jon Huberman

Steve Palmer

Julianus (JDR B.S. Construction Company)

Ani Yulinda (GUS Foundation)

Antonio Portinari (Art In Surf)

Our Vision:

A future of clean and pristine waves stewarded by an environmentally conscious community that recognizes the special beauty and significance of Uluwatu.

Our Mission:

Plan, design, build and manage a solid and liquid waste infrastructure system to preserve and restore the ravine and cave ecosystems.

  • Become a sustainable, non-profit project assisted by the surf industry for the benefit of local residents, surfers and coastal visitors.
  • To be managed and operated by the local community for the benefit of the community and visitors to Uluwatu.
  • Create a successful case study that can be replicated in other ‘environmentally-troubled’ surf areas in Indonesia, and globally.

Accomplishments to date:

  • 30 tons of solid waste and rubbish were removed from the ravine in June of 2011.
  • Daily collection of rubbish from the Uluwatu cliffside shops and warungs, where local ladies were employed by GUS Foundation began shortly after.
  • 3 times weekly the rubbish that has been carried up the steps is collected by ecoBali RECYCLING.
  • A large permanent concrete waste bin constructed by the R.O.L.E. Foundation.
  • Distribution of over 40 organic and non-organic rubbish bins accompanied by educational talks by ecoBali.
  • Professional surveying and topographical mapping of the Cliffside and shop areas completed before final design of the Liquid Waste and Sewerage System were drawn up by JDR B.S. Consultants.
  • Formation of a local council on waste and growth in April 2012 merged with ESRU.
  • Construction of housing for the central processesing underway.

Next Steps:

Raise $35,000 USD to install and manage the proposed liquid waste system.

Build a composting area so all organic waste can go towards gardens in the future – and save energy, as it’s the one kind of waste that doesn’t need to be carried up the steps.

Complete the World Surfing Heritage site application.

Hand over management to the local committee.

Ensure the future of Uluwatu is bright and green!

http://www.projectcleanuluwatu.com

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Project-Clean-Uluwatu/479706248784675

 

 Awesome Place, Awesome People, Doing Awesome Things

If you would like to volunteer your time or skills, we'd love to hear from you:

info@projectcleanuluwatu.com

story:
They Don’t Call This City the Capital of Happiness for Nothing!

 

Take a stroll in San Antonio, enjoy a relaxing evening down at Cali river or put on your dancing shoes and join the world-class salseros in Juanchito!

 

And if you are lucky, you will be able to experience the unique “La Feria de la Salsa”, the most famous salsa festival in the whole world!

 

Do You Want an Affordable and Modern Way to Spend Your Days Here?

 

We have got the solution!

We have decided to open a VEGAN hostel for people who want to have a first-hand experience of our culture, nature and cooking!

Since we offer a truly unique and cost-effective service, we are constantly booked out!

 

Our 7 beds, hammocks and air mattresses can’t cover the needs of the ever-growing tourist population!

 

That’s why we aim at improving our accommodation services!

 

With your invaluable help, we will be able to build sleek and ergonomic capsules that will provide all the necessary amenities for our cherished guests!

 

We Want You to Become a Part of Our Success Story!

 

The more you help us the better our ground-breaking capsule hostel will be!

 

Why miss out on this opportunity to become a contributor to our noble effort?

 

“No Medicine Can Cure What Happiness Cannot.”

 

As Gabriel Garcia Marquez once said, happiness is the meaning of life, and since Cali IS the world capital of happiness, you can rest assured that your contribution will make a lot of people extremely happy!

 

 

I love hostels!

 

Well, here you can meet people, learn stories, discover places, practice languages and so much more! 

 

So, we decided to open e VEGAN hostel and people have been loving our place, but we need some more beds. currently we have 7 beds and some hammocks and air mattresses and we are booked. We don't want to buy some more boring bunkbeds, we want the best private thing we know you will appreciate!!!

With your help, we will build beautiful design capsules where you can sleep with all the things you appreciate. Depending on how much you help us, we will be able to build more gadgets like lights, tables, blinds, music, ventilation, better mattresses, better sheets..... and imagination is the limit. 

Here we will build 8 capsules, but we would be able to go up to 30.

 

 

Why would anybody choose a capsule to sleep in? 

Well, let me put it this way: When you travel and sleep in hostels, you don't spend much time in the room, but you like privacy. You love to feel secure and want your belongings to remain yours. So here it is! a small private space to sleep and keep your stuff hazard free.

In our capsules we will build a locker where your backpack and stuff fit just right and secured. a real confortable mattress, nice study lamp and lets see what else you help us to put in.

With your support, we will build as many cozy capsules we can. with US$4500 we will be able too build 8 capsules.  this will be the first of 30 units. we would like to costume design a few of them and hopefully you will want to have your own costume design capsule.

 

Why do we need US$4500?

Building materials: US$1800

Mattresses: US$1300

Electricity and lamps: US$300

Blinds and privacy: US$500

Sheets and pillows: US$600

 

What if you want to get involve? 

If you like to help us with more than US$500, we will start to customize one capsule according to your wishes. We will be your best allied in cali anytime you in town. and even if you want us to replicate, we will open a vegan hostel in any other city here in Colombia.

 

Even if! 

If our project wasn't what we thought it would be, we will still finish the first 8 capsules.

 

Why believe in us?

Ok, Ok, yes. we need and want your money, but think about this:

Vegans may save the te planet, who knows! why not help a vegan out? we will do our best for the planet and for the animals.

 

 

 

You don´t have any money? no problem, there is plenty of stuff to do. like designs, campaign managing, promotion and so much sharing to do!

 Please share this project if you like it

anywhere!!

 

Thats all folks!

Ok, Ok, yes. we need and want your money, but think about this:
Vegans may save the te planet, who knows! why not help a vegan out? we will do our best for the planet and for the animals.
 
  You don´t have any money? no problem, there is plenty of stuff to do. like designs, campaign managing, promotion and so much sharing to do!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! thanks for visiting my campaign page. I am currently a college student, but I have had to take the semester off due to my financial aid being inexplicably and drastically cut. I wanted to make the best of it, though, by working and volunteering during my semester off. I have grown up hearing stories about my family volunteering on the Hudson River Clearwater Sloop (the late Pete Seeger's project) and have always wanted to go myself. 

I was surprised last week when the opportunity presented itself! However, with only a week's notice, I find myself scrambling to get the funds together for my trip -especially with late-purchase bus tickets at a premium.

What is Clearwater?

-Clearwater is a project founded by folk singer Pete Seeger. In his efforts to clean up the Hudson River, NY's primary water source, he purchased a sailboat to sail up and down the river. The boat stops along the way to pick up school children for a sail and the volunteers teach them on scene about environmental conservation and protection. (Learn more here: http://www.clearwater.org/about/)

What We Need & What You Get

This cause is extremely important to me, but as a nineteen-year-old who has already accumulated $10,000 of student debt, I am not able to reach my goal on my own. And that is where you, kind-hearted, do-gooders of Indiegogo come in...

Costs:

(Indiegogo has a minimum fundraising goal of $500, but in actuality, my calculated costs come to $310.50)

  • Bus to and from NYC, from North Carolina: $114.50
  • Bus to and from ship dock: $51
  • Volunteer Fee (meals and T-shirt): $125
  • Member Fee (mandatory for volunteers) $20

    The Impact

    Any dollar that you can spare will help so much!! I can't even articulate how much it would mean to me and help us promote environmental awareness and protection. 

    When Clearwater first started, the Hudson ran rank with sewage and waste from the city. The Clearwater Project was instrumental in passing the Clean Water Act and other legislation, and continues to do an impeccable job keeping the rivers clean today (and teaching the next generation to do the same).

    That being said, I cannot articulate to you how much good your donation will do to our shared earth!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Truly, just by viewing this campaign you have already helped! As a student myself, I don't expect most people to be able to shell out cash on a whim. I would really appreciate it, though, if you would take a couple seconds to hit the "share," button to help me get the word out over social media. Also, if you're interesting in environmental protection, be sure to check out http://www.clearwater.org/about/ to learn about this vital project!

story:
Short Summary

Chattanooga, TN is a great place to live and is known for being the scenic city. We have the world's largest fresh water aquarium at the Tennessee Aquarium, Rock City, Ruby Fall, Lookout Mountain to see 7 states, Civil war battlefield sites, vibrant art district, and many outdoor activities such as hiking, biking, fishing, rafting, mountain climbing, caving (spelunking), boating, shopping, and great places to eat. But more importantly Chattanooga is a thriving place for economic and progressive changes. We have a free electric shuttle system downtown, a bike share system, TVA Solar Initiatives, electric car charging stations, CSA farms, rooftop gardens, and many eco-conscious businesses. We currently have a few small composting efforts with a handful of businesses that support urban gardens and CSA Crab Tree Farms which coordinate to support the Food bank. I would like to see this model on a large scale for Chattanooga and cities across the nation:

About Me 

I grew up around in southern Missouri around the Branson area and my grandparents were both in the agriculture business. My paternal grandfather owned and operated several chicken hatcheries and my maternal grandpa raised crops and hogs in southeast Missouri near the boot heel. Both of my parents were health and environmentally conscious and raised me to respect animal, the environment, and people. Additionally, I have been a vegetarian for nearly my entire my life and I have a strong interest in sustainability, helping animals, and protecting the environment, which led me to study Psychology, Sociology, and Mechanical Engineering at the University of Missouri and the University of Tennessee-Chattanooga. I have a BGS in Math, Engineering, and Psychology from MU and I am working on a post-baccalaureate Mechanical Engineering degree at UTC.

When I was a child I attended Earth Day events, watched Disney Movies, enjoyed playing outside, and learning about people, plants, animals, and especially dinosaurs. Like many boys I dreamed of building amazing vehicles like that of Back to the Future or a more conventional, historic, and innovative vehicle such as a human-electric hybrid vehicle that incorporates pedaling, solar charging, regenerative braking, and plug-in charging. My observations about the world around me and culture media don't just give me ideas and inspiration, it teaches me to see how people can change the world by working together by incorporating small ideas to make a big impact. I am able to see the interconnectedness of the life on this planet and how every decision we make has a global impact. If you have heard of Immanuel Kant's Moral Imperative you may get what I mean. 

As a child I had learned about composting by Earth Day events, biology classes, Lion King, and my parents have composted in the past, my mom now feeds her food scraps to her organic, free range chickens in her back yard instead of composting. I always had the concept that you had to have a home, yard, and garden for composting to be practical, but with some introspection and research I found out I was wrong.

I am 25 and have been living the college dorm and apartment life since I was 18 and of course I recycled during that time, but I never really thought about composting, except that is something I want to do when I own a house and have a garden. I work in the food service industry serving banquets and the amount of food waste and recyclables that are trashed really got me thinking about ways to reduce my own food waste besides finishing my plate, taking home leftovers, and using smart ways to keep perishables from going bad at home. As part of my New Year's resolutions to be more sustainable I replaced my apartment 60 Watt incandescent lights with 14 Watt fluorescent bulbs, cut my phone bill in half, and bought a Worm Factory 360 and a Simple Human Compost Pail. 

Even if you don't think you produce much food waste or just have an apartment or condo balcony, you will find that you will compost more than you thought in any easy, affordable, and possibly even lucrative manner by selling compost soil, worm castings, and worm tea which are very valuable to the gardening and farming community.

What We Need 

Here is the breakdown of what is needed to make a successful city-wide composting program, although I am working on small community compost projects too:

  • Land to process city compost material 
  • Compost processing machinery and bins
  • Trucks to provide pickup service to businesses and neighborhoods
  • Containers for food service businesses to store compostable material
  • Gardening equipment supplies

What You Get

We are offering some sustainable products that demonstrate the kind of change we want to see in the world. Check out the backer rewards below.

  • Internet high five and information on how to start your compost at home on a budget. 
  • Bumper Sticker options "Compost Happens" , "Pre-sha-ate-cha", "I heart Composting", "Compost isn't what it used to be", "Compost a Rind is a terrible thing to waste"
  • T-shirts options "Compost Happens", "Pre-sha-ate-cha", 'Nooga, 
  • UrBin Grower
  • Simple Human Compost Pail
  • Worm Factory 360
  • Chattanooga Adventure Packet, Choice of 4 nights at Bed & Breakfast or Hotel in Chattanooga, tickets to Ruby Falls, Rock City, TN Aquarium, River Gorge Explorer, Adventures Unlimited White Water Rafting or Canoeing, Stand up Paddleboard rental, and $200 gift certificate to use at Chattanooga's best restaurants. You may also visit compost and urban garden projects and this program facility upon successful funding and development. Check out the Hill City Neighborhood Community Compost and Urban Garden project in North Chattanooga.

Click on the links for products above, search for more information on the above items, or contact me in the comment section for questions. 

Please note each backer reward is separate and we will they will be shipped ASAP and should arrive by the expectied arrival date listed for each reward.

The Impact

Your contribution not only makes a great impact for the city of Chattanooga, but you can use your backer rewards to reduce your carbon footprint, reduce landfill waste, make money, and grow healthy food at home.

  • Waste: According to the Environmental Protection Agency, “In 2010, Americans generated about 250 million tons of trash and recycled and composted over 85 million tons of this material, equivalent to a 34.1 percent recycling rate.” Generally, most Americans can recycle and compost at least 30-50% of their waste. Additionally, nearly 40% of all food produced in the U.S. today goes uneaten [nrdc.org]. According to the USDA, food operations such as restaurants, cafeterias, fast food service, and caterers contributed to 86 billion pounds of wasted food in 2008. Americans throw out approximately one quarter of their food and beverages purchased which equates to a loss of nearly $2,000 per year for a family of four [nrdc.org].
  • Food: According to Feeding America, 1 in 6 people in America go hungry and 46.2 million people were in poverty in 2011. A new study, Map the Meal Gap, released by Feeding America shows that children continue to struggle with hunger in every county in the nation. More than 1,000 counties have more than one in four children who are at risk of hunger.
  • By recycling, composting, reusing, and pre-cycling we can reduce over 50% of waste going to the landfill and use this waste in a constructive manner to help hungry and low-income Americans receive a hand up along with a hand out. By incorporating this type of system we can increase the quantity and quality of food going to children and families in need and provide sustainable, economic assistance to provide self-reliance and independence. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Economy is tight and every contribution helps, but here are some other way you can help

  • Use web activism to get the word out and start a conversation with friends about composting. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Sign political petition coming soon via links from my website, Twitter, and Facebook pages to request municipalities to provide compost waste management and/or support private composting companies to provide this service in your city and nationwide.
  • Educate your children and other kids in schools about gardening, composting, biology, animal welfare, sustainability, and health. The children are our future!

 Thank you for your time and support! Please share this campaign via Facebook and Twitter.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Chattanooga, TN is a great place to live and is known for being the scenic city. We have the world's largest fresh water aquarium at the Tennessee Aquarium, Rock City, Ruby Fall, Lookout Mountain to see 7 states, Civil war battlefield sites, vibrant art district, and many outdoor activities such as hiking, biking, fishing, rafting, mountain climbing, caving (spelunking), boating, shopping, and great places to eat. But more importantly Chattanooga is a thriving place for economic and progressive changes. We have a free electric shuttle system downtown, a bike share system, TVA Solar Initiatives, electric car charging stations, CSA farms, rooftop gardens, and many eco-conscious businesses. We currently have a few small composting efforts with a handful of businesses that support urban gardens and CSA Crab Tree Farms which coordinate to support the Food bank. I would like to see this model on a large scale for Chattanooga and cities across the nation:
About Me 
I grew up around in southern Missouri around the Branson area and my grandparents were both in the agriculture business. My paternal grandfather owned and operated several chicken hatcheries and my maternal grandpa raised crops and hogs in southeast Missouri near the boot heel. Both of my parents were health and environmentally conscious and raised me to respect animal, the environment, and people. Additionally, I have been a vegetarian for nearly my entire my life and I have a strong interest in sustainability, helping animals, and protecting the environment, which led me to study Psychology, Sociology, and Mechanical Engineering at the University of Missouri and the University of Tennessee-Chattanooga. I have a BGS in Math, Engineering, and Psychology from MU and I am working on a post-baccalaureate Mechanical Engineering degree at UTC.
When I was a child I attended Earth Day events, watched Disney Movies, enjoyed playing outside, and learning about people, plants, animals, and especially dinosaurs. Like many boys I dreamed of building amazing vehicles like that of Back to the Future or a more conventional, historic, and innovative vehicle such as a human-electric hybrid vehicle that incorporates pedaling, solar charging, regenerative braking, and plug-in charging. My observations about the world around me and culture media don't just give me ideas and inspiration, it teaches me to see how people can change the world by working together by incorporating small ideas to make a big impact. I am able to see the interconnectedness of the life on this planet and how every decision we make has a global impact. If you have heard of Immanuel Kant's Moral Imperative you may get what I mean.

story:
About Nature in the City 

We rely on our volunteers, members, donors, grantors, and small foundations to create, implement, and maintain our community stewardship projects in San Francisco. Our continued work together is vital to the bay area's biodiversity, even in a high-density urban environment. We look out for the little guys – in flight, in tide pools, on the ground – after all, nature is everywhere!  Urban biodiversity is our heritage and our future.  

Ensure that the city's rich biodiversity is available for future generations

We here at Nature in the City live our mission of caring for urban biodiversity and connecting San Franciscans to nature. We lead nature walks, hold events for children and families, offer eco-literacy training and volunteer opportunities, and are a resource for community groups wishing to start their own nature-based endeavors.

Nature in the City projects, made possible by your donations, help our communities to connect to the nature that is everywhere. Our newest, the Backyard Habitat & Native Plant Nursery Network, aims to provide safe haven where plants for pollinators, butterflies, birds, and insects can be grown. 

Our Executive Director Amber Hasselbring is an artist, naturalist, and educator, and has been a member of Nature in the City’s steering committee since 2006. Her public work includes Art on BART, the Angel Island Art & Ecology Festival, the Mission Greenbelt Project, Tigers on Market Street, and various pop-up nature parks, performances, and exhibitions in San Francisco. 

The Green Hairstreak Corridor

Our flagship project, the Green Hairstreak Corridor, was initiated by lepidopterist Liam O'Brien in 2006 and continues to be managed by Nature in the City. The corridor connects Green Hairstreak butterfly populations, which have been isolated due to urban development, by planting its host plants in strategically-located street parks. These parks are cared for by local residents and schoolchildren. Since the project's launch, the population of Green Hairstreak butterflies and their associated insects and birds, has increased two-fold. 

How your donations support us

  • Supplies for stabilizing soils at our sites, including wattles, stakes, jute netting; we also need hand-tools, gloves, as well as snacks, juice, and coffee for volunteers
  • Additional funds to fill the gaps! Nature in the City was awarded an San Francisco Carbon Fund grant to expand the Green Hairstreak Corridor in 2014, and this grant does not cover things like paying volunteer managers, hiring an event photographer, and paying naturalists to lead walks
  • New curriculum, created for the San Francisco Unified School District, to teach teachers how to collect local butterfly eggs, larvae, and raise them in classrooms instead of relying on mail-order kits
  • General project support to cover advocacy, paying rent, telephone bill, and all the other fun stuff it takes to run an organization

Impact

Support will give us a breath of fresh air, so we can roll up our sleeves and get to work restoring our unique habitats. What do you think of creating a coastal prairie ecosystem (the old growth at our feet) replete with wildflowers in the Sunset District ? It is in the San Francisco Planning Department's Green Connections Plan, and it will take all of us working together to make it happen. How about building a pond in your own backyard with a fountain to attract songbirds and a sunlit basin for basking Sierran Treefrogs? Nature in the City is your resource. 

Other ways you can help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily... 

You can promote us online! Tell people about our campaign on social media outlets like Facebook and Twitter and send them to this page!

  • Copy the campaign URL and paste it into an email or social media update. 
  • Click on the Facebook, Google Plus, or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks. 
  • Add a widget to your blog or personal website. Click Embed and then copy and paste the widget code. 
  • Send a direct email from Indiegogo.

You can also promote us offline throughout your community: Share our campaign by word of mouth or mention us in your community newsletter. 

Volunteer with us! We can always use more hands on our volunteer days.  Contact us at stewards@natureinthecity.org to find out how you, or your friends and family can participate.

Your company can donate volunteer time! We love corporate volunteers! Get in touch with us about setting up a volunteer day for your organization.

Nature in the City holds work parties to help improve habitats, and your help maintaining them is always appreciated. 

We are very grateful to the folks who have already stepped forward to volunteer their time! Thank you!

So many people have helped us make our projects a success. We'd like to thank all of you who have done so. You're helping build a greener and livelier San Francisco for us all!

We also gladly accept donations of materials.

story:
Help us prove aliens exist. The Tardigrade is an extremophile able to survive in space, but can it survive entering the Earth's atmosphere?


Project Summary

Project Stratobear is a senior project for three students at The Marine Academy of Science and Technology. The project will center around the goal of studying the upper atmospheric effect on Tardigrades (Waterbears). A Tardigrade is a small water dwelling micro-animal with six legs which have been hypothesized to have come from outer space. The Tardigrade is an extremophile which means it can survive in extreme conditions of heat and cold. The project involves constructing a weather balloon probe that would mimic the atmospheric effects of space to Earth entry.

 

Because of our project's diverse needs our group has chosen to split up the work and specialize in different areas:

 

Joseph Nardone- Team leader and probe housing engineer. The design challenge he will face is designing containment that will not only hold the Tardigrades into a specific area, but will also expose them to the atmospheric environment.

 

Nate Librizzi- Launch and recovery engineer. The design challenge he will face is designing a method to return the probe not only slowly, but also upright to preserve the Tardigrade containment.

 

Connor Varley- Navigation and camera operation engineer. The design challenge he will face is enabling the probe to be tracked while it flies and then relocated in a timely fashion.

 

Mentors- Our group has multiple mentors spanning from MakerSpace members to the famous naturalist Mike Shaw. With these mentors we are able to gain expert information on different topics we will be exploring.

What We Need and What You Get

Our group needs funding for multiple items:

-The probe and related equipment. Things such as helium, the balloons, parachutes, and PVC materials.

-The camera equipment and navigation equipment.

-Microscopes and other laboratory equipment to conduct the Tardigrade research.

-Website hosting and domain name fees.

 

On the right you can see some of our amazing perks. With these perks you will be receiving a reward for helping us fund our senior project.

The Impact

Our goal with our research is to support the Panspermia Hypothesis. This states that life exists throughout the universe and is spread about by meteorites, asteroids, comets, and planetoids. Tardigrades have already been proven to survive in space, but we want to see if they could survive entry.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate, but still support our project please share this kickstarter on a variety of social media networks! Thank you!

story:
The Light Bulb Moment

What is Seaside Explorers?  Picture this: a child laughing as a small, silvery fish escapes the grasp of his tiny fingers; the excited squeal of finding a hermit crab in the shell he just picked up on the beach; or the quiet concentration of viewing a dwarf seahorse that was discovered in a clump of seaweed at the water's edge through a magnifying viewer.

 I (Susan Leser) am a marine biologist and more importantly, a brand-new mom!  I will be leaving the confines of state government to return to the Florida Keys to share my love of the ocean and inspire children to be our planet’s next generation of environmental stewards.  Children of both underserved communities in Key West and family visitors to the Florida Keys will be offered targeted programs to learn about the wonders of the sea and marine conservation.  Exploration and hands-on activities will inspire a love of the ocean and foster critical-thinking skills.  

The idea for Seaside Explorers LLC came about while working at the NOAA Florida Keys Eco-Discovery Center as curator of The Living Reef exhibit.  Adult visitors would often remark that when their child is old enough, he/she could attend a marine biology camp;  children would proclaim "I am going to be a marine biologist one day!"  From these conversations I knew that an educational component was missing in the Florida Keys:  a targeted marine biology program for children on vacation with their families.

In addition, while working concurrently as a NOAA Coral Reef Classroom Instructor, I realized that many local schoolchildren did not have knowledge of the incredible resources in their own backyards:  the coral reefs of the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, the third largest barrier reef system in the world.  For this reason, Seaside Explorers will also be providing programs free of charge to local organizations such as the Boys & Girls Club.

By providing children with the ability to explore and learn under the guidance of a marine science professional, I hope to ignite a love of science and foster stewardship of our precious marine resources.

Please view the Gallery (fifth tab above) for additional photos and information about my previous work in Key West.

Getting Started

Although, this business venture and return to Key West will be self-funded in part, funding is needed for various start-up costs.   I am seeking $6,000 - liability insurance, business licenses, a new laptop, and professional services will account for approximately 50% of these costs.  The remainder will be utilized for exploration and craft activities.  Children will a) learn how to identify organisms using field guides, b) record observations and measurements in their very own take-home logbooks, c) test for water temperature and salinity with devices commonly utilized in the field, and d) participate in a host of other activities as part of their marine biologist in-training experience.  Purchases will include various types of nets, magnifying viewers, refractometers (to test salt content of water), digital thermometers, rulers / survey tape reels, and art supplies.

Your contribution is greatly appreciated and will be rewarded with some very cool marine-themed items (see Perks on the right)!

The Impact

"In the end we will only conserve what we love; we will only love what we understand, and we will understand only what we are taught." 

~Baba Dioum, 1968

One of the primary goals of this business endeavor is to provide an awareness and understanding of the incredible and fragile resources of the Florida Keys.  This not only includes the coral reef ecosystem, but also the shallow seagrass beds, the mangrove community, and sea turtles - the latter being a species I've worked with intently ever since arriving in the Keys in August of 2006.  As a parent and environmental educator, I firmly believe in the importance of connecting children to nature - there can be a profound impact on both by doing so.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for taking an interest and for supporting my passions:  the ocean and environmental education!  Please help spread the word about this campaign by telling five or more people about it.  A contributor might be a parent with a young child who dreams of being a marine biologist, a fellow educator, an avid scuba diver, or a someone who simply loves the Florida Keys.  For ease, use the Indiegogo Share tools - every little bit helps!  Even with the smallest contribution, I feel the love and support - and it gives you a stake in the success of this endeavor.

Be sure to check out Seaside Explorers' Facebook Page and website for program updates, information about your favorite marine organisms, and photos of the Florida Keys!

www.facebook.com/SeasideExplorers
