underserved communities in Key West and family visitors to the Florida Keys
will be offered targeted programs to learn about the wonders of the sea and
marine conservation.  Exploration and hands-on activities will inspire a love of the ocean and
foster critical-thinking skills.  The idea for
Seaside Explorers LLC came about while working at the NOAA Florida Keys
Eco-Discovery Center as curator of The Living Reef exhibit.  Adult
visitors would often remark that when their child is old enough, he/she could attend a marine biology camp;  children would proclaim
"I am going to be a marine biologist one day!"  From these
conversations I knew that an educational component was missing in the Florida
Keys:  a targeted marine biology program for children on vacation with
their families.
In addition, while
working concurrently as a NOAA Coral Reef Classroom Instructor, I realized that
many local schoolchildren did not have knowledge of the incredible resources in
their own backyards:  the coral reefs of the Florida Keys National Marine
Sanctuary, the third largest barrier reef system in the world.  For this reason, Seaside Explorers will also be providing
programs free of charge to local organizations such as the Boys & Girls
Club.
By providing children with the ability to explore and learn under the guidance of a marine science professional, I hope to ignite a love of science and foster stewardship of our precious marine resources. Please view the Gallery (fifth tab above) for additional photos and information about my previous work in Key West.Getting Started
Although, this business venture and return to Key West will be self-funded in part, funding is needed for various start-up costs.   I am seeking $6,000 - liability insurance, business licenses, a new laptop, and professional services will account for approximately 50% of these costs.  The remainder will be utilized for exploration and craft activities.  Children will a) learn how to identify organisms using field guides, b) record observations and measurements in their very own take-home logbooks, c) test for water temperature and salinity with devices commonly utilized in the field, and d) participate in a host of other activities as part of their marine biologist in-training experience.  Purchases will include various types of nets, magnifying viewers, refractometers (to test salt content of water), digital thermometers, rulers / survey tape reels, and art supplies.Your contribution is greatly appreciated and will be rewarded with some very cool marine-themed items (see Perks on the right)!The Impact
"In the end we will only conserve what we love; we will only love what we understand, and we will understand only what we are taught."  ~Baba Dioum, 1968One of the primary goals of this business endeavor is to provide an awareness and understanding of the incredible and fragile resources of the Florida Keys.  This not only includes the coral reef ecosystem, but also the shallow seagrass beds, the mangrove community, and sea turtles - the latter being a species I've worked with intently ever since arriving in the Keys in August of 2006.  As a parent and environmental educator, I firmly believe in the importance of connecting children to nature - there can be a profound impact on both by doing so.Other Ways You Can HelpThank you for taking an interest and for supporting my passions:  the ocean and environmental education!  Please help spread the word about this campaign by telling five or more people about it.  A contributor might be a parent with a young child who dreams of being a marine biologist, a fellow educator, an avid scuba diver, or a someone who simply loves the Florida Keys.  For ease, use the Indiegogo Share tools - every little bit helps!  Even with the smallest contribution, I feel the love and support - and it gives you a stake in the success of this endeavor. Be sure to check out Seaside Explorers' Facebook Page and website for program updates, information about your favorite marine organisms, and photos of the Florida Keys!www.facebook.com/SeasideExplorers

story:
We are an architect, a designer and a photographer who believe in transformation and design, therefore Transfodesign. We consider that most of the things can be given a second opportunity (be it recycled, up-cycled or reused), and have a purpose, socially and ecologically. Plus, that most of the problems can be solved by design. We promote our concept giving workshops, lectures, events etc, but also by offering projects and products, be it commercial or social. Please visit www.transfodesign.info to find out more.


What is Trashkitchens?


Trashkitchens is a satellite event planned during the BCN Design Festival. The event itself will take place at our shared workshop space, located in the wider center of Barcelona. During two days (15th and 16th of October), five teams   will create mobile kitchens from salvaged material. Each team will predesign the projects and they will need to produce their ideas during the event delivering a fully functional product. Currently, we are in the process of contacting the future participants. But don't worry we will keep you posted on the groups selected.


Our Transfofriends and other design lovers will be able to follow the whole building process, as the event will be open to the public. Additionally, the outstanding, we are absolutely confident they will be, installations will be publicly presented on the 17th of October, when you will  see the kitchens in action and taste the great dishes prepared in them.


UPDATES!

1. We have just finished the website on the event! Please visit it! www.trashkitchens.info

2. We have our first participants: System Design Studio (http://www.systemdesignstudio.com/) and students from the school of design Elisava led by Jose F López-Aguilar

3. Participation also confirmed by Bussoga disseny surreal (http://www.bussoga.com) + Cristina Noguer (http://www.cristinanoguer.com/).

4. Liken Studio (http://www.likenstudio.com/) has also joined in, completing our list of participants!


Why do we think it is important?


People have little knowledge what recycling and reuse of materials can give them, what are the benefits and how it can influence their daily life. Plus we think that mobile kitchens are fun, one can cook in motion. So with Trashkitchens the visitors can get information in an fun and creative way. Showing a design process from the very beginning to the end, is the most direct and personal way of communication. That way the idea that the trash can be converted into good and useful design is easily transmitted. Our ambition is to establish a regular event where creatives will have the opportunity to meet and develop one concept, and explore the many ways the materials can be transformed. 


What We Need & What You Get


Our goal is 6500 US$. It is basically what we need to have this event going. We need this amount in order to:

  • cover travel and accommodation costs for participants living outside BCN

  • provide meals during the event

  • give tools and materials (the few that will not be salvaged)

  • cover logistics and transportation costs

  • have good advertising

  • inaugurate the exhibition of the "trashkitchens"


As we are organizing this event by ourselves, with no public funding, we need your help. And, even if we do not manage to raise here all the money we need, we have all the intention of making this event happen. So other sources are being sought after.


Since you are a good transfofriend, we want to give you something in return, something you will remember us for. So choose your favorite perk and claim it. AND, no matter which perk you choose, you will receive our eternal gratitude.


Bonus


If you help us achieve our goal, all the additional funding will go to MakeaTuVida in order to bring the fantastic exhibition Rehogar to Barcelona. It would be great if we can make a joint display with them. For more information, go here.


Spread the word


Well, the title says it all. Let as many friends possible know about our campaign. We really want to make this event happen. THANK YOU!

story:
You will find an English translation further below.

Voir ci-dessous pour une traduction française.

Перевод на русский язык Вы сможете найти ниже по тексту.

 

Worum geht es diesem Projekt?

Auf einer 3 Hektar großen Pachtfläche in Berlin-Gatow im äußersten Westen Berlins wächst und gedeiht seit Anfang 2013 das Projekt SpeiseGut. Dabei handelt es sich um das erste Berliner Projekt im Rahmen der so genannten „Solidarischen Landwirtschaft“. Die Teilnehmerinnen und Teilnehmer dieser Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft erhalten für einen monatlichen, über ein Jahr festgelegten Beitrag wöchentliche Lieferungen der angebauten Produkte. Obst, Gemüse, Kartoffeln, Kräuter und Blumen wachsen nach strengen ökologischen Richtlinien ausschließlich unter freiem Himmel: regional, ökologisch und verantwortungsvoll, frei von Agrarsubventionen, Gentechnik und dem Einfluss von Großkonzernen.

 

Bei der Ernte wird darauf geachtet, dass alle Produkte unabhängig von Größe, Form und Farbe den Verbraucher erreichen. Zum Vergleich: In der herkömmlichen Landwirtschaft wird bis zur Hälfte des angebauten Obstes und Gemüses schon während der Ernte aussortiert und vernichtet, weil Farbe, Größe oder Form nicht mit den Erwartungen des Großhandels übereinstimmen. Gegen diese verantwortungslose Verschwendung will SpeiseGut ein Zeichen setzen. Für den Erfolg ist SpeiseGut auf die tatkräftige Unterstützung der Teilnehmerinnen und Teilnehmer angewiesen. An mindestens drei Tagen im Jahr sollen sie im Rahmen von Arbeitseinsätzen z. B. jäten, Obst und Gemüse ernten oder Früchte einwecken. Solidarische Landwirtschaft ist auch Mitmach- und Erlebnis-Landwirtschaft, bei der jeder sehen, riechen und fühlen kann, wie das später gegessene Obst und Gemüse wächst und wo es herkommt.

 

Die Mitarbeit ersetzt jedoch nicht die maschinelle Unterstützung, die z. B. zur Pflege des Bodens, zum großflächigen Aussetzen von Kartoffeln usw. erforderlich ist. Damit alle Arbeiten auf dem Acker erledigt werden können, plant SpeiseGut den Kauf eines Schleppers und Beetfräse.

 

Was sind die Ziele und wer ist die Zielgruppe?

Das Ziel ist die Anschaffung eines kleinen Schleppers und einer Beetfräse, um aufwändige bäuerliche Aufgaben schneller und effizienter bearbeiten zu können. Die Erfolgsaussichten des Projekts SpeiseGut werden damit erheblich gesteigert. Davon profitieren alle aktuellen und künftigen Teilnehmerinnen und Teilnehmer der Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft.

 

Warum sollte man diese Projekt unterstützen?

SpeiseGut ist ein Gegenentwurf zur herkömmlichen, subventionsabhängigen Landwirtschaft. Das Projekt ermöglicht den Bezug von regionalem, ökologischem, pestizid- und gentechnikfreiem Obst und Gemüse in Berlin. Ein dauerhafter Erfolg von SpeiseGut kann ein Anreiz für andere Bäuerinnen und Bauern im ganzen Land sein, ebenfalls Solidarische Landwirtschaftsprojekte ins Leben zu rufen.

 

Wieviel Geld brauchen wir, und was passiert damit?

Für unsere geplante Crowdfunding - Aktion benötigen wir etwa 15.000 €. Mit diesem Geld werden wir den Traktor sowie unsere Beetfräse anschaffen können. Wir hoffen, dass wir dann noch etwas Geld übrig haben, um anstehende Wartungen in der nächsten Saison durchführen zu können.


Wer steckt hinter dem Projekt?

Der Initiator und Inhaber des Landwirtschafts- und Gemüsebaubetriebs SpeiseGut ist Christian Heymann. Der gelernte Bauer ist seit 15 Jahren im Öko-Landbau tätig. SpeiseGut ist sein erstes Projekt als Selbstständiger.

 

 

English übersetzt von Stephanie Krießmann

 

SpeiseGut? What is this project about?

The project SpeiseGut thrives and prospers on 2.5 rented acres in the far West of Berlin- Gatow since the beginning of 2013. It is Berlin's first project that uses the concept of "solidary farming". The participants of this economic community receive weekly deliveries of the cultivated products that are generated according to strict ecological guidelines for a monthly fee that is specified for 12 months. Fruit, potatoes and other vegetables, herbs and flowers are produced regionally, ecologically and responsibly.They grow in open air, free from agricultural subsidy, genetic engineering and the influence of conglomerates.

 

When we harvest, we make sure that products of all sizes, forms and colours reach the consumers. For comparison: In conventional agriculture, up to half of the crop is sorted out during the harvesting, because size, colour or form are not according to the standards of wholesale trade. SpeiseGut wants to set an example against this irresponsible waste of food. To be successful, SpeiseGut needs the participants' support. They should help at least 3 days per year by weeding, harvesting fruit and vegetables or by preserving fruit. Solidary Farming is agriculture to experience and to participate in: Everybody can see, smell and feel the fruit and vegetables grow, and knows where they come from.

 

Nevertheless, human participation does not replace the aid of machines, which are needed for taking care of the soil, an extensive planting of potatoes etc.. SpeiseGut is planning to buy a haulier and a rotary cutter so that all work on the land can be done.

 

Aims of the project and its target group:

We want to buy a haulier and a rotary cutter in order to do our agricultural work faster and more efficient. This way, SpeiseGut's prospects of success can be enhanced considerably, and, furthermore, all recent and future participants of our economic community can benefit from this purchase.

 

Why you should support this project:

SpeiseGut is an alternative to conventional farming and agricultural subsidy. The projects offers its participants from Berlin the acquisition of regional, ecological fruit and vegetables that are free from pesticides and not genetically engineered. SpeiseGut's succes could be an inspiration to farmers across the country and Europe to start more projects on solidary farming.

 

How much money do wee need, and what happens with it?

We aim to acquire roundabout 15.000€ via crowdfunding in order to buy a tractor and a rotary cutter. We hope to also have some money left for the maintenance of the machines in the next season.

 

Who is the person behind this project?

Initiator and Owner of SpeiseGut is Christian Heymann. He is a farmer with 15 years of experience in ecological farming. SpeiseGut is his first project as an independent contractor.

 

 

France übersetzt von Yasmine Salimi

 

Quel est l'intérêt de ce projet ?

Sur un terrain sous bail de trois hectares situé à Berlin-Gatow, aux confins de l'ouest de Berlin, le projet SpeiseGut se développe et prospère depuis début 2013. Il s'agit là du premier projet berlinois dans le cadre de la dénommée „agriculture solidaire“. Chaque semaine, les participantes et participants de cette communauté économique sont fournis en produits cultivés, contre une contribution mensuelle fixe s'étendant sur une année. Les fruits, légumes, pommes de terre, herbes et fleurs poussent exclusivement en plein air, en accord avec des règlements écologiques exigeants : une agriculture régionale, écologique et responsable, dépourvue de subventions agricoles, d'OGM et de l'influence de grandes entreprises.

 

Lors de la récolte, nous prenons soin à ce que tous les produits, indépendamment de leur taille, forme et couleur, atteignent le consommateur. En comparaison, dans l'agriculture conventionnelle, jusqu'à la moitié des fruits et légumes cultivés sont déjà triés et détruits lors de la récolte, à cause de leur couleur, taille ou forme qui ne correspond pas aux attentes de la grande distribution. SpeiseGut veut offrir une solution à ce gâchis irresponsable. La réussite de SpeiseGut dépend aussi du soutien actif des participantes et participants. Pendant au moins trois jours dans l'année, ils s'engagent à rejoindre des interventions de sarclage, de récolte de fruits et légumes ou de mise en conserve de fruits. L'agriculture solidaire est aussi une agriculture participative et expérimentée, qui permet à chacun de voir, sentir et éprouver le parcours et l'origine des fruits et légumes dégustés par la suite.

 

La main d'œuvre ne remplace toutefois pas le soutien mécanique, nécessaire notamment à l'entretien du sol, aux plants de pommes de terre étendus etc. Pour pouvoir effectuer tous les travaux sur le terrain, SpeiseGut a prévu l'achat d'un tracteur et d'une fraiseuse de labour.

 

Quels sont les objectifs et quelle est la cible visée ?

L'objectif est l'acquisition d'un petit tracteur et d'une fraiseuse de labour afin de rendre les travaux fermiers exigeants plus rapides et efficaces. Cela ferait considérablement augmenter les chances de réussite du projet SpeiseGut. Tous les futurs et actuels participantes et participants de la communauté économique en profitent.

 

Pourquoi soutenir ce projet ?

SpeiseGut est une alternative à l'agriculture conventionnelle, dépendante de subventions. Le projet permet d'avoir accès à des fruits et légumes écologiques sans pesticides et OGM à Berlin. Un succès à long terme du projet SpeiseGut peut motiver d'autres agricultrices et agriculteurs dans l'ensemble du pays à initier à leur tour des projets d'agriculture solidaire.

 

Combien d'argent nous faut-il, et qu'allons-nous en faire ?

Pour notre projet de production communautaire avisé, il nous faut approximativement 15.000 €. À l'aide de cet argent, nous allons pouvoir acquérir le tracteur ainsi que notre fraiseuse de labour. Nous espérons qu'il restera de quoi payer la maintenance des appareils pour la saison prochaine.

 

Qui est responsable du projet ?

L'initiateur et le propriétaire de l'entreprise agricole et légumière SpeiseGut s'appelle Christian Heymann. Il est agriculteur de formation et actif dans l'agriculture biologique depuis 15 ans. SpeiseGut est le premier projet à son compte.

Russisch übersetzt von Maryna Schröter

О чём этот проект?

На арендуемой площади размером в 3 гектара, на окраине западного Берлина (Берлин-Гатов), с начала 2013 года реализуется проект «SpeiseGut» (досл. перевод – «питайся хорошо»). Речь идёт о так называемом «Солидарном сельском хозяйстве». «SpeiseGut» является самым первым проектом такого рода в Берлине. Участники этого сообщества за определённую месячную плату на протяжении всего года еженедельно получают продукцию, выращиваемую на этих землях. Фрукты, овощи, картофель, зелень и цветы выращивают строго по экологическим технологиям, без применения ГМО, и исключительно под открытым небом. Проектом не предусмотрено использование аграрных субсидий и связей с крупными корпорациями. Наш девиз: обеспечение потребителя региональной и экологически чистой продукцией.

Особое внимание при сборе урожая уделяется тому, чтобы все продукты независимо от их величины, формы и цвета достигли потребителя. Для сравнения: в традиционном сельском хозяйстве почти половина всех выращенных овощей и фруктов отсортировывается и уничтожается (выбрасывается) ещё во время сбора урожая, из-за того что их цвет, размер или форма не соответствуют стандартам оптовой торговли. «SpeiseGut» абсолютно против такого безответственного расточительства. Успех этого проекта во многом зависит от активной поддержки его участников, которые должны 3 дня в году, принять участие в процессе выращивания, уборки овощей и фруктов, а также их переработки (консервация). Солидарное сельское хозяйство предусматривает не только работу, но и является местом для новых интересных встреч, общений, ощущений. Место, где каждый может увидеть и узнать, как выращиваются овощи и фрукты, понюхать и потрогать их.

Но поддержка со стороны участников, конечно, не может заменить применение сельскохозяйственной техники, которая необходима, к примеру, для обработки почвы, для высадки картофеля и т.п. Для выполнения сельскохозяйственных работ большого масштаба «SpeiseGut» планирует приобрести трактор-тягач и машину для вспашки.

Цели сбора средств и куда они будут направлены?

Целью является приобретение маленького трактора-тягача и пахотной машины, подготавливающей почву к посадкам, которые помогут быстрее и эффективнее выполнять сельскохозяйственные работы. Таким образом шансы на успех проекта «SpeiseGut» значительно увеличатся. Отсюда извлекут выгоду не только настоящие, но и будущие участники этого сообщества.

Почему нужно поддержать этот проект?

«SpeiseGut» - является инициативой абсолютно противоположной по своему характеру традиционному сельскому хозяйству, полностью зависящему от государственных субсидий. Этот проект позволяет получать региональную и экологически чистую (без применения пестицидов и ГМО) продукцию в пределах Берлина. Продолжительный успех проекта «SpeiseGut» сможет стать примером для других сельскохозяйственных производителей (фермеров) по всей стране, стартовать подобные проекты по солидарному сельскому хозяйству.

You will find an English translation further below.
Voir ci-dessous pour une traduction française.
Перевод на русский язык Вы сможете найти ниже по тексту.

Was sind die Ziele und wer ist die Zielgruppe?
Das Ziel ist die Anschaffung eines kleinen Schleppers und einer Beetfräse, um aufwändige bäuerliche Aufgaben schneller und effizienter bearbeiten zu können. Die Erfolgsaussichten des Projekts SpeiseGut werden damit erheblich gesteigert. Davon profitieren alle aktuellen und künftigen Teilnehmerinnen und Teilnehmer der Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft. 
 
Warum sollte man diese Projekt unterstützen?
SpeiseGut ist ein Gegenentwurf zur herkömmlichen, subventionsabhängigen Landwirtschaft. Das Projekt ermöglicht den Bezug von regionalem, ökologischem, pestizid- und gentechnikfreiem Obst und Gemüse in Berlin. Ein dauerhafter Erfolg von SpeiseGut kann ein Anreiz für andere Bäuerinnen und Bauern im ganzen Land sein, ebenfalls Solidarische Landwirtschaftsprojekte ins Leben zu rufen.
 
Wieviel Geld brauchen wir, und was passiert damit?Für unsere geplante Crowdfunding - Aktion benötigen wir etwa 15.000 €. Mit diesem Geld werden wir den Traktor sowie unsere Beetfräse anschaffen können. Wir hoffen, dass wir dann noch etwas Geld übrig haben, um anstehende Wartungen in der nächsten Saison durchführen zu können.
Wer steckt hinter dem Projekt?
Der Initiator und Inhaber des Landwirtschafts- und Gemüsebaubetriebs SpeiseGut ist Christian Heymann. Der gelernte Bauer ist seit 15 Jahren im Öko-Landbau tätig. SpeiseGut ist sein erstes Projekt als Selbstständiger.
 
 
English übersetzt von Stephanie Krießmann
 
SpeiseGut? What is this project about?
The project SpeiseGut thrives and prospers on 2.5 rented acres in the far West of Berlin- Gatow since the beginning of 2013. It is Berlin's first project that uses the concept of "solidary farming". The participants of this economic community receive weekly deliveries of the cultivated products that are generated according to strict ecological guidelines for a monthly fee that is specified for 12 months. Fruit, potatoes and other vegetables, herbs and flowers are produced regionally, ecologically and responsibly.They grow in open air, free from agricultural subsidy, genetic engineering and the influence of conglomerates.
 
When we harvest, we make sure that products of all sizes, forms and colours reach the consumers. For comparison: In conventional agriculture, up to half of the crop is sorted out during the harvesting, because size, colour or form are not according to the standards of wholesale trade. SpeiseGut wants to set an example against this irresponsible waste of food. To be successful, SpeiseGut needs the participants' support. They should help at least 3 days per year by weeding, harvesting fruit and vegetables or by preserving fruit. Solidary Farming is agriculture to experience and to participate in: Everybody can see, smell and feel the fruit and vegetables grow, and knows where they come from.
 
Nevertheless, human participation does not replace the aid of machines, which are needed for taking care of the soil, an extensive planting of potatoes etc.. SpeiseGut is planning to buy a haulier and a rotary cutter so that all work on the land can be done.
 
Aims of the project and its target group:
We want to buy a haulier and a rotary cutter in order to do our agricultural work faster and more efficient. This way, SpeiseGut's prospects of success can be enhanced considerably, and, furthermore, all recent and future participants of our economic community can benefit from this purchase.
 
Why you should support this project: 
SpeiseGut is an alternative to conventional farming and agricultural subsidy. The projects offers its participants from Berlin the acquisition of regional, ecological fruit and vegetables that are free from pesticides and not genetically engineered. SpeiseGut's succes could be an inspiration to farmers across the country and Europe to start more projects on solidary farming.
 
How much money do wee need, and what happens with it?
We aim to acquire roundabout 15.000€ via crowdfunding in order to buy a tractor and a rotary cutter. We hope to also have some money left for the maintenance of the machines in the next season.
 
Who is the person behind this project?
Initiator and Owner of SpeiseGut is Christian Heymann. He is a farmer with 15 years of experience in ecological farming. SpeiseGut is his first project as an independent contractor.
 
 
France übersetzt von Yasmine Salimi
 
Quel est l'intérêt de ce projet ?
Sur un terrain sous bail de trois hectares situé à Berlin-Gatow, aux confins de l'ouest de Berlin, le projet SpeiseGut se développe et prospère depuis début 2013. Il s'agit là du premier projet berlinois dans le cadre de la dénommée „agriculture solidaire“. Chaque semaine, les participantes et participants de cette communauté économique sont fournis en produits cultivés, contre une contribution mensuelle fixe s'étendant sur une année. Les fruits, légumes, pommes de terre, herbes et fleurs poussent exclusivement en plein air, en accord avec des règlements écologiques exigeants : une agriculture régionale, écologique et responsable, dépourvue de subventions agricoles, d'OGM et de l'influence de grandes entreprises.
 
Lors de la récolte, nous prenons soin à ce que tous les produits, indépendamment de leur taille, forme et couleur, atteignent le consommateur. En comparaison, dans l'agriculture conventionnelle, jusqu'à la moitié des fruits et légumes cultivés sont déjà triés et détruits lors de la récolte, à cause de leur couleur, taille ou forme qui ne correspond pas aux attentes de la grande distribution. SpeiseGut veut offrir une solution à ce gâchis irresponsable. La réussite de SpeiseGut dépend aussi du soutien actif des participantes et participants. Pendant au moins trois jours dans l'année, ils s'engagent à rejoindre des interventions de sarclage, de récolte de fruits et légumes ou de mise en conserve de fruits. L'agriculture solidaire est aussi une agriculture participative et expérimentée, qui permet à chacun de voir, sentir et éprouver le parcours et l'origine des fruits et légumes dégustés par la suite.
 
La main d'œuvre ne remplace toutefois pas le soutien mécanique, nécessaire notamment à l'entretien du sol, aux plants de pommes de terre étendus etc. Pour pouvoir effectuer tous les travaux sur le terrain, SpeiseGut a prévu l'achat d'un tracteur et d'une fraiseuse de labour.
 
Quels sont les objectifs et quelle est la cible visée ?
L'objectif est l'acquisition d'un petit tracteur et d'une fraiseuse de labour afin de rendre les travaux fermiers exigeants plus rapides et efficaces. Cela ferait considérablement augmenter les chances de réussite du projet SpeiseGut. Tous les futurs et actuels participantes et participants de la communauté économique en profitent. 
 
Pourquoi soutenir ce projet ?
SpeiseGut est une alternative à l'agriculture conventionnelle, dépendante de subventions. Le projet permet d'avoir accès à des fruits et légumes écologiques sans pesticides et OGM à Berlin. Un succès à long terme du projet SpeiseGut peut motiver d'autres agricultrices et agriculteurs dans l'ensemble du pays à initier à leur tour des projets d'agriculture solidaire.
 
Combien d'argent nous faut-il, et qu'allons-nous en faire ?
Pour notre projet de production communautaire avisé, il nous faut approximativement 15.000 €. À l'aide de cet argent, nous allons pouvoir acquérir le tracteur ainsi que notre fraiseuse de labour. Nous espérons qu'il restera de quoi payer la maintenance des appareils pour la saison prochaine.
 
Qui est responsable du projet ?
L'initiateur et le propriétaire de l'entreprise agricole et légumière SpeiseGut s'appelle Christian Heymann. Il est agriculteur de formation et actif dans l'agriculture biologique depuis 15 ans. SpeiseGut est le premier projet à son compte. 
Russisch übersetzt von Maryna Schröter
О чём этот проект?
На арендуемой площади размером в 3 гектара, на окраине западного Берлина (Берлин-Гатов), с начала 2013 года реализуется проект «SpeiseGut» (досл. перевод – «питайся хорошо»). Речь идёт о так называемом «Солидарном сельском хозяйстве». «SpeiseGut» является самым первым проектом такого рода в Берлине. Участники этого сообщества за определённую месячную плату на протяжении всего года еженедельно получают продукцию, выращиваемую на этих землях. Фрукты, овощи, картофель, зелень и цветы выращивают строго по экологическим технологиям, без применения ГМО, и исключительно под открытым небом. Проектом не предусмотрено использование аграрных субсидий и связей с крупными корпорациями. Наш девиз: обеспечение потребителя региональной и экологически чистой продукцией.
Особое внимание при сборе урожая уделяется тому, чтобы все продукты независимо от их величины, формы и цвета достигли потребителя. Для сравнения: в традиционном сельском хозяйстве почти половина всех выращенных овощей и фруктов отсортировывается и уничтожается (выбрасывается) ещё во время сбора урожая, из-за того что их цвет, размер или форма не соответствуют стандартам оптовой торговли. «SpeiseGut» абсолютно против такого безответственного расточительства. Успех этого проекта во многом зависит от активной поддержки его участников, которые должны 3 дня в году, принять участие в процессе выращивания, уборки овощей и фруктов, а также их переработки (консервация). Солидарное сельское хозяйство предусматривает не только работу, но и является местом для новых интересных встреч, общений, ощущений. Место, где каждый может увидеть и узнать, как выращиваются овощи и фрукты, понюхать и потрогать их. 
Но поддержка со стороны участников, конечно, не может заменить применение сельскохозяйственной техники, которая необходима, к примеру, для обработки почвы, для высадки картофеля и т.п. Для выполнения сельскохозяйственных работ большого масштаба «SpeiseGut» планирует приобрести трактор-тягач и машину для вспашки.
Цели сбора средств и куда они будут направлены?
Целью является приобретение маленького трактора-тягача и пахотной машины, подготавливающей почву к посадкам, которые помогут быстрее и эффективнее выполнять сельскохозяйственные работы. Таким образом шансы на успех проекта «SpeiseGut» значительно увеличатся. Отсюда извлекут выгоду не только настоящие, но и будущие участники этого сообщества.
Почему нужно поддержать этот проект?
«SpeiseGut» - является инициативой абсолютно противоположной по своему характеру традиционному сельскому хозяйству, полностью зависящему от государственных субсидий. Этот проект позволяет получать региональную и экологически чистую (без применения пестицидов и ГМО) продукцию в пределах Берлина. Продолжительный успех проекта «SpeiseGut» сможет стать примером для других сельскохозяйственных производителей (фермеров) по всей стране, стартовать подобные проекты по солидарному сельскому хозяйству.

story:
-> Eine Deutsche Textversion ist weiter unten abgedruckt.

25 million bamboo trees

Our goal:

We want to plant 1,500 bamboo saplings by spring 2014, laying the foundations for a bamboo forest of 25 million bamboo trees – a real powerhouse and an almost inexhaustible green resource. With the additional resources of raw materials, we will be able to launch the Kissed by Bamboo  Bamboo Health & Beauty Drink
for consumers by Spring 2014.

 

Sustainable economy:

Over the past 2 years, we have built a bamboo factory at our site in Wuyishan. There, we extract highly-effective anti-inflammatory bamboo extracts for the cosmetics, pharmaceutical and nutritional industries from our organic bamboo.

Bamboo Power:

Bamboo plants are interconnected via their roots. Generations of trees join to create a forest – a rapidly-growing, mythical place of power. Fascinated by this energy, in 2010 Patrick Neuenschwander and I decided to invest all of our wealth and entrepreneurship in becoming bamboo producers. Since then, we have been chasing the business idea of using our own organically-certified bamboo forest to produce leaves for the extraction of bamboo essences. Bamboo extracts have a very strong anti-inflammatory effect and are therefore a very interesting raw material for the cosmetics, pharmaceutical and nutritional industries.

Venture:

This spring, after a 2-year test period and with the help of investors, our bamboo factory began operations at the foot of our own small organically-certified bamboo forest (50 hectares) in Wuyishan (China). Using organic bamboo extracts and following intensive self-testing (www.selbstversuche.ch), we have developed a unique health and beauty drink. Bamboo leaf extracts contain innumerable ingredients which mean that our bamboo drink has an anti-inflammatory effect and strengthens the body from within.
The development of our production means that our Need for organically-certified bamboo leaves has increased. We also want to continue to harvest our raw materials sustainably and to be able to trace each leaf directly back to its origin in the forest. We are launching this Indiegogo campaign to attract capital and commitment for our vision.

Be part of an amazing story!

Christian Gerig
Co-Founder Organic Bamboo Industries Ltd.

 

Production Procedure: Bamboo Extracts

Step 1: Cutting the Bamboo

 

Step 2: Picking the leaves

 

Step 3: Drying the leaves

 

Step 4: Extract the Bamboo Serum

Our forest and the production of the bamboo extracts are certified organic by IMO
according to the EU and NOP organic standard.

               

 

 

 Deutsche Übersetzung:

25 Mio. Bambusbäume

Unser Ziel: Wir wollen im Frühling 2014 1’500 Bambussetzlinge pflanzen und so den Grundstein für einen Bambuswald mit 25 Mio. Bambusbäumen legen – ein wahres Power-House und eine fast unerschöpfliche grüne Ressource. Mit den zusätzlichen Ressourcen an Rohmaterial können wir bis Frühling 2014 den Bamboo Health & Beauty Drink Kissed by Bamboo™ für Endkonsumenten lancieren.

Nachhaltige Ökonomie: In den letzten 2 Jahren haben wir an unserem Standort in WuYiShan eine Bambusfabrik aufgebaut. In dieser Fabrik extrahieren wir aus unserem Bio-Bambus hochwirksame, entzündungshemmende Bambusextrakte für die Kosmetik-, Pharma- und Lebensmittelindustrie

Bambus Power: Bambuspflanzen sind über das Wurzelwerk vernetzt. Generationen von Bäumen verbinden sich zu einem Wald – einem schnell wachsenden, mythischen Kraftort. Fasziniert von dieser Energie entschieden sich Patrick Neuenschwander und ich 2010 dazu, unser gesamtes Vermögen und Unternehmerherz dafür zu investieren, Bambusfabrikanten zu werden. Seither verfolgen wir die Geschäftsidee, aus dem eigenen biozertifizierten Bambuswald Blätter für die Extraktion von Bambusessenzen zu gewinnen. Bambusextrakte wirken stark entzündungshemmend und sind deshalb ein hoch interessanter Rohstoff für die Kosmetik-, Pharma- und Lebensmittelindustrie.

Unternehmung: In diesem Frühjahr ging nach 2-jähriger Pionierphase mit der Hilfe von Investoren direkt am Fuss des firmeneigenen kleinen biozertifizierten Bambuswaldes (50 ha) in WuYiShan (China) unsere Bambusfabrik in Betrieb. Auf Basis der Bio-Bambusextrakte haben wir nach intensiven Selbstversuchen (www.selbstversuche.ch) einen einmaligen Gesundheits- und Beautydrink entwickelt. Im Bambusblattextrakt kommen unzählige Wirkstoffe vor, die dazu führen, dass unser Bambusdrink entzündungshemmend wirkt und den Körper von innen heraus stärkt.

Mit dem Ausbau unserer Produktion steigt unser Bedarf an biozertifizierten Bambusblättern. Wir wollen auch weiterhin unsere Rohstoffe nachhaltig ernten und jedes Blatt lückenlos bis zum Ursprung im Wald zurückverfolgen können. Wir lanciere diese Indiegogo-Kampagne um für unsere Vision Kapital und Herzblut zu sammeln. Werde Teil einer grossartigen Geschichte!

Christian Gerig
Co-Founder Organic Bamboo Industries Ltd.

Christian GerigCo-Founder Organic Bamboo Industries Ltd.

story:
Pedicab Pisa, our clean energy project is at risk of shut-down.

Pedicab Pisa is the first and only ecological-tourism service in Pisa, a project born and driven by the will to propose a new resource, a new way to live the city and the urge of creating a job for ourselves. A kind of enterprise already present in the most important cities of the World since decades. A dream that risks to end despite our efforts.

It's been three years since we, Roberto (pedicab driver) and Gianni (photographer and graphic designer, graduate in Foreign Languages) both unemployed, began this adventure. We invested every resource at our disposal, succeeding in buying our first rickshaw e winning the battle against bureaucracy to obtain permissions. We have been dealing with technical, logistical and bureaucratic problems by ourselves, despite the economical crisis and the absence of help by institutions. We began the experimentation of the project working for free or by tips and we immediately received a positive and strong feedback, great beyond our expectations.

Our Eco-Tour aimed at the discovery of the cultural and artistic treasures of the city of Pisa has been enthusiastically appreciated by thousands of tourists from all over the World. The project has been completely supported and encouraged by citizens, by retailers, by the press and the Internet, as well as numerous sponsors we still thank for the precious help they are giving us. Determined to create a collaboration between the restaurants and enterprises of the city center, we extended the project creating a illustrated guide aimed at the discovery of the legendary heritage of the city, its typical products and food.

Many of the tourists who tried our Eco-Tour stayed longer in the city, more than they programmed, instead of traveling somewhere else once they had visited the Leaning Tower. We are an example of how good initiatives can improve the economy of a city, step by step.

However, because of serious economical problems and the absence of a necessary help by institutions, the future of the project is uncertain. We can't afford any more the maintenance expenses for the vehicle (there are no rickshaw factories in Italy), for a place to safely keep it, to pay our home rent and we are risking eviction. We risk to lose what we managed to achieve so far just for a few (2-3) thousands of Euros, necessary to carry on with the project.

We have no clue on how to go on and we risk to lose a valuable chance to create an occupation. If we weren't left all by ourselves dealing with all these problems, today we could have been offering a job to other people too.

This is why we're asking for a concrete help by Institutions.

We address this letter to our fellow citizen Italian Prime Minister Enrico Letta, to Regional Government President of Tuscany Enrico Rossi, to Major of Pisa Marco Filippeschi and anybody who wishes to help us.

We have a strong will to work, to propose initiatives, to offer our potential.

We firmly believe in our project and we just don't want to give up.

We are looking for and we welcome the collaboration of anybody who wishes to help us making our dream come true with a free donation or simply helping us sharing our campaign.

www.pedicabpisa.it/Donazione.aspx

www.facebook.com/PedicabPisa

www.twitter.com/PedicabPisa

Roberto Alberti and Gianni Lo Piccolo

Pedicab Pisa

story:
9 years ago a small seed was planted in Rosia Montana: can music spark a revolution?

FânFest is the biggest multi-art activist festival in Romania. 

It started with the battle to stop the largest gold mine in Europe and grew to be the epicenter of one of the biggest civil and environmental movements in Eastern Europe.

This tiny village in the Apuseni Mountains in Transylvania has captured the imagination and hearts of people from across the world who come to FânFest to enjoy music, exhibitions, theater, dance, workshops, debates and express solidarity with the campaign to save Roșia Montană.

Between 11-17 August 2014 people will come to Roșia Montană to discover the beautiful heritage here and the sustainable development alternatives for the area: tourism, local crafts and traditional farming.

What is Roșia Montană?

The small village of Roșia Montană is inhabited since pre-Roman times, making it the oldest documented mining settlement in Romania and the continent's largest gold deposit. It is also one of the seven 'most endangered' European cultural sites, meeting 4 UNESCO criteria of highly importance for our World Heritage. But most important of all, it is a quiet place with warm-hearted people who risk irreversible damage upon their ancestral land, in exchange for short-term profits.

Why it matters

Since 2000, year after year, dedicated „Save Roșia Montană” campaigners managed to stop the illegal and controversial cyanide mining project by taking action in courts of law, among others. Things changed last autumn, when politicians tried to pass a law that would give Rosia Montana Gold Corporation extraordinary powers, including  the right to conduct expropriations in Rosia Montana, divert rivers and create the largest cyanide tailing pond in Europe.

Few expected the massive street protests which followed, with people flooding the streets and chanting „United, we save, Roșia Montană”. Romania's biggest civil and environmental uprising in a century quickly went global, spreading throughout 75 cities worldwide, from Bucharest to London and New York to Shanghai.

The movement has seen dozens of artistic projects launched, from the creation of a collective canvas bringing together pieces from around the world, to live performances, film screenings, exhibitions and a human chain around the 4th largest building in the world (the Romanian Parliament).

Who are we and what have we achieved?

  • FânFest is organised by Alburnus Maior NGO through the work of the locals of Rosia Montana and hundreds of volunteers from across Romania.

  • FânFest kick-started one of the fastest growing and most vibrant environmental movements in the last decade in Eastern Europe.

  • FânFest transformed a small community in the Apuseni Mountains in the number one destination for those who love art and culture, nature, heritage and those who stand for justice and human rights.

  • FânFest is proof that sustainable development alternatives can help a community to flourish and its people to thrive.

  • FânFest is the host of the largest Activist Social Forum in Romania where participants from around the world learn, teach, develop strategies, plan tactics for campaigns that make the world a better place.

  • FânFest inspired an entire generation of artists, academics, activists and people from all over the world to volunteer and work together to protect our cultural and natural heritage.



9 years of FânFest history

The festival is organized entirely by volunteers. Organizers, artists, guests participate pro bono and the participants have FREE access to all the FânFest events.

Every year, FânFest has brought between 5,000-15,000 people to Roșia Montană,  In 9 years, FânFest has made possible...

  • 1000s concerts, dance and theatre performances
  • 100s of hands-on restoration workshops
  • 1000s of games for kids and grownups
  • 1000s of film screenings, exhibitions, poetry nights
  • 100s of performances and DJs
  • 100s of debates, presentations and workshops about creativity, activism, sustainability and more
  • 1000s of walks, hikes and tours of Rosia Montana, one of the oldest settlements in Transylvania
  • 100s of outdoor activities from slack-lining to skydiving

FânFest is set across dozens of different locations in the mountain village of Rosia Montana, from lush meadows, to historical houses and churches, parks and the windy streets of this beautiful mountain village. 

How your donations help FânFest

  •   Accommodation for our guests  €750
  •   Food for our 150+ volunteers and guests  €1200
  •   Simultaneous interpretation equipment  €960
  •   Festival tents renting costs  €1400
  •   Other infrastructure costs (generators, eco-toilets, man-made showers, waste management)  €1690
  • Indiegogo fees €440

So far we have raised money to pay for the stage, the sound system and part of the transport costs for our guests. Donations which exceed the target will be used to cover the transport costs for the artists, the second biggest cost for the festival. 

We need you to make the 9th edition happen. Please donate.

Together, we will grow the revolution!


and here are the perks...


The perks will be sent out to you in the first week after the end of the campaign, which finishes on July 26, 2014. (we'll get in touch with those who claimed The Tour, The Hero and The Visit to make all the arrangements)

story:
Summary

Last year in London Vandana Shiva announced the creation of “Seed Festivals” around the world to liberalise the seeds and to generate awareness of the importance of the seeds for our food and health.

Jointly with London, Warsaw, Athens and Amsterdam, the Urban Ecology Centre  supported by Demeter International and many local partners are coordinating the "Zaden Festival des Graines" (Seed Festival) in Brussels, Belgium. You can participate in this event on the 11/12 October 2014 at the Forum du Campus de la Plaine of the Université Libre Bruxelles (the Free Univesity Brussels) and support us by donation.

We will organise a special organic dinner for all the donors at the festival!

What We Need & What You Get

This festival unites academics and NGOs as well as local citizens to save or liberate seeds, to exchange them, to learn how to become personally and practically engaged, and to simplify reproduction and commercialisation. We want to show the crucial importance of seeds for life, nutrition and health. We need to push for freedom of seeds related to patents and intellectual property rights. We want to create agriculture in harmony with Nature, not using any GMOs.
By supporting our festival you participate in the initiation of the Brussels Free Seed Bank, modelled upon the existing London Seed Bank! We will also send you varied free seeds in exchange!

The Impact

The Festival will engage breeders, farmers, gardeners, entrepreneurs, citizens and NGOs to raise awareness of, and to celebrate the importance of, Open-pollinated Seeds for our food and health as well as for biodiversity. Our message : let us sow seeds to create hope and a system of greater justice and health, based on multi-local markets and a better and sustainable environment now and for future generations.

Challenges to face

The Festival will combine dance, music, art, exchange of seeds, seed-breeding and plant-growing workshops, discussions and exhibitions of sustainable projects around seeds, farming with food and cookery… We want to discuss the practical implementation of 30% ecological seeds and farming by the year 2030, as well as the impact of the Free Trade Agreement between the EU and the US for food and health on a local, regional, European or worldwide level. You can be part of this change!

Other Ways You Can Help

Your attendance is essential whether in the capacity of an individual and/or as part of an organisation. We invite you to present your projects and activities, your products and ideas and to participate in the discussions.

You can also help simply by sharing this campaign with people in your networks!

www.zadenfestival.be

story:
If our current level of overfishing continues, the fish we eat today could disappear within our own lifetime, Which is a big problem because approximately a billion people rely on fish as their primary source of food! (Bell, 11/20/13) As young high school students, we have realized that we are the missing link to saving our oceans. As many aquatic species, the Coho salmon's population has been declining rapidly right in our own backyard. Due to our current fishing practices, the Coho population has become more vulnerable than ever before. In the last 50 years commercial fishing in lakes and rivers has quadrupled. (Bell, 11/20/13)

Please donate today to help preserve the fragile ecosystem our Coho live in. We plan to give 100% of your donations to the Salmon Protection and Watershed Network (SPAWN), a non-profit organization in Marin dedicated to helping protect the Coho. Through restoration projects, campaigning, and education your donation will help save our Coho salmon before it's too late!! 

***Sidenote: If possible, please sign our petition (link below), to send to administrator of NOAA Dr, Kathryn Sullivan to start enforcing stricter regulations on fishing limits from commercial vessels! https://www.change.org/p/dr-kathryn-sullivan-cr...

story:
Greenpeace International has generously funded subsidized ticket prices, offering us a more affordable bus at a fraction of the original price. However, we still have to meet our fund-raising goal to fulfill our end of the bargain: $4000, not $1000!! We have to raise 400% of our original goal! Help make this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to effect real change accessible to Oles, Carls, and the Northfield Community!

from the organizers:

This is an invitation to change everything.

In September, world leaders are coming to New York City for a UN summit on the climate crisis. UN Secretary­ General Ban Ki-­moon is urging governments to support an ambitious global agreement to dramatically reduce global warming pollution.

With our future on the line and the whole world watching, we’ll take a stand to bend the course of history. We’ll take to the streets to demand the world we know is within our reach: a world with an economy that works for people and the planet; a world safe from the ravages of climate change; a world with good jobs, clean air and water, and healthy communities.

To change everything, we need everyone on board.
Sunday, September 21 in New York City. Join us.

SIGN UP NOW

THE PLAN FOR THE PEOPLE'S CLIMATE MARCH

The March - 11:30 am, Sunday, September 21st

Assembly location: the area north of Columbus Circle.

March Route:

    • The march will begin at 11:30 am.
    • leave Columbus Circle and go east on 59th Street
    • turn onto 6th Ave. and go south to 42nd Street
    • turn right onto 42nd Street and go west to 11th Ave
    • turn left on 11th Ave. and go south to 34th Street

End Location: 11th Ave. in the streets between 34th Street and 38th Street

story:
Migratory birds connect us all. As these remarkable travelers navigate migration routes throughout the globe, they connect people across countries, cultures, and even hemispheres.

Alarmingly, many migratory birds are in decline, a clear signal of the worsening health of the ecological systems that support life on earth.

Klamath Bird Observatory, a scientific non-profit organization based in southern Oregon, has developed an award-winning science-based conservation model that improves conditions for migratory birds. Now, we need your support to build a dedicated community of conservationists who will apply our successful, science-based model throughout the world!

The Klamath Bird Observatory internship program provides mentorship and expert instruction in applied conservation science techniques, including bird survey methodologies, to early-career conservation scientists. These motivated student-interns develop the personal and professional skills they need to excel in to the future as conservation leaders.

Your support will help fund a Klamath Bird Observatory intern for six months, including living stipend, housing, equipment and learning tools, mentor support, and transportation during the field season.

Through your generosity, we can continue to strengthen the safety net for migratory birds, identifying and addressing needs on their breeding grounds, migratory stopover sites, and wintering locations.

Together, we can keep aloft the miraculous migratory birds that delight us, inspire us, connect us together, and serve as an accurate measure of the health of our land, air, and waters. Join us today!

A History of Success

Klamath Bird Observatory’s illustrious early-career training program has graduated over 170 bird monitoring interns from 18 different countries, including Argentina, Australia, Belize, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ethiopia, Holland, Hungary, Jamaica, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, Spain, Trinidad & Tobago, United Kingdom, and the United States. Many of these individuals have gone on to achieve advanced degrees and develop conservation capacity in areas where it is needed most. For example:

  • Luis Morales of Mexico interned with Klamath Bird Observatory in 2012. At that time he was laying the foundation for a new bird observatory in his native San Pancho, Nayarit, located on the Pacific coast of Mexico. The San Pancho Bird Observatory is now a healthy and growing organization advancing bird conservation and education in western Mexico, where many of our nesting songbirds spend their winters.
  • Mauricio Lewis and Diego Garcia of Peru, and Andres Henao and Miguel Moreno of Colombia, all became certified by the North America Banding Council as expert bird banders and banding trainers during their KBO internships. Each of them now sponsors and participates in training workshops held throughout Mexico and Central and South America, reaching dozens of new students and potential conservationists each year.
  • Carl Fitzjames, a community leader from Brasso Secco in Trinidad and Tobago, participated in the KBO internship program and then returned to his home as one of the few certified bird banders in his country. Carl now works with the University of the West Indies to support applied research studies being implemented by professors and graduate students. Such studies are increasing the awareness and protection of wetlands that are important for resident and migratory birds. Carl also works with the US Embassy to present education programs for small communities and school groups.

These former Klamath Bird Observatory student-interns embody the leadership qualities of our interns and demonstrate the sustained and far-reaching influence of KBO’s international capacity building and training programs. 

Please help us strengthen this essential conservation training program with a donation today!

About Klamath Bird Observatory

Klamath Bird Observatory is a scientific non-profit organization that achieves bird conservation in the Pacific Northwest and throughout the migratory ranges of the birds of our region. We developed our award-winning conservation model in the ruggedly beautiful and wildlife rich Klamath-Siskiyou Bioregion of southern Oregon and northern California, and we now apply this model more broadly to care for our shared birds throughout their annual cycles. Emphasizing high caliber science and the role of birds as indicators of the health of the land, we specialize in cost-effective bird monitoring and research projects that improve natural resource management. Also, recognizing that conservation occurs across many fronts, we nurture a conservation ethic in our communities through our outreach and educational programs. We owe our success to committed donors, volunteers, staff, and conservation partners who demonstrate that each of us can contribute to a legacy of abundant bird populations and healthy land, air, and water.

Birds are indicators of the environment. If they are in trouble, we know we’ll soon be in trouble. – Roger Tory Peterson

Help Us By Making Some Noise!

Please help us spread the word about this campaign by telling your friends, family, and colleagues through social media. Thanks for your commitment to birds and our beautiful planet!

Thank you to the photographers that have helped this campaign for migratory birds. Photograph credits: Jim Livaudais, Melody Noraas, Graham Lewis, Amos Butler Audubon Society, and Klamath Bird Observatory.

Klamath Bird Observatory has made every effort to acquire proper permissions for the photos used in the video and website for this campaign. If you have any questions or concerns about the images, please contact Klamath Bird Observatory (kbo AT klamathbird.org). Music used in our campaign video is royalty-free through iMovie.

story:
Sow a SEED of Hope Today!

The Shipibo Ecosocial Entrepreneurship Diploma (SEED) is supporting indigenous communities of the Peruvian Amazon to regenerate their environment using Permaculture.


Our grassroots initiative aims to restore the Rainforest's vibrant culture, flourishing biodiversity and health, while co-creating sustainable livelihoods with the people who live there. This is a regenerative social movement based on nurturing a paradigm of abundance and prosperity to defend the “lungs of the Earth” and create resilience in the face of climate change.

Donate & share this campaign with your friends and family today!

Who We Are

Alianza Arkana is a Peruvian NGO with nearly 3 years of experience successfully implementing community-based projects in the areas of environmental justice and human rights, sustainable waste management, and intercultural education. This program will be implemented with leadership from 3 Shipibo communities and in partnership with our sister NGO, the Chaikuni Institute of Permaculture.

The Shipibo are an indigenous people who live on the Ucayali River, a main tributary of the Amazon. They are famed artisans and healers and traditionally were skilled hunters, gatherers, and subsistence agriculturalists - but they are now facing the challenges of a deteriorated forest, pollution, and ensuing economic pressures.

Together, we are crafting a community-led model of eco-social abundance rooted in Permaculture and indigenous wisdom. Permaculture is an ethical design science that creates regenerative and resilient habitats by mimicking the patterns and processes found in nature - in essence it is human ingenuity wedded to the wisdom of the wild. Permaculture teaches us that by taking care of the Earth, the people, and the future we can help to create a world of abundance and regeneration. Indigenous wisdom teaches the same. By integrating the two, we are creating lasting and positive change in the Amazon for generations to come.

What We Do And How You Can Help

After decades of environmental and social devastation, a seed of hope is germinating in the Peruvian Amazon among indigenous youth who are reclaiming the diverse natural, cultural, social, and spiritual commonwealth of their ancestors.

The SEED Project is creating opportunities for the rising generation of Shipibo to be catalysts for positive change in their communities. Through an innovative training program integrating indigenous wisdom with Permaculture design, Alianza Arkana and Chaikuni are supporting the Shipibo to develop forest gardens, fire-breaks, and integrated pest- and waste-management systems capable of providing food sovereignty, community cohesion, and a biodiversity-rich, climate-resilient landscape.

Over the next year, these motivated and inspiring young people will dedicate themselves to working with their communities to develop 10 acres of Permaculture forest gardens, plant over 15,000 trees and kickstart the process of regeneration for this heavily degraded landscape. They will also ensure their financial stability by cultivating Amazonian superfoods and medicinal plants and partnering with ecosocial businesses to gain access to local, regional and international markets.

To put it into perspective, one acre of Rainforest yields $60 of timber once. One acre for grazing yields an owner $400 per year until the soils are too degraded or compacted to provide good quality pasture. One acre of renewable medicinal plants and fruits is capable of yielding an estimated $2400 per year indefinitely. The average Shipibo family has a yearly income of $1300.

We have already conducted the first phase of a Permaculture training program with a group of young Shipibo pioneers - check out the blog for more details. These graduates are now in possession of the knowledge and techniques to lead their communities on the path to regeneration.

But Now They Need Your Help!

The SEED Project needs $26,000 to implement our combined vision for a new and thriving forest. Your contribution will help these young men and women to:

  • Establish a seed bank full of diverse Amazonian species including food, fiber fuels, medicines, oils, etc. $1 buys one seedling, $5 buys 100 seeds for their nurseries.
  • Buy the tools and materials they need. $50 will buy essential tools for all our participants.
  • Organize mingas - shared community labor centered around achieving a common goal. $55 pays for one minga with food and drink for the whole community.
  • Give stipends to 10 participants and help them focus their time and energy on regenerative ecosocial entrepreneurship as an alternative to working for the extractive industries responsible for their degraded landscapes. $133 pays one participant to implement Permaculture systems in their community for one month, including:
    • fire breaks
    • agroforestry
    • assisted natural regeneration
    • irrigation
    • waste management systems
  • Build a community nursery at a cost of $300
  • Create a local cooperative to market Amazonian crops
  • Lay the foundation for a resilient local economy based on non-timber forest products.

What We Are Up Against

The destruction of the Amazon Rainforest is a familiar concept to us all, but less known are the extreme challenges faced by the indigenous people, such as the Shipibo, who continue to live in these places once the forest is gone.

For the Shipibo communities we work with, their daily reality is in stark contrast to the contemporary view of indigenous communities co-existing in harmony with lush tropical Rainforests. Charred earth, deforestation, pollution and vast invasive grasslands now characterize the landscapes on the edge of what we know as the Amazon Rainforest - one of the most biodiverse regions on the planet.

Sadly, many young people here have never even seen a primary forest. Elders speak in somber tones of the timber, mining, and oil industries; the industrial agriculture, commercial fishing and cultural imperialism that have plundered the land and rivers while disintegrating their cultures and way of life. They reminisce about the abundant flora and fauna of their youth, the pure water, the fertile soils and clean air. This is not the environment their grandchildren live in now.

The current generation of Shipibo is the first to face severe challenges of poverty, food insecurity, disease and malnutrition. Many are leaving their communities in search of employment, disconnecting from their culture and often ending up working for the very same industries responsible for the destruction of their forest home.

These are the costs of “development” which have transformed healthy, vibrant forests, cultures and people into a patchwork of degradation, contamination, and scarcity.

But these Permaculture pioneers will demonstrate that a new model of development IS possible - one that co-creates environmental and social prosperity through a union of the ancient and the contemporary.

Perks: Our Way Of Saying Thank You

We want to thank you for your generosity by sending you a unique piece of the Amazon and even offer you the chance to come and experience the Rainforest's magic first-hand!

We can't wait to plant these seedlings in your name. Help us grow over 15,000 trees!

Note: Each of the handmade items are unique and one of a kind. All photos of handmade items are examples for illustration purposes and are not the exact item you will receive.

Planting Seeds Is Just The Beginning...

These Permaculture pioneers must demonstrate the ancestral wisdom they have revived and the Permaculture techniques they have learned to prove how effective they are and inspire and motivate others.

Through farmer-to-farmer dissemination of these methods the positive impact will grow, year after year, incorporating friends, family and neighbors while expanding from the field to the landscape level.

Please help us nurture these seeds of hope and grow this vision of regeneration!

More Ways To Help

This Campaign

  • Spread the word! Please share with family and friends on all your online social networks so we can reach as wide an audience as possible.
  • Follow Alianza Arkana on facebook, twitter and our blog.
  • Follow Chaikuni on facebook and our blog.
  • Every donation counts, no matter the amount - We appreciate whatever you can give!
  • Don't hesitate! The more momentum we can build early on in the campaign the more we will increase our visibility, helping us reach critical mass and ultimately reach our funding goal.
  • If possible, please pay by credit card instead of PayPal as this will reduce the fees we have to pay on the donation so that more money goes to the project.

General

  • Join the Alianza Arkana team by volunteering with us in Shipibo communities!
  • Become a Chaikuni intern or volunteer and come get your hands dirty!
  • Buy products sourced from ecosocial businesses such as Eco-Ola who are supporting rural farmers of the Amazon to produce superfoods in an ecological, sustainable and equitable way.
  • Support growers' cooperatives and education in rainforest communities - Source your perfumes and essential oils from innovative businesses such as Coeur du Foret and help them plant more trees while you're at it!

Thank you for helping to make this vision a reality
for the Amazon Rainforest and her people!
story_txt:
Sow a SEED of Hope Today!
The Shipibo Ecosocial Entrepreneurship Diploma (SEED) is supporting indigenous communities of the Peruvian Amazon to regenerate their environment using Permaculture.

Our grassroots initiative aims to restore the Rainforest's vibrant culture, flourishing biodiversity and health, while co-creating sustainable livelihoods with the people who live there. This is a regenerative social movement based on nurturing a paradigm of abundance and prosperity to defend the “lungs of the Earth” and create resilience in the face of climate change.
Donate & share this campaign with your friends and family today!
Who We Are
Alianza Arkana is a Peruvian NGO with nearly 3 years of experience successfully implementing community-based projects in the areas of environmental justice and human rights, sustainable waste management, and intercultural education. This program will be implemented with leadership from 3 Shipibo communities and in partnership with our sister NGO, the Chaikuni Institute of Permaculture.
The Shipibo are an indigenous people who live on the Ucayali River, a main tributary of the Amazon. They are famed artisans and healers and traditionally were skilled hunters, gatherers, and subsistence agriculturalists - but they are now facing the challenges of a deteriorated forest, pollution, and ensuing economic pressures.
Together, we are crafting a community-led model of eco-social abundance rooted in Permaculture and indigenous wisdom. Permaculture is an ethical design science that creates regenerative and resilient habitats by mimicking the patterns and processes found in nature - in essence it is human ingenuity wedded to the wisdom of the wild.  Permaculture teaches us that by taking care of the Earth, the people, and the future we can help to create a world of abundance and regeneration. Indigenous wisdom teaches the same. By integrating the two, we are creating lasting and positive change in the Amazon for generations to come.
What We Do And How You Can Help
After decades of environmental and social devastation, a seed of hope is germinating in the Peruvian Amazon among indigenous youth who are reclaiming the diverse natural, cultural, social, and spiritual commonwealth of their ancestors.
The SEED Project is creating opportunities for the rising generation of Shipibo to be catalysts for positive change in their communities. Establish a seed bank full of diverse Amazonian species including food, fiber  fuels, medicines, oils, etc.  $1 buys one seedling, $5 buys 100 seeds for their nurseries.

Buy the tools and materials they need.  $50 will buy essential tools for all our participants.

Organize mingas - shared community labor centered around achieving a common goal. $55 pays for one minga with food and drink for the whole community.

Give stipends to 10 participants and help them focus their time and energy on regenerative ecosocial entrepreneurship as an alternative to working for the extractive industries responsible for their degraded landscapes.  $133 pays one participant to implement Permaculture systems in their community for one month, including:

fire breaks
agroforestry
assisted natural regeneration
irrigation
waste management systems

Build a community nursery at a cost of $300
Create a local cooperative to market Amazonian crops
Lay the foundation for a resilient local economy based on non-timber forest products.

story:
Our Story: A Forest Garden at a Health Clinic Bringing Free Nutrition to All!!

Meeting each other as members of the Syracuse Peace Council's Advisory Board, Magda Bayoumi and Frank Raymond Cetera hit upon a serendipitous endeavor to use Permaculture to grow healthy food outside of the newly developing Rahma Free Health Clinic.  Magda shared the story of the clinic and their desire to landscape the lawn area around the clinic building.  Rahma ("mercy" in Arabic) is a project of the Muslim American Care and Compassion Alliance (MACCA).  Frank said to Magda, I can help you create a forest garden to share nutritious food and bring the health care mission of the clinic outside of its doors.  Working through The Alchemical Nursery, a Syracuse nonprofit organization using Permaculture and Ecovillage methodologies to instill community regeneration.  They both said: "Let's do it!".


 

The Rahma Clinic is a new resource for Syracuse providing free health care services at 3100 South Salina St.  An important part of health is nutrition and healthy eating; it is a well known fact that the southside of Syracuse currently does not have a grocery store providing fresh produce and healthy food choices, and is commonly referred to as a food desert.  Young and old are often tasked with finding food options at local corner stores, which often specialize in pre-packaged sugar laden snacks and processed “foods”.  More healthy food options are needed for southside residents and visitors.


Read an article about the project from the Southside Stand at http://mysouthsidestand.com/more-news/a-growing-community/

 

 

The Impact

On the surface, this project directly relates the concept of nutrition through proper food choices to health and wellness through integration with the Rahma Clinic’s health care mission.  On a further cultural level, this project will communicate and educate wellness choices through lifestyles related to self-sufficiency skills, edible landscape design, and native plant knowledge.


This project will integrate perennial edible landscaping into the urban fabric showcasing: > Use of perennial plant species to reduce annual maintenance of propagation, cultivation and planting needs > Use of native species and ground covers to reduce watering needs  > Use of multi-story design to utilize vertical growing space without expensive built infrastructure  >   Use of diverse plant products for self-mulching and self-fertilizing (maintenance of site integrity).

Want to learn more about forest gardening?  Learn from the best at http://www.edibleforestgardens.com/about_gardening

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

This project is 100% grassroots and non-profit in nature, and the forest garden will be open to the public for free picking.


We needs funds to pay for plant material (trees, shrubs, berry bushes, perennial vegetables, herbs, ground covers - some of these are largely unknown perennials that are being rediscovered through the Permaculture community worldwide and can be divided in the future for sharing) - $600; educational and identification signage for the plants, site infrastructure such as bench seating, and tools - $700; and administrative & overhead costs towards project implementation and maintenance over the next growing season - $700. 

 

 

You can view and download a full size version of the planting plan (as seen at left, designed by Steve Gabriel for the Community Permaculture Design Open) by visiting: http://www.alchemicalnursery.org/news/370-edible-forest-snack-garden-design-chosen.html

 

And you can see our full plant list at: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AojqPrjAiK0HdEp1b01jemJrYkJ4VzJRMUliZ1FhbHc   


We'll also accept direct plant donations of starts, seedlings, saplings, or divisions if you are able to bring them to the April 14 volunteer day!  Just contact us directly to report what you will provide so we can update the plant list.


If we don't reach out entire IndieGoGo funding goal of $2,000 we'll use what we have to make sure we get the forest garden planted with as much stock as possible this spring, and then continue to work into the future for funds to pay for educational signage and maintenance needs.  We're also going to apply to a local grant program for watershed related projects - what's more exciting than green infrastructure that also creates food we ask?  We all know however, that grants are often hit and miss even for the best writers among us. So your contributions now will ensure our success.  Any excess money will go towards a fund for future Permaculture and forest garden projects in CNY.


Check out our unique perks to the right.  In staying within our design and creation activities, we're providing variety such as perennial seed mix packs, Permaculture consulting, signed full-color prints of the design seen here, and even a picnic in the garden, among more traditional offerings such as stickers and t-shirts.


Donations made through the PayPal option will be disbursed directly to The Alchemical Nursery (a 501(c) non-profit tax exempt organization), and thus will be tax deductible.  Tax deductible donations of $250 or more will receive a donation receipt from the Alchemical Nursery as per IRS requirements.  Sorry, IndieGoGo does not enable tax deductions for direct credit card payments, but you can still pay that way if you're not concerned about a deduction.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

No matter at what level you can give or not, we ask that you help us by spreading the word about our campaign.  After all, this is called crowd funding, so we need a crowd right?  Don't worry about worrying about who to send it to.  If you think it is cool and merit worthy, your friends and family and co-workers probably will too.


Please join us in making this project a reality - it really is as unique and worthy as it sounds, just ask others who are supporting the forest garden.   Students from the S.U. Newhouse School and the comm.UNITY program, who filmed, edited, and produced the trailer video for this fundraising campaign.  The trainees of the Finger Lakes Permaculture Institute's Community Ecological Design Training course will be giving of their time to join us on April 14th.  The Rahma Garden is recognized as a Member Community Garden by Syracuse Grows here in Syracuse.  And we will be fortunate to have a Say Yes To Education group high school project participating through a media studies after-school course documenting the project, and volunteering with us on April 14th as well.


We're certainly a fan of the IndiGoGO mantra of DIWO! - 'Do It With Others'.  So let's make some action together!  It's easy just by using the share tools right on this page, send us a note if you need help figuring them out.  And once you sign in as a supporter and a donor, you'll learn much more about the project, our partners, and events and activities though our updates, can't wait to share with you!
