story:
We're showing the world green energy works best when it belongs to everyone!

 

  • We're the SF Energy Co-op, and we're a team of political organizers and budding solar experts. Check us out at sfenergycooperative.com/staff/
  • Our cooperative needs to get a pilot project putting solar on our neighborhood center up and running so we can raise membership around it and show other neighborhoods how they can get together on profitable solar projects too. 
  • One after another, we can seed community-funded solar projects and spread the cooperative solar model all over the state, the nation and the world. If we can show that anyone can own a piece of solar and get a decent return on even a tiny investment, we can jumpstart a green energy revolution- without waiting on huge energy corporations or top-down government initiatives. 

 

Help us grow a solar seed...

 

  • We need $25000 dollars to put a down payment on our pilot installation and make our local neighborhood center solar. We'll use it as a test case to educate the Bay Area about our unique mission and use funds to raise our membership around solar projects through community awareness efforts like canvassing, promotional materials and events. 
  • These indiegogo contributions aren't memberships- just seed money to get us on the map. But people who do become members and contribute to the solar resource fund become part owners of our new kind of energy company- and get profits from their investment. Our contributors here will get mentions in our newsletter, goodies like bumper stickers, and some will even get their names put up in the neighborhood center as sponsors of our pilot project. 
  • If we don't reach our target in its entirety, we'll still put the majority of funds aside as a down payment for the pilot installation, and use what's left to meet our membership goals and fund the installation through membership sales. 

 

...into a society of energy farmers

If we can provide viable proof of concept for the energy cooperative, neighborhood centers, schools, and libraries are just the beginning. With a good model that allows anyone to put something into solar and see returns over time, we can change the way we think about energy. 

  • Your contribution directly funds a green energy installation, helping our neighborhood become cleaner, greener and more conscious of its power to change the world. 
  • In a larger sense, you'll help us provide proof that this concept is viable anywhere- a template for changing the world, one rooftop, one power bill at a time. 
  • We've got numbers to back up our projections and a solid plan. Check it out on our website at www.sfenergycooperative.com/how-it-works/san-fr...

Contributions are key, but we need promotional help too.

  • Share our campaign on your fb wall, twitter feed, blog or other social media platforms.
  • Use Indiegogo's sharing tools
  • And hey, if you live in California, why not join the Co-op by visiting  sfenergycooperative.com/membership/ ? 
    Memberships are just ten bucks a year, and contributing to the resource fund will help us build projects and net you dividends.

And hey, if you live in California, why not join the Co-op by visiting  sfenergycooperative.com/membership/ ? Memberships are just ten bucks a year, and contributing to the resource fund will help us build projects and net you dividends.

story:
Redbird is a Native American and environmental non profit. Our need is simple, and urgent.  We need to replace the transmission in 1990 Suburban, which was donated to us last year.  Below you can read about who are and what we do; if you're interested in Native American culture and environmental education and restoration, but cannot contribute financially, please look below for other ways to get invoved.

 

Redbird

Mission Statement

 Promoting the awareness and celebration of indigenous cultures and people and creating a sustainable future

 Redbird is a charitable and educational non profit association which received its status as a 501(c)(3) organization in 1994. We have five program areas which focus on Native American cultural preservation and multi-cultural immersion, and environmental education and action.  We host two annual events, are engaged in two ongoing environmental projects, and are in the process of restoring the Chilao School property for use as an educational facility.  We serve Native American, multi-ethnic and non native people including but not limited to low income and challenged families.

 Children of Many Colors Powwow

Annual three day event, held the third weekend of July at Moorpark College in Moorpark, California, the Children of Many Colors Powwow is our signature event, bringing together the urban Native American community of southern California with visitors from all walks of life in a friendly environment where cultural preservation and multi-cultural learning and understanding take place.

 Blanket, Toy and School Supplies Drive

Held annually the first Saturday in December in Simi Valley. This one day mini-powwow generates donations which are shared with reservations in some of the most impoverished areas of the United States, as well as local families.

 Forest Recovery Project

This effort, in its fourth year, documents the recovery of the Angeles National Forest from the Station Fire and includes educational presentations made throughout California, focusing on the ecology of fire and our role as environmental stewards.  The Station Fire was the largest in the history of Los Angeles County.  It took lives and property, and 160,577 acres of forest.  Understanding fire - its role in the health of natural environments and the responsibility we have as residents of urban/wilderness interfaces, can save lives and contribute to better wilderness management.  The Forest Recovery Project connects ordinary people with their extraordinary natural world, and its siter effort, the Pinon Project, helps restore a vital tree species to the Angeles National Forest.

Pinon Project

This is an ongoing effort to restore a viable population of piñon trees to the Angeles National Forest in areas where they once thrived.

 Chilao School

Located in the heart of the Angeles National Forest, Chilao School is our first land base and a venue which we are making available to groups in the greater southern California region who address the underserved, at risk, developmentally and physically challenged, and terminally ill children.  We also wish to be of service to the arts and culture community, including the healing arts, the educational community including but not limited to fire ecology, and outdoor recreation programs that include an educational component.  The school is an ideal location for a rural library, particularly since internet access is not available to all forest residents.

Get Involved 

We are an all volunteer organization.  Each of our projects requires the involvement and commitment of volunteers, both native and non native.  Join us for our upcoming Open House; for the Children of Many Colors Native American Powwow, our signature event; volunteer to gather pinon seeds, plant seeds and trees, help gather supplies bound for reservations, volunteer at an event, or help us get the materials we need to improve and renovate Chilao School.  Everyone has gifts of value to share with the world.  We welcome yours.

www.RedbirdsVision.org 

 

Like us on Facebook:

 

www.facebook.com/RedbirdsVision         www.facebook.com/ChilaoSchool

story:
Short Summary

My name is Dan Mohlenhoff, also known as "Cowboy Dan". I started Water4Wells in 2004. It went great until the economy went south. I was able to get into a nice home and drive a decent car ('65 Corvette Stingray). By 2009 I had sold the car, was living on credit cards, and looking at foreclosure on my home. Now that the economy is getting up some steam again I am anxious to get back to work. I am still in my home but everything else is gone. I am now driving a "practical" car (Honda Element). 

What We Need & What You Get

I stll have all the equipment for testing for groundwater. I need money for advertising and operating expenses for the first three months. $15,000 wlll be spent on advertising. For all the years I was successful I have had a deal worked out with an outfit in Arizona that puts me in 50 different publications every week for $5,000.00 per month. I will rent a truck for operations in the beginning. I also need to hire a helper. I have a guy I have used for the past couple of years who is willing to do piece work, making him very affordable.

I wish I had some kind of perk or incentive to offer but the service I provide is very unique. If you have a piece of land in Nevada or Arizona we will come and find a spot for you to drill a well if you donate $1200.00 or more.

I'm not sure we will raise the $35,000 we are targeting. If we don't half that will accomplish what we have set out to do which is to get Water4Wells up and running at full capacity again.

The Impact

Having gone through some very tough times these past few years I have learned to be humble. The humility I have learned obligates me to give back at a level to which I was previously averse.

My goal is to eventually be able to provide my services for free or at drastically reduced prices for the Native American communities in Arizona who are literally forced to carry water for miles and miles because they cannot afford to keep drilling until they get lucky enough to find water in an area that is very sparsely hydrated. Methods used in those areas now are water witching (proven to be ineffectual) and the "poke and hope" method; where they drill in a spot picked either at random or some other nonsensical method and hope they find water before they run out of pipe for the rig.

Once that goal is accomplished I want to take my services to some of the depressed areas in the world like Africa where people are dying of thirst because they don't have potable water. One of the advantages of using the technology I employ is that it does not detect salt water, a common problem with water in Africa.

All things happen for a reason. I think I was put through these hard times to help me appreciate my success. I hope to get this new lease on life so I may enhance the lives of others, rather than just getting a bunch of cool stuff for myself.

Other Ways You Can Help

I realize not everyone can help and that some of you may not be inclined to donate if you don't get some little gadget in return. If that is the case just use the share tools to let others you know about my campaign and give them the chance to help me and a whole bunch of very deserving people get a new lease on life.

story:
About the Radix Center

The Radix Ecological Sustainability Center is a new non-profit organization situated on a half acre parcel in the South End in Albany.  Our mission is to create a demonstration of ecologically sustainable tools and technologies, teaching capital district residents how to live more sustainably in a city environment.  A few of the features that Radix has onsite include gardens, chickens, ducks, rabbits, a community-scale composting operation, and a solar-heated greenhouse containing an aquaculture system.  The Radix Center focuses on teaching “ecological literacy” to urban youth – an understanding of natural systems relating to food production, water, waste management, climate issues, energy and their connection to STEM disciplines.  We also offer classes for adults on a variety of hand-on, DIY topics.  Believing that true sustainability takes into account environmental, social, and economic issues, Radix is also working to develop green job opportunities for urban areas.  The Radix Center operates a pilot residential and small business compost collection program called the Community Compost Initiative.

 

Since September of 2011, Radix has been visited by over 900 people through organized workshops, class trips, open houses, and casual drop-ins.  From the beginning, Radix has accomplished an enormous amount on a shoestring budget through the dedication of its volunteers.

 

Urban Ecological Literacy Youth Workshops

Your tax-deductible support will allow us to bring school groups to the Radix Center for 1-2 hour workshops on:

  • Sustainable Food Systems
  • Aquaponics and Aquatic Ecosystem Science
  • Energy
  • Waste

 (See below for detailed descriptions of each module.)

 

Through hands-on educational experiences, students will be encouraged to use critical thinking skills to develop innovative solutions to the environmental issues confronted by their communities, like

 

  • Climate change
  • Waste management
  • Environmental degradation
  • Food production
  • Fossil fuel depletion
  • Toxins in the environment
  • Health and nutrition

 

Students will see

  • The dynamic relationships between living ecosystems taught in hands-on format
  • Ecological relationships demonstrated on a small scale by actual living organisms
  • A living laboratory that will foster an understanding of environmental science
  • How their consumption of food, energy, and production of waste are related to and dependent upon global ecological processes

 

 

The one to two hour workshops will be appropriately tailored to each age group, kindergarten to twelfth grade. Workshops can also be adapted to more closely augment what a particular class is covering in the classroom. In all of the workshops, critical thinking and problem solving skills will be cultivated through group discussions and brainstorming sessions. Each workshop will end with a hypothetical design charrette, in which students will be challenged to develop creative solutions to the environmental issues impacting their communities using information learned in the workshops.

The Radix Center is located in New York State’s Capital District.  Its three main cities are Albany, Schenectady, and Troy.  The School Districts for each of these cities are respectively ranked 658th, 672nd, and 683rd out of New York State’s 697 school districts.  

RadixCenter workshops will support struggling schools by providing an educational experience meant to excite and inspire students - an experience that could change the course of lives.

 

Budget

This funding will allow us to offer these workshops to area schools for free.  The budget will cover personnel (outreach to schools, preparing for and teaching the workshops) supplies, and insurance.  To offer 2 classes a week, our total budget is around $10,000 per semester.  This campaign is to get us started, we will use this assistance to help leverage other support from foundations and local businesses.  If less money is raised, the number of classes will be scaled back accordingly.   

 

About us

The Urban Ecological Literacy workshop program will be led by Educational Director Scott Kellogg and Executive Director Stacy Pettigrew. Kellogg and Pettigrew designed and implemented a $200,000 EPA 2004 Brownfield Cleanup Award awarded to the Rhizome Collective for the Grove Landfill Cleanup in Austin, Texas. They authored the book “Toolbox for Sustainable City Living” (South End Press, 2008). A leading expert and innovator in the fields of urban sustainability and regenerative ecosystems, Kellogg has lectured and taught workshops at numerous universities and conferences throughout the country. He holds a M.S. from Johns Hopkins University.

 

Because we believe that a transition to a more environmentally sustainable future is critical, we (Kellogg and Pettigrew) have invested our own money and time into building the Radix Center over the past year and a half.  We volunteer daily to caretaking the living systems at the Center, giving tours and classes to neighbors and school groups, maintaining the website and accounting, and expanding project.  This funding will enable the Radix Center’s first regularly scheduled youth workshops.  We are really excited to see this come to fruition!

 

If you are unable to make a donation, you can still help! 

 

  • Please consider helping us get the word out about the campaign by sharing campaign with your contacts. 
  • If you are a local educator or know a teacher that may be interested, please give them information about us.
  • Sign up on our mailing list to hear about upcoming workshops and classes news about the RadixCenter and like us on Facebook.

 

Workshop Descriptions

Aquaculture and Aquatic Ecosystem Science 

Using a modeled aquatic ecosystem, this module demonstrates the relationships between the biological, chemical, and physical components of an aquatic ecosystem and its inhabitants. The model ecosystem will be contained within a greenhouse and will consist of a series of tanks filled with re-circulating water.  Each tank will represent a different type of freshwater aquatic environment, such as a pond, stream habitat, or wetland, and will contain an array of organisms found in each of those ecotypes.  Wastes produced by fish living in the tanks will be converted by the activity of microorganisms into nutrients for plants co-habitating the system.

 

By studying and interacting with this simulated ecosystem, students will develop an awareness of

  • nutrient cycling and contaminant transport in aquatic environments, 
  • the role of sewage and agricultural runoff in the eutrophication of bodies of water,
  • fish biology,
  • the hydrological cycle,
  • the importance of watersheds,
  • aquatic invertebrate’s function as indicators of ecosystem health, 
  • the connection between the health of local aquatic environments and drinking water quality
  • small scale aquaculture’s potential as a susainable alternative to the depletion of global fisheries and its promise as a “green” urban micro-industry.  

 

 Energy

This module will take a critical look at global energy issues and assess the pros and cons of conventional and alternative energy sources. 

Emphasis will be placed on renewable, non-polluting, and locally producible energy sources, such as solar, wind, and biofuels.  Functioning examples of each of these technologies will be on display, including:

  • a passive solar oven,
  • wind turbines,
  • waste vegetable oil burning vehicles,
  • small scale biogas digesters, and
  • technologies that efficiently and cleanly use wood for heating and power generation. 

 

The idea that technologies may either be environmentally harmful or benign depending on their use, scale, and context will be stressed.  Additionally, the causes and impacts of global climate change will be discussed, particularly within the context of energy use decisions.  Furthermore, students will become familiar with such critical concepts as carbon neutral and carbon negative energy strategies.

 

 Sustainable Food Systems

This module will cover issues of local sustainable food production, including methods for raising vegetables, mushrooms, and small livestock.  An emphasis will be put on creating intensive, small scale food production systems that can be carried out with limited access to space. Broader issues of food security and nutrition will be integrated into the discussion. 

 

Students will learn the basics of small scale animal husbandry, including feeding, cleaning, and sheltering chickens, rabbits, and goats.  The use of easily accessible waste products as feed stocks and the appropriate integration of animals into an urban environment will be examined.

 

Students will also learn about the fungal kingdom and the ecological significance of fungi in the environment, particularly their role in waste reduction and nutrient cycling.  Mushroom’s potential to turn waste products into valuable protein sources through fungi’s metabolic processes, and the role fungi can play in the remediation of toxins will be covered.   Students will inoculate a straw-filled bag with oyster mushrooms, a common edible mushroom species, which afterwards they can bring back to their own classroom to watch grow. 

 

In addition, organic vegetable gardens and a functioning rainwater collection system for use in conjunction with food production will be displayed.  Students will become aware of the impacts of soil erosion and the importance of good soil conservation practices.  Class participants will become familiar with the concept of brownfields and possibilities for remediation and reuse of brownfields for urban food production.

 

Waste

This module explores how common organic waste products can be converted into soil, energy sources, and feed stocks for animals.  Class participants will:

  • learn the basics of home-scale backyard composting, such as determining the proper balances and sources of carbon and nitrogen. 
  • witness and interact with a worm composting system that converts food wastes into a nutrient rich fertilizer which improves soil quality and can be used in the remediation of soil-based toxins. 
  • observe a black soldier fly composting unit, which rapidly converts putrescent wastes, such as meat and dairy, into compost and produces insect larvae as a feed for chickens and fish. 

 

Larger discussions will be incorporated that examine problems with conventional waste disposal, and how organic waste buried in landfills contributes to greenhouse gas emissions.

story:
Who are we? Citizens Climate Lobby (citizensclimatelobby.org)-- A super PAC of super people with one special interest: creating the climate for a livable world; run by the passion and dedication of hundreds of volunteers.

What’s the plan? Enacting national legislation to slow or reverse our climate crisis.  Carbon fee and dividend:  Put a fee on carbon-based fuels and return all collected funds to the people.

How we make our mission a reality: As volunteers, we meet with US Representatives, Senators, and their aides throughout the year in local offices to build relationships, educate, and bring opposing minds together.  These efforts culminate once each year with a gathering in Washington DC.   Volunteers from around the US and Canada travel to the Citizens Climate Lobby conference for a full day of education on the issues followed by several days meeting with elected officials. In face-to-face meetings, we make the case for Carbon Fee and Dividend. 

Your role:  You can help make this conference a reality.  While volunteers pay their own way and their accommodations, there are many essential conference-related expenses.

How you can be empowered: Everyone can participate; everyone can help to slow or reverse the climate crisis.  Some have the time and passion to volunteer; others make those efforts possible by donating money.  Do what works for you. Any of the funds we raise will be applied towards the 2013 conference.

CCL is a volunteer, non-partisan & non-profit organization that--since its founding in 2007--has grown to over 80 groups, and 1400 active volunteers all over the United States and Canada. We had our first DC conference in 2009; there were three of us then.  Just a few years later, in July of 2012, 175 showed up. We are growing fast. This year we plan to interact with every congressional office.

MORE VOLUNTEERS AND MORE MEETINGS IN DC EACH YEAR: Watch us grOW...

 

 "After I had given just a few talks about the climate, I realized that the actions I was suggesting, while essential, were not a match for the problem. I realized that ordinary people like me would have to organize, educate ourselves, give up our hopelessness and powerlessness, and gain the skills to be effective with our government." Marshall Saunders, Founder, Citizen's Climate Lobby

Visit: http://www.citizensclimatelobby.org/content/are-you-ready-more 

Your donation will go to Citizens Climate Education Corporation, a 501(c)(3) organization, and is tax-deductible.
story_txt:
Who are we? Citizens Climate Lobby (citizensclimatelobby.org)-- A super PAC of super people with one special interest: creating the climate for a livable world; run by the passion and dedication of hundreds of volunteers.
What’s the plan? Enacting national legislation to slow or reverse our climate crisis.  Carbon fee and dividend:  Put a fee on carbon-based fuels and return all collected funds to the people.
How we make our mission a reality: As volunteers, we meet with US Representatives, Senators, and their aides throughout the year in local offices to build relationships, educate, and bring opposing minds together.  These efforts culminate once each year with a gathering in Washington DC.   Volunteers from around the US and Canada travel to the Citizens Climate Lobby conference for a full day of education on the issues followed by several days meeting with elected officials. In face-to-face meetings, we make the case for Carbon Fee and Dividend. 
Your role:  You can help make this conference a reality.  While volunteers pay their own way and their accommodations, there are many essential conference-related expenses.
How you can be empowered: Everyone can participate; everyone can help to slow or reverse the climate crisis.  Some have the time and passion to volunteer; others make those efforts possible by donating money.  Do what works for you. Any of the funds we raise will be applied towards the 2013 conference.
CCL is a volunteer, non-partisan & non-profit organization that--since its founding in 2007--has grown to over 80 groups, and 1400 active volunteers all over the United States and Canada. We had our first DC conference in 2009; there were three of us then.  Just a few years later, in July of 2012, 175 showed up. We are growing fast.  "After I had given just a few talks about the climate, I realized that the actions I was suggesting, while essential, were not a match for the problem. story:
My name is Maggie Cochrane and I am an undergraduate student at Princeton University. This summer I am doing thesis research in Central Kenya on the social impacts of conservation. Prior to my field work I want to climb Mt. Kilimanjaro. Not just for me, but as a charity climb, raising money for charity:water. Charity:water is an amazing non profit that brings clean, safe drinking water to people in developing countries. I feel passionate that all humans should have the right to clean water and the means of survival. I also believe that ascending Mt. Kilimanjaro would be an amazing, life changing challenge and experience. Therefore, I have combined the two! I want to raise $4000, to cover the $2000 fee to climb Kili and the equal amount to be donated to charity:water! Please help me in my endeavor to bring clean water to communities in need!

I plan on climbing with a GoPro camera for the entirety of my trip so I can document my experience. I want to provide all my contributors with pictures and video of Kilimanjaro and personal thankyou notes informing everyone of my amazing climb and confirming my donation to charity:water!

story:
Our Story

Alternative Spring Break (ASB) is a student-run, non-profit volunteer organization of the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and the Univeristy YMCA.  ASB sends U of I students on nationwide service trips four times throughout the year.  During the fall, winter, spring, and summer breaks, ASB participants travel throughout the country to learn about and actively combat social justice and environmental issues.  

This winter break, our ASB trip will be going down to New Orleans to partner with Green Light, a non-profit organization. From their website, their mission is to: "invest energy in people by assisting New Orleans in person, one household at a time.  Our volunteers install free energy efficient light bulbs to demonstrate that a mass movement of individual actions creates a significant impact on our environment and community.  We connect New Orleans residents to relevant, local opportunities and encourage individual actions so that everyone can benefit from a vibrant, resilient, and sustainable community" (www.greenlightneworleans.org).

Please donate to Green Light New Orleans in any  amount you can!  All donations help no matter how big or small!

The Impact

We are hoping to raise at $200 to give to Green Light New Orleans as a donation to help give the New Orleans community a hand up.  Thank you for your support!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about Alternative Spring Break and Green Light New Orleans!  Help send the link to friends and family to help us reach our fundraising goal!

If you attend the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, work with us and get involved on a ASB volunteer trip! Find us at http://illinoisasb.org/

story:
A Green Ribbon School

The Tomorrow River Community Charter School has been recognized as a 2014 US Department of Education Green Ribbon School, an honor only 49 other public schools in the United States have received. Many schools spend years planning and hiring consultants to achieve this task while TRCCS was able to accomplish this in its inaugural year! 

At Tomorrow River Community Charter School (TRCCS) sustainability and the environment run deep. Nature and arousing children’s reverence for it are major facets of the public school’s curriculum inpspired by Waldorf pedagogy. Situated at the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point’s Central Wisconsin Environmental Station (CWES), the school is located in rural Amherst, Wisconsin, a progressive community that has a lineage of alternative energy and sustainability. With neighbors and partners like the Midwest Renewable Energy Association, Farmshed, local organic farmers, and lovers of the arts and outdoors, it is critical to the mission of the school and the community to raise stewards of the earth through education, mentoring, and immersion. TRCCS has documented significant achievement in all three pillars of U.S. Department of Education Green Ribbon Schools.

As a Green Ribbon winner, four representatives of our school have been invited to the Green Ribbons Schools Ceremony in Washington DC to receive recognition and to connect with other schools to share the measures and practices that earned us our Green Ribbon.  These four representatives will be:

Diana Bohman (District Representative): School District liaison for the Tomorrow River Community Charter School and retired educator.

Tina Giombetti (Governance Board Representative): Founder, Secretary of the TRCCS Governance Board, and mother of 2 TRCCS students, and lover of all things sustainable.

Chamomile Nusz (TRCCS Staff Representative): Founder, TRCCS School Coordinator, mother of 2 TRCCS students, and compassionate, committed steward of the earth.

Tom Quinn (CWES Representative): Program Manager at the Central Wisconsin Environmental Station (our school's home) and TRCCS Governance Board Chair.

This trip will be an amazing way for our school to not only celebrate this fine achievement, but to meet the other educators, administrators, and parents who are transforming schools into healthy, sustainable, and environmentally responsible places to learn and work. It does, however, come at a cost to our representatives. But we know that there are many folks who are just as passionate about education and the environment that would love to support us by donating just a bit to our trip cost. If it's donating the cost of an organic meal or the cost of a airline ticket we would be incredibly grateful. Even if we don't meet our goal of fully funding each representative's trip, your collective donations will help to offset the cost of the trip to make it affordable for these folks that are working to change the world. 

The $4,000 will go to cover air fare, transportation, hotel and food for all 4 participants. 

What will they do while they are there? 

  • Attend the Award Ceremony in Washington DC. 
  • Tour the U.S. Botanic Garden
  • Walking tour of the National Memorial
  • Meet with the U.S. Department of Energy and get an update of the future of clean energy. 
  • Meet with Tammy Baldwin, their school's U.S. Senator.

story:
Project Summary

My name is Brian Cohen, and I am a photographer based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

Pennsylvania is experiencing the rapid expansion of a major industry aimed at extracting deposits of natural gas from deep underground.  The industry brings prosperity to some, not least the companies doing the drilling, but the process is still controversial, and may have unintended negative health and environmental consequences on local and regional levels.  We are daily subject to material intended to shape our view of the industry, but there is a lot we don't know.

For most people, Marcellus Shale gas drilling, (what many people call "fracking"), is an idea more than a daily reality.  We set up the Marcellus Shale Documentary Project because wanted people to understand how the introduction of this industry has affected the lives and lifestyles of people in gas areas, how it affects the air and water in and beyond those areas, and how those effects may be felt by all of us in the years to come.

So since late 2011, a team of six photographers have been documenting the advance of natural gas drilling in Pennsylvania, telling the story from a wide variety of angles and perspectives.  We have been collecting the accounts and stories of the people who are most directly affected by gas drilling - the people who live and work in these areas.  The stories we have uncovered, are real, moving, and beautifully articulated.

The net product is twofold: a travelling exhibition at which people will be able to discuss openly, and without coercion or intimidation, the subject of gas drilling, along with their neighbors, friends, interested parties, experts, and so on; and a permanent archive recording for posterity the impact of the gas industry.  The exhibit will include a book summarizing the project.  The more we can travel the exhibit, the more people we can reach - we would like to get the work shown not only in traditional venues for photographic exhibitions, but into schools, libraries, community centers, town halls - places where people can see first hand what to most of them is just a distant idea.

The images will travel to venues throughout Pennsylvania, New York, and other areas, where gas drilling is either under way, or is being considered. The exhibit will be a staging ground for meetings, forums and symposia at which the public will be able to learn more about the industry and its consequences, intended and unintended.  Many of the venues at which we would like to show this work are non-traditional sites with no budget for staging exhibitions such as this.

Your contribution will help enable us to travel the show widely, as well as to continue shooting footage to expand the historical archive.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we raise will serve two purposes: first, to enable us to travel the work to the non-traditional venues described above; and second, to enable us to continue photographing - we have covered a lot of ground in the last nine months, but there is still so much more to tell.

Even if we do not meet our goal, the more we raise, the more places we will be able to achieve.

The Impact

Your contribution will help ordinary people to understand what gas drilling actually looks like; how it affects our homes, our environment, our communities; who benefits and who doesn't.  The more we raise, the more stories we tell, and the more people we will reach.

story:
Pandemic threatens sanctuary for rescued wildlife  

8 April 2021

The Wildlife Friends Foundation Thailand, or WFFT, home to more than 800 rescued animals, had planned to celebrate its 20th anniversary on 1 May. Instead, we may be shutting many gates for the last time. 

Like so much of Thailand, the Covid-19 crisis and closure of the borders has hit the rescue centre hard, with WFFT losing more than 70% of its income for the past year. This income derives from overseas volunteers who pay for room and board, day visitors and lodge guests who bring their families for a learning experience and the soothing hilly landscape of Phetchaburi. WFFT prides itself on providing a home in an environment that is as close to a natural habitat as possible for wildlife and other animals who have been abused or are no longer wanted as pets, like Chico and Maggie, the resident orangutans.  

WFFT was blessed with countless donations over the past year that helped sustain the monthly expenses. Several large grants from organizations, businesses and private citizens helped improve or build desperately needed enclosures. But the toll of the pandemic has finally consumed all gifts. We have endured monthly losses since March 2020, and WFFT has only enough funds remaining for one month of operations.

With the financial reserves approaching depletion, voluntarily handing over the wildlife animals now looms as a potential solution to reduce expenses. But we know this is not a viable solution because the Department of National Parks does not have any facility that could manage this many animals. Nor in this crisis time can it likely afford their upkeep. 

Twenty years ago we constructed a few primate enclosures, a small kitchen and four bedrooms. We never thought then that our foundation would grow to the size it is today and to have an international reputation as a model rescue centre. Our commitment to rescuing and caring for animals deepened as the years flew by. That commitment remains, but our hearts are breaking as the funding disappears.  

The longer the borders remain closed due to the pandemic, the dimmer grows our optimism that returning tourism will rescue WFFT as the public knows it now. Without tourism, the rescue centre is dependent on donations and fundraising. But without sufficient funding and with the emerging court battle, WFFT is now forced to consider unacceptable solutions.

Your contribution can change that!

story:
Tanganyika Apicultural Limited is a Tanzanian registered social venture (registration number 109573). We are promoting our all-natural handmade beeswax candles in support of our efforts to further the sustainable use of natural resources in rural Tanzania, economic development and female economic empowerment.

Our beeswax candles are organic and natural. They also purify the air by releasing negative ions that eliminate pollutants and allergens. 

We also have many other ways to thank you for your contribution to the development of the rural Tanzanian beekeeping industry.

  1. Tote Bags hand sewn by Singidan female entrepreneurs
  2. Small batch organic Central Tanzanian honey
  3. Tanzanian beekeeping photo albums
  4. Custom trucker hats
  5. Handmade Tanzanian top bar beehives
  6. Sponsorship of a beehive or a beekeeping group
  7. Personalized tour of Tanzanian beekeeping and cultural sites 

Beekeeping is the fastest and lowest cost way to double household earnings in rural Tanzania that is also socially and environmentally sustainable. 

Tanzania has over 2 million traditional artisanal beekeepers, but they suffer from lack of access to modern equipment, training, finance and markets. Tanzanian beekeeping has yet to meet its poverty-alleviating potential. 

The benefits of our intervention extend far beyond charity. We aim to demonstrate that Tanzania has the human capacity and the natural resources to sustainably and ethically produce high quality bee products. 

With your help we plan to show the government, development banks, exporters, retailers and financiers that investing in rural beekeeping is a win-win economically, socially and environmentally.

Who We Are

Tanganyika Apicultural Limited was founded by Olujimi (Jimi) Akindele and Philemon Kiemi. Jimi Akindele is from New York City, studied Biology and Philosophy at Stanford in California and is a Fordham Law graduate.  He first moved to Tanzania in 2011 to support private sector driven approaches to promoting renewable energy and economic development in rural Tanzania. Philemon Kiemi is a Tanzanian from Singida where he and his brothers learned beekeeping from their father while growing up on their farm. Upon graduating from Sokoine University of Agriculture Philemon Kiemi returned to Singida to train beekeepers across the region in modern beekeeping practices and to give back to his community. 

Why Are Bees So Great?

We are not the first to to promote beekeeping as a powerful and sustainable way to support rural livelihoods in the developing world. See Bees for Development. See also another amazing crowdfunded bee project in Brazil.

Bees are not only a source of honey, wax and propolis (what bees use to seal their hives), but they are also essential pollinators, they help plants have sex to make fruits, vegetables and nuts for us to eat. In fact beekeeping has been shown to increase nearby agricultural yields by up to 300%.  See also another UN Report.

Through the introduction and promotion of modern beekeeping we intend to improve  agricultural yields throughout the community. In turn, beekeepers and farmers will both benefit.

In fact, a recent study has shown that for every $1 USD invested into an East African honey enterprise there are $15.48 USD in social impact returns.

Economic Impact

With your help we will train over 300 women to hand-craft candles and Kanga Totes, providing much needed income for our partners.

Currently our out grower network consists of over 400 beehives.

We have already loaned 150 beehives to youth and female rural cooperative groups.

With your help our operations  will support the beekeeping activities of over 1500 beekeepers over the next year. 

We have reached out to  Kiva.org to expand our micro finance program, and we have partnered with a Tanzanian parastatal, SIDO (Small Industries Development Organization), as well as other governmental and NGO partners to support our processing and packaging operations and thereby increase access to markets for beekeepers across the region.

Other Benefits:

  • providing a second source of income for rural women
  • less labor intensive than traditional beekeeping 
  • seasonal and part-time, allowing women to manage other responsibilities
  • provides economic incentive to not over-exploit forests
  • spurs development of related industries (carpentry, sewing, candle making, beauty and pharmaceutical products)

Once we have recruited and adequate number of beekeepers we plan to export our honey to the United States, Europe and Middle East.

Environmental Impact

Today Tanzania’s bee product sector is in a unique position in the world market. Its honey catchment area is free of pesticides and pollution; Tanzanian bee products are widely considered organic. Your support for our efforts will create a  financial incentive to ensure that Tanzania's bee forage areas stay pristine, healthy and safe from deforestation.

What We Need

Your donations and purchases will allow us to:

  • reach out and include even more beekeepers and rural cooperatives 
  • invest in modern equipment to better support the rural Tanzanian beekeeping industry
  • obtain certifications to ensure that our products are of the highest quality, and meet the highest international ethical and environmental standards

With your help we will also be able to support the development of value added products from beekeeping. We started with candles, but we are planning to make organic soaps, sustainable skin products and eco-friendly surfboard wax.

What You Get

1. Handmade Air-Purifying Candles


Most candles today are now made of paraffin, a petroleum product, which upon burning contributes what you might expect to the environment – and your lungs! Soy-based candles are also commonly available, but are often sourced from industrialized, genetically modified crops. 

Our beeswax candles are entirely sustainable, organic and natural. They are also purify the air by releasing negative ions which remove pollutants and allergens.

Beeswax candles were originally developed by European churches during the Middle Ages. Today we are inviting you to experience the benefits of old world candle-making together with the exotic natural aromas of African beeswax!

2. The Kanga Tote


Show your colors with the “Kanga Tote”. Kanga’s are a popular clothing item in Swahili Africa (Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda), though they are thought to have originated in the Comoros Islands in the Indian Ocean. Kangas are noted for their print patterns as well as often featuring a mji or saying, e.g.:

Majivuno hayafai — Greed is never useful

Mkipendana mambo huwa sawa — Everything is all right if you love each other

Mwanamke mazingira tuanataka, usawa, amani, maendelo — We (women) want equality, peace, and progress

Our Kanga Totes are hand sewn by female entrepreneurs in Singida Tanzania. 

3. Trucker Hat

Sport your Support for Sustainable African Beekeeping with our Custom Trucker Hats!

4. Small Batch Organic Honey

We would like to thank our most committed contributors with our finest forest honey harvested from our apiaries. This honey is has a warm hazelnut brown hue and comes from the nectar of Singida’s flowering foliage: Itigi thickets, Mlonge trees, and Miombo forests.

5. Tanzanian Beekeeping Photo Album

From the shores of Lake Rukwa to the terraced hills of Moshi, enjoy an intimate view of the beekeeping practices across Tanzania with our hardcover bound photo collection of Tanzanian apiculture. 

5. Authentic Handmade Tanzanian Top-Bar Bee Hive


At Tanganyika Apicultural we are working to promote the usage of improved beehives, particularly the Tanzanian Top-Bar Hive, made from Tanzanian hardwoods. Top-bar hives are simple to install and maintain and are a fun introduction to beekeeping. Try it on your bees at home!

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_top-bar_hive#Tanzanian_top-bar_hive

http://www.motherearthnews.com/homesteading-and-livestock/keeping-bees-top-bar-beekeeping-zmaz09onzraw.aspx#axzz3Da5A89Gy

6. Sponsorship of a Beehive

With this perk you can sponsor a beehive that we will donate to one of our beginner female beekeepers.

  • You can personalize the hive with your name/color (Spiderman themed?...no problem. Let us know.)
  • You will receive a picture of the installed hive with the donee
  • You will have the hive's GPS coordinates and be able to track the hive's production and management via your browser and mobile app http://www.hivetracks.com/
  • Each year you will receive 1 Kg of Honey harvested from your sponsored beehive for 3 years

7. Sponsorship of a Beekeeping Group

You can donate 10 beehives to one of our local beekeeping groups and we can work with you to determine to which group you would like to donate 

  • You can personalize the hives of the apiary with your name/color
  • We will send you pictures and video of the apiary once the hives are installed
  • You will have the GPS coordinates of the hives from your apiary and will be able to track the production and management of the hives via your browser and mobile app http://www.hivetracks.com/
  • You will receive 10 kg  of honey yearly from your sponsored apiary for 3 years

    8. A Tour of Tanzanian Beekeeping and Honey Harvesting

    Come visit us for a private tour of Central Tanzanian beekeeping!

    • inspect and harvest hives from our outgrower network in Singida,
    • collect beeswax from forest communities in Tabora
    • visit the rock art of hunter gatherers and pastoralists who lived thousands of years ago near Kondoa (an UNESCO World Heritage Site http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1183)
    • visit the beekeepers of Kinyamweda and Sumbawanga
    • visit the Tabora Beekeeping Training Institute 

    Donations

    Of course we would greatly appreciate any and all donations. All donations will go to providing  beehives and protective clothing to rural female beekeeping groups.
    Donations over $10 will receive a handwritten thank you.
    Please remember to spread the word!
    "Like" and "Share" us on Facebook!
    "Follow" us on Twitter @TangApic!
story_txt:
Tanganyika Apicultural Limited is a Tanzanian registered social venture (registration number 109573). We are promoting our all-natural handmade beeswax candles in support of our efforts to further the sustainable use of natural resources in rural Tanzania, economic development and female economic empowerment.Our beeswax candles are organic and natural. They also purify the air by releasing negative ions that eliminate pollutants and allergens. We also have many other ways to thank you for your contribution to the development of the rural Tanzanian beekeeping industry.
Tote Bags hand sewn by Singidan female entrepreneurs
Small batch organic Central Tanzanian honey
Tanzanian beekeeping photo albums
Custom trucker hats
Handmade Tanzanian top bar beehives
Sponsorship of a beehive or a beekeeping group
Personalized tour of Tanzanian beekeeping and cultural sites 

Beekeeping is the fastest and lowest cost way to double household earnings in rural Tanzania that is also socially and environmentally sustainable. 
Tanzania has over 2 million traditional artisanal beekeepers, but they suffer from lack of access to modern equipment, training, finance and markets. Tanzanian beekeeping has yet to meet its poverty-alleviating potential. 
The benefits of our intervention extend far beyond charity. We aim to demonstrate that Tanzania has the human capacity and the natural resources to sustainably and ethically produce high quality bee products. With your help we plan to show the government, development banks, exporters, retailers and financiers that investing in rural beekeeping is a win-win economically, socially and environmentally.
Who We Are

Tanganyika Apicultural Limited was founded by Olujimi (Jimi) Akindele and Philemon Kiemi. Jimi Akindele is from New York City, studied Biology and Philosophy at Stanford in California and is a Fordham Law graduate.  He first moved to Tanzania in 2011 to support private sector driven approaches to promoting renewable energy and economic development in rural Tanzania. Philemon Kiemi is a Tanzanian from Singida where he and his brothers learned beekeeping from their father while growing up on their farm. Upon graduating from Sokoine University of Agriculture Philemon Kiemi returned to Singida to train beekeepers across the region in modern beekeeping practices and to give back to his community. 

Why Are Bees So Great?
We are not the first to to promote beekeeping as a powerful and sustainable way to support rural livelihoods in the developing
world. See Bees for Development. See also another amazing crowdfunded bee project in Brazil.
Bees are not only a source of honey, wax and
propolis (what bees use to seal their hives), but they are also essential pollinators, they help plants have sex to make fruits, vegetables and nuts
for us to eat. In fact beekeeping has been shown to increase nearby agricultural yields by up to 300%.  See also another UN Report.

Through the introduction and promotion of modern beekeeping we intend to improve  agricultural yields throughout the community. In turn, beekeepers and farmers will both benefit.

In fact, a recent study has shown that for every $1 USD invested into an East African honey enterprise there are $15.48 USD in social impact returns.

Economic Impact

With your help we will train over 300 women to hand-craft candles and Kanga Totes, providing much needed income for our partners.
Currently our out grower network consists of over 400 beehives.
We have already loaned 150 beehives to youth and female rural cooperative groups.
With your help our operations  will support the
beekeeping activities of over 1500 beekeepers over the next year. 
We have reached out to  Kiva.org to expand our micro finance program, and we have partnered with a Tanzanian parastatal, SIDO (Small Industries Development Organization), as well as other governmental and NGO partners to support our processing
and packaging operations and thereby increase access to markets for beekeepers across the region.
Other Benefits:


providing a second source of income for rural women
less labor intensive than traditional beekeeping 
seasonal and part-time, allowing women to manage other responsibilities
provides economic incentive to not over-exploit forests
spurs development of related industries (carpentry, sewing, candle making, beauty and pharmaceutical products)

Once we have recruited and adequate number of beekeepers we plan to export our honey to the United States, Europe and Middle East.
Environmental
Impact
Today Tanzania’s bee product sector is in a unique
position in the world market. Its honey catchment area is free of pesticides and pollution; Tanzanian bee products are widely considered organic. Your support for our efforts will create a  financial incentive to ensure that Tanzania's bee forage areas stay pristine, healthy and safe from deforestation.
What
We Need
Your donations and purchases will allow us to:


reach out and include even more beekeepers and rural cooperatives 
invest in modern equipment to better support the rural Tanzanian beekeeping industry
obtain certifications to ensure that our products are of the highest quality, and meet the highest international ethical and environmental standards




With your help we will also be able to support the development of value added products from beekeeping. We started with candles, but we are planning to make organic soaps, sustainable skin products and eco-friendly surfboard wax.
What You Get

1. Handmade Air-Purifying Candles


Most candles today are now made of paraffin, a petroleum product, which upon burning contributes what you might expect to the environment – and your lungs! Soy-based candles are also commonly available, but are often sourced from industrialized, genetically modified crops. 
Our beeswax candles are entirely sustainable, organic and natural. They are also purify the air by releasing negative ions which remove pollutants and allergens.

Beeswax candles were originally developed by European churches during the Middle Ages. Today we are inviting you to experience the benefits of old world candle-making together with the exotic natural aromas of African beeswax!
2. The Kanga Tote



Show your colors with the “Kanga Tote”. Kanga’s are a popular clothing item in Swahili Africa (Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda), though they are thought to have originated in the Comoros Islands in the Indian Ocean. Kangas are noted for their print patterns as well as often featuring a mji or saying, e.g.:
Majivuno hayafai — Greed is never useful
Mkipendana mambo huwa sawa — Everything is all right if you love each other
Mwanamke mazingira tuanataka, usawa, amani, maendelo — We (women) want equality, peace, and progress
Our Kanga Totes are hand sewn by female entrepreneurs in Singida Tanzania. 
3. Trucker Hat


Sport your Support for Sustainable African Beekeeping with our Custom Trucker Hats!
4. Small Batch Organic Honey
We would like to thank our most committed contributors with our finest forest honey harvested from our apiaries. This honey is has a warm hazelnut brown hue and comes from the nectar of Singida’s flowering foliage: Itigi thickets, Mlonge trees, and Miombo forests.
5. Tanzanian Beekeeping Photo Album




From the shores of Lake Rukwa to the terraced hills of Moshi, enjoy an intimate view of the beekeeping practices across Tanzania with our hardcover bound photo collection of Tanzanian apiculture. 
5. Authentic Handmade Tanzanian Top-Bar Bee Hive


At Tanganyika Apicultural we are working to promote the usage of improved beehives, particularly the Tanzanian Top-Bar Hive, made from Tanzanian hardwoods. Top-bar hives are simple to install and maintain and are a fun introduction to beekeeping. Try it on your bees at home!
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_top-bar_hive#Tanzanian_top-bar_hive
http://www.motherearthnews.com/homesteading-and-livestock/keeping-bees-top-bar-beekeeping-zmaz09onzraw.aspx#axzz3Da5A89Gy
6. Sponsorship of a Beehive


With this perk you can sponsor a beehive that we will donate to one of our beginner female beekeepers.


You can personalize the hive with your name/color (Spiderman themed?...no problem. Let us know.)
You will receive a picture of the installed hive with the donee
You will have the hive's GPS coordinates and be able to track the hive's production and management via your browser and mobile app http://www.hivetracks.com/

Each year you will receive 1 Kg of Honey harvested from your sponsored beehive for 3 years


7. Sponsorship of a Beekeeping Group
You can donate 10 beehives to one of our local beekeeping groups and we can work with you to determine to which group you would like to donate 


You can personalize the hives of the apiary with your name/color

We will send you pictures and video of the apiary once the hives are installed
You will have the GPS coordinates of the hives from your apiary and will be able to track the production and management of the hives via your browser and mobile app http://www.hivetracks.com/

You will receive 10 kg  of honey yearly from your sponsored apiary for 3 years



8. A Tour of Tanzanian Beekeeping and Honey Harvesting
Come visit us for a private tour of Central Tanzanian beekeeping!




inspect and harvest hives from our outgrower network in Singida,
collect beeswax from forest communities in Tabora
visit the rock art of hunter gatherers and pastoralists who lived thousands of years ago near Kondoa (an UNESCO World Heritage Site http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1183)
visit the beekeepers of Kinyamweda and Sumbawanga
visit the Tabora Beekeeping Training Institute 



DonationsOf course we would greatly appreciate any and all donations. All donations will go to providing  beehives and protective clothing to rural female beekeeping groups.

Donations over $10 will receive a handwritten thank you.
Please remember to spread the word!
"Like" and "Share" us on Facebook!
"Follow" us on Twitter @TangApic!

story:
**********  UPDATE: THIS JUST IN, YOU ROCK! ***********

WOW!!  We are absolutely blown away with the level of support received so far! With your generosity and shared vision, we were able to sail by our initial (and vital), goal of $10K with 7 days STILL remaining in the campaign. But, because we don't play small... WE KEEP ON TRUCKIN'! 

To get even closer to our goal of 100% CARBON NEUTRALITY and the highest level of ENERGY EFFICIENCY, we're aiming high for the following goals...

  • $1500 - OUTBACK POWER INVERTER: adds more capacity to the conversion process of solar energy to usable electricity, effectively doubling our capacity to provide clean power
  • $2000 - HHO GENERATOR = A system that would integrate into our current combustion engine the to increase energy efficiency by creating and storing hydrogen as an alternative fuel source through the electrolysis of water. Basically, we would RUN THE ENGINE ON WATER!... With oxygen being the resulting emission. 
  • $500 - REPLACEMENT HYDRAULICS  for solar array walls = elevates solar paneling to achieve maximum sun exposure
  • $2000 - PERMANENTLY INTEGRATED AND INSTALLED STEREO SYSTEM to reduce event labor and increase audio and overall efficiency. 
  • $1300 -NEW TIRES / ALIGNMENT  (Because they we cover a lot of miles spreading our message!)
              ************************************************************

Our story:

We wanted to transform the current energy paradigm in a unique, fun way... 

So, we did what any sensible group of creative environmentalists would do...

We repurposed a delivery truck into a mobile, SOLAR POWERED performance venue for DJs, bands, artists and performers of all kinds.  

In 2010, our team at the GOBI Project, a community based 501c3 not-for-profit organization supporting the development of  clean energy practices, began building this outrageous, interactive experience.  In an effort to introduce the renewable energy conversation to a not the so typical audience...

We are: SolarBeatz 

Our mission, because we chose to accept it...
SolarBeatz is a unique, thought provoking, inspirational, and educational catalyst used at festivals, community events, private parties and schools to promote environmental sustainability.  
Delivery Truck turned mobile, Solar Powered spectacle and performance venue... 
And we're a (fun) clean energy source... for almost anything off the grid! 

By providing a mobile, renewable energy source for various events, private parties, concerts, and art installations, we use a hybrid of entertainment and education to inspire change and transformation existing ways of thinking in the realm of energy consumption. 

We're a community...

SolarBeatz is more than a radical, solar powered spectacle of light and sound.  We are a global community of conscious beings:  artists, innovators, environmentalists, lovers and creators of all kinds. We believe that sustainability doesn't need to sacrifice the quality of life, but rather, inherently improves it. Moreover, SolarBeatz is always CREATING community by bringing people, from all walks of life, together for a one-of-a-kind group experience. 

The Tech Specs

SolarBeatz is equipped with highly advanced solar technology, concert quality sound and lighting, and an educated, passionate crew who advances the clean-tech conversation through fun and experiential education.  

This "mobile spectacle" stimulates audiences and demonstrates the possibilities of clean energy by engaging the green conversation with the atypical audience-- and powering a massive 5000W speaker system, off the grid.  Our goal is to ultimately be 100% carbon neutral.  

But we're not there yet... 

When we originally built SolarBeatz we did so with the intention of changing the energy game and revolutionizing "green" celebrating,  We got off to a rocking' (literally and figuratively) start and were able to host solar powered parties for days at a time! 

However, after 4 years of community gatherings, parades, concerts and events the truck is getting a little tired. So tired in fact, that after the sun goes down, the excess solar energy stored in our battery bank can only power the fun for about 2 hour. Unfortunately, once that bank runs dry we turn to fossil fuels so to keep the celebrations going for everyone. Which in turn, means we are moving FURTHER away from our mission. 

The batteries, couple with a slew of other repairs and updates, are casting a grim picture of the future for SolarBeatz. We don't want to give up on our community, but we certainly don't want to continue to compromise the integrity of our mission...


It's always challenging and scary to admit to any shortcomings, but as our community we are committed to YOU and to the authenticity of our relationships. Which is why we are not going to quit, stop or stall until we fulfill our promise to provide you with carbon-conserving revelry!


What Is Needed

We’re seeking a higher level of sustainability, and to keep you dancing. We have to repair a 240W Solar Panel, update our power-flex energy converter, and replace the entire battery bank to do it. Solar energy is essential in the preservation of Earth for future generations, Creative expression is the pulse of the human spirit, and to produce results, community action is mission critical. That’s why we’re asking YOU, our community, to help us reach our full potential. Together, we can keep the sustainability conversation and celebration going long into the night.


And GREAT news!!!! Your contribution IS tax deductible because SolarBeatz is part of the Gobi Project, a registered 501c(3)!!!



Breakin' it down for folk...

SolarBeatz cannot continue to 
In order to perform the MINIMUM amount of work required to return SolarBeatz to a sun-sustained-superstar:
$10,000 is needed

  • $6000 - 24 six volt deep cycle AGM batteries ($250/battery)
  • $1000 - labor to mount batteries
  • $500 - 240W solar panel
  • $300 - labor to instal solar panel
  • $1200 - stage improvements = harsh conditions, miles and dancing bodies over four years have put some wear on our beautiful stage. Aesthetic enhancements by local artists will give Solarbeatz a permanent artistic upgrade to its physique.
  • $1000 - replacement of instrument panel (speedometer over 40mph and fuel gauge do not work)

Because we are in the business of dreaming big, pushing the envelope of our goals, and creating community in a big way...we have created a "nothing can stop us" list of NECESSARY but not vital attention items for the overall health of SolarBeatz:
  • $1300 - new tires & alignment
  • $1500 - outback power inverter which adds more capacity to the conversion process of solar energy to usable electricity, effectively doubling our capacity to provide clean power
  • $2000 - HHO generator = system that uses solar power to increase energy efficiency by creating and storing hydrogen as an alternative fuel source through the electrolysis of water
  • $500 - replacement hydraulics for array walls = elevates solar paneling to achieve maximum sun exposure
  • $2000 - permanently integrated & installed stereo system to reduce event labor and increase audio


Annual Overhead Costs for Keeping SolarBeatz running:

  • $3000 - event production, truck storage and logistics
  • $5000 - insurance premium
  • $750 - annual service minimum = oil change, fluids, rotation etc. 

The Impact

$50.00

...the cost to fill a 15 gallon tank full of gasoline

But when put towards clean photovoltaic solar energy $50 is  
the cost to save 294.6 pounds of C02 from entering the air we breath!

Risks & Challenges

Presently, our greatest risk is that to the environment.  

Though creating community space through performance, art and music is a fundamental cornerstone of our mission, SolarBeatz was built on a foundation of sustainability and alternative energy. 

Failure to meet our goal of $10,000 could put SolarBeatz temporarily out of commission, as we feel that it would be environmentally irresponsible to continue hosting the show without integrity to the cause. 

As they say in show biz..."The show MUST go on..." But we can't without your help.


Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that not everyone is in a position to make a financial contribution, and we can empathize! 

Whether you're in that boat or not, spreading the word on solar energy is a worthwhile investment and FREE! 

Contributions make a huge difference, but so does community support. Please share our campaign with your friends, family, colleagues & strangers alike through email, text, word of mouth, phone conversations, carrier pigeon, baseball signs and ESPECIALLY SOCIAL MEDIA! You can use the nifty INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS or you can copy and paste the page link into all social/digital platforms!  http://igg.me/at/solarbeatz 


Alone we go faster...

BUT TOGETHER WE GO FURTHER!

story:
Observation:

Lets see if we can manage to employ more poachers as guards! Since thanks to you we reached our goal in no time, we will use all aditional funds that come in to give more poachers a chance for change. 

In Maio we have more than 30 nesting beaches that have to patrolled, so we actually need more protectors on the beach!

Can we manage do employ a 6th poacher?

From Poacher To Protector

With the "Poacher to Protector" Initiative we plan to give sea turtle poachers an opportunity for change, by training and employing them as sea turtle protectors on Maio Island, Cape Verde, Africa.  In this campaign we wish to employ as many poachers as possible. Over the years the Maio Biodiversity Foundation (FMB) has realised that directly involving local people in turtle guarding is one of the most effective ways to stop poaching. The main cause of poaching in Maio is unemployment, and the best way to stop this is by giving them a financial alternative. In the past we have also learned that these poachers can create strong links to turtles and get passionate about them once they are involved in working for their protection. Dozens of cases of "poachers to protectors" have shown us that after a seasons work protecting turtles, seeing the mothers nest and the babies hatch,  these ex-poachers fall in love with this ancient species and become the best spokespeople for turtle conservation, telling others in their community that they will never be able to kill a turtle again.

The need to protect Maio´s turtle is urgent: In 2012 the island had the highest rates of killed females (40%) and poached nests (20%) in the country. However, in the 2013 sea turtle nesting season, FMB introduced a new conservation strategy on Maio. Turtle protection teams were placed in the coastal villages around the island and team members were hosted by local families. Their main job was to patrol turtle nesting beaches. The presence of the teams in each village was critical to raise awareness about the importance and threats to sea turtles. We also created much needed job opportunities for the community members, as a guard or host family. This combination of practical education, direct protection and a turtle friendly source of income proved to be highly effective, and resulted in a 71% reduction in the mortality of nesting female turtles and a 91% reduction in poached nests in just one season! For this amazing achievements FMB was and recently awarded with the "Grassroots Conservation Award" at the  35th International Sea Turtle Symposium in Dalaman, Turkey (April 2015) and is extremely proud to receive international recognition for its work.

By helping us create job opportunities for these people you will drastically reduce the number of turtles killed and eggs harvested this season, assuring the survival of a wonderful and charismatic endangered species, and you will help give someone the opportunity to change their life in a way that will have a deep impact on that person forever. Every year dozens of poachers come to us asking for jobs, but we always have to say that we simply do not have the money to employ them all. Lets change this, and give these people an opportunity for change.

What will happen to your donation?

Everything we receive through this campaign will go 100% to financing a guards salary. A guards salary is 200 USD per month and we wish to employ them for the whole length of the three month turtle nesting season in 2015. In this initial campaign we hope to raise 3000 USD to allow us to give five poachers from different communities an opportunity for change by employing them for the three month season. 

If we do not reach our 3000 USD goal, we will use the money to employ as many guards as the money allows. 

This campaign will generate paid jobs for previous young offenders during the turtle nesting season, providing them with an alternative to turtle poaching and an opportunity to fully integrate with our volunteer team so they will benefit from additional learning opportunities and have a real chance to change. 

The Poacher To Protector Initiative (PTP)

Ex turtle poachers will initially be trained in nest monitoring activities, hatchling release and nest camouflage and will also undergo a short course in sea turtle biology. Further on during the season, additional training will be offered, and we expect our PTP participants to voluntarily join and assist in sea turtle handling, release techniques for accidentally caught turtles, whale stranding emergency response, general marine animal identification, swimming classes, etc. They will also support other educational activities promoted by the FMB team in the village.

PTP participants will work together with the FMB team. An experienced supervisor will provide full support for the team in dealing with the ex-poachers, and will join the patrols on a regular basis to monitor and evaluate the participant’s performance and behavior and to provide support where necessary. 

The NGO: Maio Biodiversity Foundation (FMB)

Maio Biodiversity Foundation is a local NGO founded in 2010 in Maio, Cape Verde. Our mission is to preserve the fauna and flora of Maio and create opportunities and long-term benefits for its people.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for both national and international volunteers to join the patrol teams in the communities.  As a volunteer you will stay in one of the communities with a host family and share meals with them. At night you will join the local guards, team leaders and volunteers on their regular patrols of nearby beaches to guard against egg and turtle poaching. Volunteering is hard work, but extremely rewarding as you do not only experience the joys and difficulties of conservation in Africa, but you will also dive deep into African rural life by living within the local communities. Please do not hesitate to get in touch with us if you would like any further information on volunteer opportunities through Indiegogos contact or maio.volunteers@gmail.com.
story_txt:
Observation:
Lets see if we can manage to employ more poachers as guards! Since thanks to you we reached our goal in no time, we will use all aditional funds that come in to give more poachers a chance for change. 
In Maio we have more than 30 nesting beaches that have to patrolled, so we actually need more protectors on the beach!
Can we manage do employ a 6th poacher?

From Poacher To Protector
With the "Poacher to Protector" Initiative we plan to give sea turtle poachers an opportunity for change, by training and employing them as sea turtle protectors on Maio Island, Cape Verde, Africa.  In this campaign we wish to employ as many poachers as possible. Over the years the Maio Biodiversity Foundation (FMB) has realised that directly involving local people in turtle guarding is one of the most effective ways to stop poaching. The main cause of poaching in Maio is unemployment, and the best way to stop this is by giving them a financial alternative. In the past we have also learned that these poachers can create strong links to turtles and get passionate about them once they are involved in working for their protection. Dozens of cases of "poachers to protectors" have shown us that after a seasons work protecting turtles, seeing the mothers nest and the babies hatch,  these ex-poachers fall in love with this ancient species and become the best spokespeople for turtle conservation, telling others in their community that they will never be able to kill a turtle again.


The need to protect Maio´s turtle is urgent: In 2012 the island had the highest rates of killed females (40%) and poached nests (20%) in the country. However, in the 2013 sea turtle nesting season, FMB introduced a new conservation strategy on Maio. Turtle protection teams were placed in the coastal villages around the island and team members were hosted by local families. Their main job was to patrol turtle nesting beaches. The presence of the teams in each village was critical to raise awareness about the importance and threats to sea turtles. We also created much needed job opportunities for the community members, as a guard or host family. This combination of practical education, direct protection and a turtle friendly source of income proved to be highly effective, and resulted in a 71% reduction in the mortality of nesting female turtles and a 91% reduction in poached nests in just one season! For this amazing achievements FMB was and recently awarded with the "Grassroots Conservation Award" at the  35th International Sea Turtle Symposium in Dalaman, Turkey (April 2015) and is extremely proud to receive international recognition for its work.



By helping us create job opportunities for these people you will drastically reduce the number of turtles killed and eggs harvested this season, assuring the survival of a wonderful and charismatic endangered species, and you will help give someone the opportunity to change their life in a way that will have a deep impact on that person forever. Every year dozens of poachers come to us asking for jobs, but we always have to say that we simply do not have the money to employ them all. Lets change this, and give these people an opportunity for change.







What will happen to your donation?
Everything we receive through this campaign will go 100% to financing a guards salary. A guards salary is 200 USD per month and we wish to employ them for the whole length of the three month turtle nesting season in 2015. In this initial campaign we hope to raise 3000 USD to allow us to give five poachers from different communities an opportunity for change by employing them for the three month season. 
If we do not reach our 3000 USD goal, we will use the money to employ as many guards as the money allows. 
This campaign will generate paid jobs for previous young offenders during the turtle nesting season, providing them with an alternative to turtle poaching and an opportunity to fully integrate with our volunteer team so they will benefit from additional learning opportunities and have a real chance to change. 



The Poacher To Protector Initiative (PTP)


Ex turtle poachers will initially be trained in nest monitoring activities, hatchling release and nest camouflage and will also undergo a short course in sea turtle biology. Further on during the season,
additional training will be offered, and we expect our PTP
participants to voluntarily join and assist in sea turtle handling, release
techniques for accidentally caught turtles, whale stranding emergency response, general marine animal identification, swimming classes, etc. They will also support
other educational activities promoted by the FMB team in the village.
PTP participants will
work together with the FMB team. An experienced supervisor will provide full support for the team in
dealing with the ex-poachers, and will join the patrols on a regular basis to
monitor and evaluate the participant’s performance and behavior and to
provide support where necessary. 


The NGO: Maio Biodiversity Foundation (FMB)


Maio Biodiversity Foundation is a local NGO founded in 2010 in Maio, Cape Verde. Our mission is to preserve the fauna and flora of Maio and create opportunities and long-term benefits for its people.

We are always looking for both national and international volunteers to join the patrol teams in the communities.  As a volunteer you will stay in one of the communities with a host family and share meals with them.
