story:
Short Summary

SERV International exist to give people the opportunity to make a difference through FOOD | WATER | SHELTER | LIFE. Our feeding programs open the door to build relationships with villages such as Nabuskaal. What makes SERV different is we don't stop there. We build relationships and connections with these communities to provided resources they need to provide for themselves. We are going to drill a well in this village. It is a 2 hour drive from the closest town, and a 10 mile walk from the nearest water source. We estimate it to cost $25,000 of which we have $5,000 already. Join our campaign to raise the other $20,000 to end the generations of people walking 10 miles for dirty river water. 

What We Need 

We need your help to raise the remaining $20,000 to drill a well in the Northwest desert of Kenya. Once we have the initial survey we will have a breakdown of funds to share. But from our previous wells the initial estimate is $25,000

The Impact

More than 1.1 billion people in developing countries have inadequate access to water and over 2.6 billion lack basic sanitation. 

We have successfully drilled 3 wells in other similar villages and are looking forward to the 4th.  

You can make a difference in the lives of this village. Any donation helps and sharing this campaigns brings awareness to the desperate needs of these people. 

The Perks

Instead of giving away gifts in exchange for donations, we are using the money that would of been spent on gifts towards this much needed well. Your perk is, clean water to those that live without.

story:
The Power of a Playground

WaterPowerPeace’s centerpiece is an innovative playground that pumps clean water and generates electricity to use for lights, irrigation, charging stations and other important classroom aids.

Schools and students are brought together in a sister school cultural exchange. A school in the United States works together with their sister school, which can be a school anywhere in the world that lacks access to clean drinking water and power.  Students learn about:

  • the cultures,
  • the world water crisis,
  • the science of water and clean water technology,
  • the science of the amazing playground,
  • conversion of kinetic energy, and
  • alternative energy sources used in the playground like wind and solar power.

Students then raise money to bring the playground to the sister school. Additional work between the schools includes visits, teacher exchanges, planting orchards and gardens using water from the new playground, building classrooms, and more.

The project began with an initial grant from the Sabre Companies LLC, who invented, designed and built the playground.

How will the Money Be Used This Summer?

In July two members of WaterPowerPeace (WPP) will travel to Babati, Tanzania and spend five weeks acquiring materials for the irrigation system to be installed at the Sinai Primary School and begin planting seedlings and will then begin work on a book of photographs, interviews and the culture of Babati to be published and sold to help raise funds for installation of the playground.

In August a group engineers, teachers and students will join the first team.  Together they will plant the orchards and gardens now possible due to team efforts of the previous two years.  Engineers will teach all students and others in the community how to build a hand pump from scratch, and install drip irrigation lines and rainwater catch systems.  Students from the US will build a library to house the books they are bringing so that students can continue reading and improving their English which is required for Tanzanian students to advance to secondary school.

This fundraising effort is primarily for airfare, visas, local travel and expenses for the two member team spending five weeks in Babati this summer.  Any monies collected in excess of our goal, will be put toward the same for the second team arriving in August.  Beyond that funds will go directly toward installation of the playground in Babati next summer.

Donations

The Play for Power Fund is used to support the WaterPowerPeace curriculum and to build the playgrounds at the sister school and here in the United States so that many more schools can join the curriculum. The net proceeds of this Crowd Funding will be contributed to the Play for Power Fund of The Community Foundation for the Greater Capital Region, Inc.

The gifts for $500 donations will be acquired specially for you while in Babati this summer.  Please allow 6 weeks for delivery of these gift.

Other Ways You Can Help

Those of you unable to contribute at this time can still help by helping us spread the word about this project using Facebook, Twitter, your blog and email.  Links are provided below to help you, help us make some noise!

For More Information

Please visit us at www.WaterPowerPeace.org

story:
Did you miss our campaing? For news and orering info: goto www.WIKISPEED.org

--- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---

High resolution photos for press download here. For press inquiries, please contact info@WIKISPEED.com. Follow WIKISPEED on twitter@WIKISPEED and on Facebook.

What if the car you drove to work every day got 100 mpg?

Ignite the future of automotive transportation with WIKISPEED, the modular 100 mpg car company. With our 150 person global team, we are using the technology we developed to compete in the X Prize and our functional road-going prototypes as the launchpad to bring ultra-efficient, modular cars to the world with the 100 mpg Comfortable Commuter Car, the WIKISPEED C3. We aim to deliver the C3 as a complete car for $17,995 and as a kit for $10,000; we need your backing to make that possible.

We have 150 team members in 15 countries to help get this done.

Currently we have working prototypes of each part that makes up the ultra efficient, ultra-low emissions, gasoline powered C3. The car is designed and manufactured in eight parts. We need to enhance each piece from prototype to production-ready part. Enhancing each part costs us right about $50,000 in prototyping tools, materials, and testing fees. We've set the launch minimum for this project at $50,000 (+5% to Indiegogo) to enable us to evolve our test chassis to the C3 chassis, the foundation of our C3 and the future of automotive manufacturing. When we pass that initial fundraising goal, every subsequent dollar goes to improving the engine module from prototype to C3 level—and so on for all eight modules. You are enabling us to deliver a fully tested, safe, and fun 100 mpg commuter car.

Here's what your dollars build:

Your money will specifically fund (1) ten additional crash tests, (2) fuel-efficiency testing, (3) materials for prototyping and testing, (4) expert reviews and fabrication, and (5) the additional tools required to make the future of automotive transportation happen right now. WIKISPEED is a registered automotive manufacturer and able to deliver complete vehicles in the United States and kits globally. Let's take ultra-efficient modular prototypes to the mainstream. Let's help the environment, reduce everyone's cost at the gas pump, and revolutionize automotive manufacturing. Let's drive WIKISPEED!

Want to drive to work at 100 mpg?

Our prototypes are available now for $25k, but aren't yet weather-tight and have few convenience featres. With the funds from this campaign we'll going to see if it is even possible to deliver a version of the car that can be built as a kit for $10,000, and we'll absolutely offer the C3 kit direct through Crowd Funding! You are REVOLUTIONIZING AUTOMOTIVE MANUFACTURING by supporitng this campaign!

story:
Hello from Scotland! My name is Evan Williams and I would like to ask for your help to defeat climate deniers and reveal the truth about the climate crisis.


After seeing Al Gore’s climate change documentary An Inconvenient Truth in 2006, I knew I had to get involved personally, to do my part to help solve the climate crisis. I learned about Mr. Gore’s non-profit group, now called The Climate Reality Project, and quickly volunteered my time and effort to educating people about the causes of and solutions to the climate crisis. In 2007, I was trained by Mr. Gore to deliver his slideshow from An Inconvenient Truth and since then I have delivered more than 200 presentations to all types of people in my community.


My son Michael has also gotten involved! We enjoy giving the slideshow presentation together – it’s a great experience for us and our audiences hear perspectives from both of our generations. I’m proud that my son is following in my footsteps – his dedication to helping solve the climate crisis by educating others really makes me feel good about our future.


On September 15, I’ll be participating in the 24 Hours of Reality event, created by The Climate Reality Project and Al Gore. 24 Climate Presenters from around the world, one in every time zone, will deliver a new slideshow from Mr. Gore that focuses on the link between extreme weather and climate change.


I’ll be presenting this slideshow in London, a city vulnerable to flooding as sea level rises, tidal surges in the North Sea increase in height, and winter rainfall increases in volume and intensity — putting more than 1 million people and nearly half a million properties at risk. Ironically, London is also considered to be one of the driest capital cities in the world. While climate change will likely bring heavier rainstorms to London, the total amount of rainfall in a year will also decrease, increasing the probability of drought during summer months.


I hope you’ll “tune” in. The slideshow is fantastic and I can’t wait to share it.


Why I’m asking:

Since 2006, Al Gore has trained more than 3,000 volunteer activists like me from around the world to deliver updated versions of the slideshow featured in An Inconvenient Truth. These Climate Presenters have delivered more than 70,000 climate presentations and reached a global audience in excess of 7.3 million people!


Climate Presenters are on the front-lines, educating people around the world at a peer-to-peer level every day about the science and impacts of climate change, and they are helping us expand the global movement of people working together to solve the climate crisis. 


I’d like to ask for your contribution of $25 or more to support Climate Reality’s efforts to continue to train Climate Presenters. With your gift, you’ll help Climate Presenters like me give presentations all over the world, building a movement of people who care about climate change. Plus, your donation will be tax-deductible if it is made via PayPal.


More about me:

In my day job, I see the impacts of climate change, too, which inspires me to continue working hard with The Climate Reality Project to make sure people around the world learn about the crisis and how we can all work together to solve it. I’m an environmental economist and consultant and I live in Paisley, a town near Glasgow, Scotland. I previously worked for the Scottish Environment Protection Agency, where I was Head of Economics and Sustainable Development. In 2008, I started my own environmental consulting firm, Environmental and Resource Economics, and partnered with the Prince of Wales for the Princess Rainforest Project.


More information about the 24 Hours of Reality event, from The Climate Reality Project:

Spanning 24 hours, 24 time zones and 13 languages, 24 Hours of Reality features a new multimedia presentation from Vice President Al Gore that will make the reality of climate change impossible to ignore. This new presentation will be delivered by Vice President Gore and an elite corps of Climate Presenters from around the world, including Evan Williams from the U.K.


Beginning in Mexico City on September 14 and proceeding westward around the globe, 24 Hours of Reality will offer a snapshot of the global climate crisis from Tonga to Cape Verde, Auckland to Rio, Jakarta to London. With one event scheduled in each time zone at 7 p.m. local time, the entire 24 hours will be streamed live online and will include commentary from scientists, elected leaders, business leaders, celebrities and activists.

 

Other ways you can help:

Join us for 24 Hours of Reality! Visit our website and RSVP on Facebook to show the world what can change in a day.

story:
UPDATE: #abambooproject article is being picked up by blogs,like: Made in the USA Challenge!!  and our fan base is growing. We have also loaded the new a bamboo project introduction video to this page. To view a more comprehensive video of the project video; please visit our project media page or our You Tube Channel.

TY for your growing support of A Bamboo Project!

Help fund a 2 acre parcel of land, greenhouse, laboratory, and processing center for research and development of cleaner processing methods, and potential uses for bamboo! You’ll get some really cool bamboo products for doing it and feel GREAT about yourself. You can think of it as an investment to lower the price of bamboo products, while helping the environment and LOCAL businesses providing the perks. 

Lower the PRICE of Bamboo products?

YES lower the price. Not to mention the environmental impact a container ship has releasing enough CO2 for 50 million cars. Here is the proof.. A U.S. company pays $.50-$1.50  for a bamboo towel (see alibaba.com)  you pay $36.00 from a U.S. retailer

WHY the HUGE markup? Well there are a lot of people to be paid in your products journey. Shipping is anywhere from $3,000-$6,000 dollars. Then there are customs, brokers, warehousing, and salesmen that all need to make money resulting in the $36.00 towel. If bamboo is sourced here, the “middlemen” and transportation affects are WIPED OUT. As a benefit you will also be saving our environment, creating jobs, and find additional uses for this wonder plant. After considering all the different factors when ordering from China; the United States can afford to be competitive.

This proof of concept is all that is needed to acquire second round grants and funding already committed to the project. You will help us become a local supplier to U.S. companies already producing bamboo flooring, clothing, skateboards, surfboards, diapers, and other products! You are lowering the price you pay for bamboo, ensure it is harvested RESPONSIBLY, move jobs back to the U.S. that already exist in China and UNLOCK the potential for bamboo bio fuels, bio mass, medicines, bio char, bio plastics and other products identified so far.

From there we go to a lease/purchase model of parcels of land with existing bamboo growing, and take advantage of the requests to ‘clear bamboo’ from private and public lands. WHile starting bamboo farms from scratch. We immediately service U.S. companies manufacturing bamboo products. If they aren’t that fast, we manufacture wood pellets for use as bio mass in the EU and this project is profitable from the start. All that is missing is the front end investment. All that is missing is YOUR help and commitment to green.

WHY??

The U.S. currently has a tremendous imbalance of trade even as we import over 50 million dollars a year worth of bamboo shoots, poles, furniture, flooring, and other products.

We also have: massive unemployment, many abandoned small farms, overburdened landfills, organic waste disposal issues, receding water tables and diminishing water quality, severe soil erosion, material shortfalls, inequitable land distribution, worsening air pollution, etc.

Americans Need Jobs. Building a domestic bamboo industry from the ground up creates jobs. Cleaner, greener, and with the promise of cleaning up our soil, air and water. That's Bamboo. 

The only roadblock is the political support and front end investment. Through the bamboo project, our goal is with your help, we will begin the bamboo industry here and now through the acquisition of land already growing Bamboo, setup of a bamboo processing center, and the setup of a bamboo research and development center. 

 

Why Bamboo??

Bamboo is extremely versatile and already has made an impact worldwide. This plant is truly green. This plant is totally sustainable. This plant has a use in every industry. Popularity is growing every year. Imagine a plant growing up to 100 feet tall, being cut down and replenishing itself in 45 days. 

I realize this is a spectacular claim. I know many will tell me the jury is still out. However, let us look at the facts:

  1. Bamboo is one of the fastest growing plants on the planet. Bamboo can grow up to 2 feet per day and over 90 feet tall in one season.
  2. Bamboo sequesters 35% more Co2 than trees.
  3. Bamboo requires only one third of the water than cotton does. There is much less carbon associated with growing bamboo such as operating tractors in harvesting and maintenance than cotton. Unless American cotton can be genetically engineered to plant and pick itself, the cotton industry in America faces a dismal future.
  4. Bamboo has no natural pests. Therefore, NO PESTICIDES.
  5. Bamboo filters soil of contaminants and prevents soil erosion. Something we can use in the Gulf region prone to oil spills and still reeling from the effects of the BP Oil Spill.
  6. Bamboo is flexible. It can be used in virtually any application such as bike frames, domes, and other products.
  7. Bamboo is leterally stronger than steel and more durable than wood. It can be used as a composite, structural beams, flooring, scaffolding, supports, housing, car frames, and concrete reinforcement.
  8. Bamboo is being used for clothing. Bamboo is soft, and anti-bacterial, it acts like a sponge whisking perspiration away from the skin.
  9. Over 1.5 BILLION people use bamboo worldwide. Trade is worth over 5 billion per year and rising.
  10. The United States is the LARGEST IMPORTER of Bamboo.

Young seedlings cannot be imported into the United States unless they remain in quarantine for one year. These rules have prevented the supply of young plants to establish bamboo forests. This plant only flowers every 30 to 120 years, depending on the species. Companies like Booshoot in Seattle, Washington have conquered this obstacle by inventing new ways to propagate bamboo. These methods have proved to be the foundation of the Bamboo industry in the United States via projects like this and others.

Today with the renewed push towards greener solutions, bamboo is once again being considered. And with good reason- It is also growing in population as more consumers become eco-conscious.

But Bamboo has received some bad press.

Some of the methods used to breakdown bamboo to fiber are dirty. VERY chemically toxic. This is not the ONLY method used. Mechanically crushing the bamboo is also an option and we have another option. Steam.

Bamboo has also been accused of being an intrusive plant. There are 2 types of bamboo, runners and clumpers. Clumping bamboo does not spread. Running bamboo can be easily controlled via conventional methods or simple mad made divisions. 

Bamboo can transform abandoned lands into working farms, and the current demand for bamboo is endless. Bamboo as an industry can create tons of thousands of jobs here in the U.S.

We know this for a fact.

These jobs exist in China serving OUR DEMAND. I mean that there are tens of thousands of workers in China and other countries whose daily work is harvesting or producing bamboo products for the United States market. Doesn’t this seem foolish to you? You haven’t even heard the punch line yet. This bamboo is being obtained from OVER harvested bamboo plantations. The consequences of this for the China environment are disastrous.

From harvesting to production, bamboo creates jobs in industries across the board in the U.S.

Retrofitting cotton harvesting equipment is easy and inexpensive. Everyone knows farmers must diversify. Bamboo as a crop has a market, and produces yields many times over that of current agriculture. It also shares a multi-industry demand, so bamboo is not dependent on one customer. While bamboo is a food, it does not compete as a food stock in the U.S. It is a safe crop.

 

Today Bamboo is used in a variety of products at the same time what is known about bamboo and its true potential is in its infancy.

Our goal is to help this process along and quickly. We will achieve bamboo enlightenment through a very simple business model.

Bamboo library: We have been compiling information on everything Bamboo, we have posted 10% on the internet so far. This library is already the largest collection of bamboo related materials and will contibute to grow for ALL to use. Please see #abambooproject.

We have studied and implemented these findings in many of our production and agriculture plans. We have created new systems, closed loop manufacturing systems, and clean breakdown processes utilizing steam. 

We can't wait to uncover more. 

Bamboo acquisition: in the southern U.S. bamboo grows wild. Public lands, and private land owners are willing to give us this timber. They call, we haul type of scenario. Or in some cases, we may lease or purchase the land. Remember, bamboo is renewable. It can replenish itself in as little as 45 days so our supply chain is readily available.

From there the bamboo is hauled to our processing center. Our processing center is envisioned at 5,000 sq. ft. to begin with, Expanding as our bamboo efforts grow.

In order to support growth we will begin manufacturing products that are already in demand and involve the least amount of handling. For example:

Biomass:  Demand for biomass, most commonly in the form of wood pellets that can easily be transported, has leapt since the EU in 2007 set its 2020 climate goals.

Fiber or Pulp: Used by the paper industry to offset their demand on forests, this use of bamboo is gaining rapid attention.

Wood for consumer products: Flooring, skateboards, kitchen utensils, surfboards, furniture and other items. All are made with bamboo and imported every day. We can supply these companies manufacturing these products in the U.S.  For those companies that import these products are making green claims, the pressure will mount not only by the consumer questioning their greenness, but as the cost of transportation continues to rise, domestically sourced bamboo will become more cost efficient.

That equals more factories and MORE JOBS!

It’s important to emphasize what I just explained…Through locally sourcing our own materials and selling the bamboo to the industries requiring the least amount of manufacturing makes this project profitable from the start.

This finances the development of new “open source” methods and technologies and thus begins the explosion of bamboo into a U.S. industry. Additionally, we have second round financing ready once the pilot project is done. That's where we need YOUR help. From the popularity of the issue gaining more political support to every dollar raised you are bringing real awareness to the US acgriculture industry which is suffering due to drought, and bad political policy. This puts farmers to work, can reverse effects of global warming, and supply our needs SUSTAINABLY. 

Research and Development Center will consist of 2 acres of land, one small building, and a greenhouse. It is where the breakthroughs will occur, where the results of those breakthroughs will be shared with universities and industry.

 Our research will include:

  1. Bamboo pyrolysis. (Turning bamboo into an energy source by basically baking it similar to how a clay pot is made.)
  2. Bamboo Charcoal as a filter for industrial and home application. Power plants and coal factories are already considering bamboo charcoal as a method of capturing pollutants being emitted.
  3. Bamboo fibers. These fibers are already being currently used as textiles used in clothes, and linens, as fiber for toilet tissue, paper, and various other paper products as ‘pulp’.
  4. Bamboo processing. Bamboo is a very heavy and woody plant. We have pioneered methods in clean processing utilizing stream, but there are others that show the promise of a more efficient system of processing. Replicating the digestive system of the Panda is one. Recently, universities started trying to identify the digestive enzyme that processes bamboo in pandas. Bamboo is 90 percent of a panda’s diet.
  5. Bamboo as a construction material. There are several types of structural beams, plywood, flooring, doors and other building products made of bamboo on the market.  However, in many respects these materials are higher priced than their wood counterparts. We want to see the products affordable by all.

While Bamboo is growing very popular in the U.S. it is still a somewhat segmented and niche following. Your help will bring the issue mainstream, with every job created in the U.S. bamboo proves itself. We hope and believe a good idea has merit just because people like you deem it worthy. We believe you will see that merit in this wonderplant. Please visit Abambooproject  for much more information and if you have ANY questions please contact me.

The Perks:

This was a perplexing problem. What to offer, then it hit us.. What better way to show you the benefits of bamboo and a local economy than offering Bamboo products from local resources!?!

 

ALL PERK PACKAGES INCLUDE:  A thank you and your name on the bamboo Library wall. Your name included in the Bamboo Industry for the U.S. Registry. This registry will be utilized in many petition and campaign pushes for tax incentives, and subsidies to further provide incentives for farmers and offset the initial losses during first planting to harvest.

 Right to left: Do The BOO T-shirt/Sweatshirt, Bamboozing wine accessory kit, Boo Book Bamboo Notebook, Bamboo IPad case, Foudner Package entrance wall. 

L. Bamboo iZen bluetooth bamboo keyboard, R. Imagine Bamboo pendant

We look forward to hearing from you. With every share, every dollar, every like or tweet you are helping us get the bamboo industry off the ground in the United States, and making a big difference on the environment. As our research continues, and already existing products are a lower cost, the popularity of Bamboo will continue to grow, and the demand will be met by local growers, made in U.S. factories, and help America toward a greener future. 

Thank for checking out #A Bamboo Project!
story_txt:
UPDATE: #abambooproject article is being picked up by blogs,like: Made in the USA Challenge!!  and our fan base is growing. We have also loaded the new a bamboo project introduction video to this page. To view a more comprehensive video of the project video; please visit our project media page or our You Tube Channel.
TY for your growing support of A Bamboo Project!

Help fund a 2 acre parcel of land, greenhouse, laboratory, and processing center for research and development of cleaner processing methods, and potential uses for bamboo! You’ll get some really cool bamboo products for doing it and feel GREAT about yourself. You can think of it as an investment to lower the price of bamboo products, while helping the environment and LOCAL businesses providing the perks. Lower the PRICE of Bamboo products?YES lower the price. Not to mention the environmental impact a container ship has releasing enough CO2 for 50 million cars. Here is the proof.. A U.S. company pays $.50-$1.50  for a bamboo towel (see alibaba.com)  you pay $36.00 from a U.S. retailer

WHY the HUGE markup? Well there are a lot of people to be paid in your products journey. Shipping is anywhere from $3,000-$6,000 dollars. Then there are customs, brokers, warehousing, and salesmen that all need to make money resulting in the $36.00 towel. If bamboo is sourced here, the “middlemen” and transportation affects are WIPED OUT. As a benefit you will also be saving our environment, creating jobs, and find additional uses for this wonder plant. After considering all the different factors when ordering from China; the United States can afford to be competitive.
This proof of concept is all that is needed to acquire second round grants and funding already committed to the project. You will help us become a local supplier to U.S. companies already producing bamboo flooring, clothing, skateboards, surfboards, diapers, and other products! You are lowering the price you pay for bamboo, ensure it is harvested RESPONSIBLY, move jobs back to the U.S. that already exist in China and UNLOCK the potential for bamboo bio fuels, bio mass, medicines, bio char, bio plastics and other products identified so far.
From there we go to a lease/purchase model of parcels of land with existing bamboo growing, and take advantage of the requests to ‘clear bamboo’ from private and public lands. WHile starting bamboo farms from scratch. We immediately service U.S. companies manufacturing bamboo products. If they aren’t that fast, we manufacture wood pellets for use as bio mass in the EU and this project is profitable from the start. All that is missing is the front end investment. All that is missing is YOUR help and commitment to green.

story:
Who Are We

Hello my name is Lauren, I am a student at Wilfrid Laurier University in the Business program.  I am involved with the University of Waterloo Alternative Fuels team (UWAFT), a group comprised of undergraduate and graduate students from the University of Waterloo and Wilfrid Laurier University.  UWAFT’s primary mandate is to research, design and implement advanced vehicle technologies into existing gasoline-powered vehicle platforms. In addition to technical research and development, UWAFT educates the public about alternative fuels and hybrid technologies, while raising environmental awareness through public outreach events and social media.

We are currently participating in the EcoCAR 2: Plugging In to the Future competition, in which students are challenged with the goal of reducing the environmental impact of a Chevrolet Malibu without compromising performance, safety or consumer acceptability. I feel extremely blessed to be surrounded by teammates that share the same passion and enthusiasm for innovative design. UWAFT encourages knowledge and innovative thought in order to promote a more sustainable future, but we need your help!

For more information on UWAFT and the EcoCAR competition, please refer to the following links:

UWAFT Website

UWAFT Facebook Page

EcoCAR 2 Website

How YOU Can Help Us Reach Our Goals

EcoCar2 is a three-year collegiate engineering competition with 14 other universities across North America competing. The competition’s mission is a vital one: offer an unparalleled hands-on experience to educate the next generation of automotive engineers. With a preliminary 3rd overall rank placement after the first year, we would like to offer you the opportunity to become involved with our project. Our challenge is to reduce the environmental impact of a Chevrolet Malibu without compromising performance, safety and consumer acceptability while educating the public about alternative fuels and hybrid technologies and raising environmental awareness. 

This is the second year of the three-year project and our goal is to turn the designs made in the first year into a reality. 

The money we raise goes towards funding the EcoCar project and building the car. You can be secure in the knowledge that your donation will be used to help change the world, and create an environmentally sustainable car. Every little penny helps us get a little closer to our goal! We have several perks to reward our supporters ranging from gift cards to up close and personal interactions with the engineers and competition car!

In the event that we do not reach our $5,000 goal the money raised will go towards acquiring technologies or tools that will benefit not only UWAFT but the University of Waterloo student body as a whole. All technology obtained by UWAFT are shared with other clubs and students, enabling their innovative juices to flow!

The Impact

UWAFT is a student team that draws upon top engineering and business students from the University of Waterloo and Wilfrid Laurier University to design and build the green car of tomorrow. Our goals also include educating the public about alternative fuels and hybrid technologies and raising environmental awareness. EcoCar 2 is a very comprehensive competition, with deliverables in outreach and public awareness. We are very active in elementary schools and attend a number of green energy events in the Waterloo-Kitchener area.

The Breakdown

For a clear picture of what your contribution with will used toward, please refer to the breakdown provided. It should be noted that these are approximate amounts and that fluctuations in spending may vary.

Outreach Programs (25%) ~ $1250

Acquiring Car Parts (40%) ~ $2000

Technical Services (35%) ~ $1750

Other Ways You Can Help

Financial contribution might not be an option for all but please support this campaign either way by spreading the word and making some noise about our campaign. Also, don’t forget to check out our events page and come out to show your support for UWAFT! Remember use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out there.

Thank you for your support and interest in UWAFT and EcoCAR2!

story:
What's Blooming?

"Blooming in the Water" is a film about the hostile silence that has descend on all that's happening in Fukushima nuclear plant after the 11th of March 2011.

The silence is equal a lie, if it is a silence about the radioactive waste in the water - the womb of life of this planet.

The silence is equal to killing, if it is meant to cover up how unlivable the region has become after the tragedy.

Documentary: what will it look like?

This is a documentary about a fisherman, who is  living on the coast of the sea, wakes up to go fishing each morning, feeds the family with the fish he brings, selling or giving all that remains out to others. It’s the routine of his life, the routine of the life of his father, a life that’s been carried out by many generations beforehand.  A routine that's continuing for ages, yet after the Fukushima disaster that resulted in the radioactive waste spills in the water everything is different, as it was different for Chernobyl. A deafening silence in the face of a tragedy is, for the least, disquieting.


Every day voyage of this fisherman – the waking up, the dressing up, him picking up the nests, taking the boat and going to the sea, nothing would be different. There’s only the thought of an inevitable – the life in the post-nuclear world – that is threatening, while watching the towers of the Plant steadfast under the grey monotony of the sky.


While the fisherman lives on, the people continue whispering brutal stories about some that have never come back after going to another shift in the Plant after the tragedy, stories about children getting strange diseases, about the soil that’s now growing poisonous plants and the sea that hides a tragedy.

Yes, but why? A brief motivation

On the 11th of March 2011 I had this deafening silence in my head, just after I read what happened in Japan. I have a musician friend there, him and his wife were showing no signs of life for ten days. Afterwards they informed me that they are safe in a faraway island.
In those ten days a song started in my head, I recorded it and we mixed it together with that friend of mine (here's a link to it: http://snd.sc/viENu1 ). It was one of the three moments in my life that I got to realize we've got no time to lose.

Until August I tried to follow the events to know if they are to clean the environment and to somehow take care of peoples’ lives. There was little information from the governmental sources in Japan, and the little that seemed objective was minuscule particles of information from independent researchers. I remember an article that said that one of the measures taken by the government to “tackle” the problem was to raise the allowed amount of the radioactive particles for children. Not bad for “tackling” I suppose.

In the end everything comes down to simple mathematics: radioactive particles are descending into the soil and with the rain and underground waters go straight into the ocean, where they remaining on the algae, that are being eaten by small fish, that are being eaten by bigger fish, that are being eaten by the biggest ones, till the end of the line where there is every one of us. We are water.

I know there is a lot going on to clean the surface if the Island as well as to clean the water and to make the environment livable. Yet somehow in all these months there was too much silence from the official sources about what's going on and how things are being resolved.

I know that I have to try and move this issue - and I want to make it a documentary, a universal language of moving pictures.

The Impact

The impact I'd hope for would be the global awareness. The tragedy happened, but it is already so far from everything we do in our daily life. One checks over the daily news - it does not exist anymore. So I thought, in-between all those report-like and research-style documentaries, a poetic documentary on the tragedy could have its place.

With the help of all you, hopefully, the documentary will travel the globe. It will sure end up on the screen, be presented on the DVD and will be screened at schools all over, I'll make sure to to make it happen with a little help of those who find it a right cause.

What We Need & What You Get

I've summed up that a 15000 USD support would be enough to get it going and done. The main part of the costs - I believe more than a half - will be the travel. At this point I'm planning to be able to do it on one trip that could have a duration of one month or more (location search, permissions, etc.), where I should be taking an assistant sound engineer along. So the rest would go for the equipment rental, assistant's salary, translator's help, the post production equipment (editing room basically), DVD editor, communication expenses (DVD printing etc.).

During the preparation period I will send out some applications to national and Japanese institutions that could be interested to contribute to the film. I will also seek for some producer or production company that would give me a hand to distribute the film.

The incentives

During the stay in Japan I will do a video-diary of how things are being done, and the access to these video online will be one of the incentives for the supporters of the film. With some others, I will share the soundtrack and/or the parts of the soundtrack of the film. The DVDs of the film will be available to others and everyone will have his or hers name in the "thank you" line on the facebook page of the project as well as in the end titles of the film.

Other Ways You Can Help

If everyone would share a word or two about the project with all the folks they know, together, we would make it to raise enough funds and to spread the word. Use Twitter, Facebook, word-of-mouth at the dinner table, anything does.
It would be great if there would be someone out there that would care to organize the screening events (on the completion of the DVD) in their school, town, community house etc. That would make it have a tour around the globe and perhaps make some real impact.
If by any chance there would be someone from Japan that would like to participate in the project while being there as a translator, a supporter, a guide, please do not hesitate to get in touch, your participation will be highly appreciated!!
story_txt:
What's Blooming?

"Blooming in the Water" is a film about the
hostile silence that has descend on all that's happening in Fukushima nuclear
plant after the 11th of March 2011. 
The silence is equal a lie, if it is a silence about the
radioactive waste in the water - the womb of life of this planet. 

The silence is equal to killing,
if it is meant to cover up how unlivable the region has become after the
tragedy.


Documentary: what will it look like?

This is a documentary about a fisherman, who is  living on the coast of the sea, wakes up to
go fishing each morning, feeds the family with the fish he brings, selling or
giving all that remains out to others. It’s the routine of his life, the
routine of the life of his father, a life that’s been carried out by many
generations beforehand.  A routine that's
continuing for ages, yet after the Fukushima disaster that resulted in the
radioactive waste spills in the water everything is different, as it was
different for Chernobyl. A deafening silence in the face of a tragedy is, for
the least, disquieting.

Every day voyage of this fisherman – the waking up, the
dressing up, him picking up the nests, taking the boat and going to the sea,
nothing would be different. There’s only the thought of an inevitable – the
life in the post-nuclear world – that is threatening, while watching the towers
of the Plant steadfast under the grey monotony of the sky. 

While the fisherman lives on, the people continue whispering
brutal stories about some that have never come back after going to another
shift in the Plant after the tragedy, stories about children getting strange
diseases, about the soil that’s now growing poisonous plants and the sea that
hides a tragedy.
Yes, but why? A brief motivation
On the 11th of March 2011 I had this deafening silence in my head, just after I read what happened in Japan. I have a musician friend there, him and his wife were showing no signs of life for ten days. Afterwards they informed me that they are safe in a faraway island. In those ten days a song started in my head, I recorded it and we mixed it together with that friend of mine (here's a link to it: http://snd.sc/viENu1 ). It was one of the three moments in my life that I got to realize we've got no time to lose. Until August I tried to follow the events to know if they are to clean the environment and to somehow take care of peoples’ lives. There was little information from the governmental sources in Japan, and the little that seemed objective was minuscule particles of information from independent researchers. I remember an article that said that one of the measures taken by the government to “tackle” the problem was to raise the allowed amount of the radioactive particles for children. Not bad for “tackling” I suppose. In the end everything comes down to simple mathematics: radioactive particles are descending into the soil and with the rain and underground waters go straight into the ocean, where they remaining on the algae, that are being eaten by small fish, that are being eaten by bigger fish, that are being eaten by the biggest ones, till the end of the line where there is every one of us. We are water.I know there is a lot going on to clean the surface if the Island as well as to clean the water and to make the environment livable. Yet somehow in all these months there was too much silence from the official sources about what's going on and how things are being resolved. I know that I have to try and move this issue - and I want to make it a documentary, a universal language of moving pictures. The Impact
The impact I'd hope for would be the global awareness. The tragedy happened, but it is already so far from everything we do in our daily life. One checks over the daily news - it does not exist anymore. So I thought, in-between all those report-like and research-style documentaries, a poetic documentary on the tragedy could have its place. 
With the help of all you, hopefully, the documentary will travel the globe. It will sure end up on the screen, be presented on the DVD and will be screened at schools all over, I'll make sure to to make it happen with a little help of those who find it a right cause.

What We Need & What You GetI've summed up that a 15000 USD support would be enough to get it going and done. The main part of the costs - I believe more than a half - will be the travel. At this point I'm planning to be able to do it on one trip that could have a duration of one month or more (location search, permissions, etc.), where I should be taking an assistant sound engineer along. So the rest would go for the equipment rental, assistant's salary, translator's help, the post production equipment (editing room basically), DVD editor, communication expenses (DVD printing etc.).During the preparation period I will send out some applications to national and Japanese institutions that could be interested to contribute to the film. I will also seek for some producer or production company that would give me a hand to distribute the film. The incentivesDuring the stay in Japan I will do a video-diary of how things are being done, and the access to these video online will be one of the incentives for the supporters of the film. With some others, I will share the soundtrack and/or the parts of the soundtrack of the film. The DVDs of the film will be available to others and everyone will have his or hers name in the "thank you" line on the facebook page of the project as well as in the end titles of the film.

Other Ways You Can HelpIf everyone would share a word or two about the project with all the folks they know, together, we would make it to raise enough funds and to spread the word. Use Twitter, Facebook, word-of-mouth at the dinner table, anything does.It would be great if there would be someone out there that would care to organize the screening events (on the completion of the DVD) in their school, town, community house etc. That would make it have a tour around the globe and perhaps make some real impact. If by any chance there would be someone from Japan that would like to participate in the project while being there as a translator, a supporter, a guide, please do not hesitate to get in touch, your participation will be highly appreciated!!

story:
There are over 1 billion people on earth who have inadequate shelter. Cal-Earth is working to remedy this by teaching people to build with earth. 

Cal-Earth Institute is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization founded in 1991. After the passing of founding architect and humanitarian Nader Khalili (1936-2008), his son and daughter along with a team of his former apprentices gathered together to continue his quest to provide sustainable solutions to human shelter through research, development, and education in earth architecture.  


In the years since Nader Khalili's passing, Cal-Earth has grown immensely. We currently reach over 1.5 million through worldwide outreach and social media, in addition to more than 1,500 visitors who come to the site annually for workshops and tours. 



Structures have been built in over 40 countries, Cal-Earth workshops have been held on 5 continents, and Cal-Earth Spain was officially established in 2009. 

Your donation to the Vision Campaign will go towards two main projects: An online education program, and additional scholarships for low-income students.



This is a grassroots organization,  built entirely by students and volunteers. We need your help to ensure that Nader Khalili's work and Cal-Earth's legacy of sustainability will not only endure but also thrive and expand.  



If it is not accessible, it is not sustainable.  We are committed to teaching anyone who is interested in learning, regardless of their financial position. The more we are able to raise, the more scholarships we can provide for deserving students. 



Housing should not be out of reach. Through our combined efforts at Cal-Earth, we hope to achieve Nader Khalili's ultimate vision: a world in which every person is empowered to build a safe and sustainable home with their own hands, using the earth under their feet. 



Please help us advance Cal-Earth's legacy of sustainability. We hope we can count on your help as we continue to reduce environmental impact and reach more of those in need of shelter.


Ways you can Help:

1) First, Make a Tax-Deductible Donation

2) Be a Campaign Champion! Follow Us and Share on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. 




This technology has been published by NASA, endorsed by the United Nations, featured in countless world media outlets, and awarded the prestigious Aga Khan Award for Architecture in 2004. 

"It's a proven technology, it's cost effective, you need very little building material, just what nature gives you. So simple it can be learned by everybody." --The United Nations Director of Emergency Response Division (Reuters)


Please consider donating to help us reach our goal.

If you are not able to donate but care about this work, please help us by spreading the word. Follow and Share us on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. 

Nader Khalili always quoted his favorite poet, Rumi who said, "You are not one person, you are a thousand people."

Thank you for your support. 


With Gratitude,

Sheefteh Khalili, Dastan Khalili, and the entire Cal-Earth team 

Subscribe to the Cal-Earth Newsletter for future updates

story:
Short Summary

I am trying to set up this business to clean up garbage off of reefs. My goal is to build up enough money to file company with state and internet site and get things going. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to collect enough money to file with state 
  • We need to get a internet site set up for additional info and donation
  • Donations will be used to buy supplies and equipment necessary
  • Eventually we will need padi certified divers to help with cleanup

The Impact

  • Keeping garbage and fishing debris off off reefs will help reefs grow and thrive and help eliminate possible threats to fish population 
  • I am a padi certified diver and have been cleaning reefs as a hobby there is no shortage of garbage on the reefs I always come up with something
  • Keeping reefs clean will help ensure our future the ocean is an important eco system that keeps our world turning

Risks & Challenges

  • State may deny business if they find unnecessary 

Other Ways You Can Help

After business is up and running padi certified volunteers will be needed


And that's all there is to it.

story:
What do we all need other than Food? Water.

Help send Derrick to Portugal!

Hey there! My name is Derrick Idleburg Jr. and I am a member of Rotaract International, an Entrepreneur and Healthcare professional. I was selected by my Rotaract Club to attend these conferences. 

I'm campaigning to help get more funding to go to Lisbon, Portugal to attend the 2013 World Water Summit and 2013 Rotary International Convention! 

By contributing, this will grant the opportunity for me to attend a summit focused around water and international service. 

This is important to me because your help will grant me the opportunity to learn more about the humanitarian efforts taking place across the globe with Rotary and learn more about the impact of the global water focused initiatives and ways to get more involved on a local, national and international level. 

I am a greenhorn when it comes to global humanitarian efforts, these conferences will expose me to a wide range of efforts and how to dive in! 

See below for more information about the conferences.

World Water Summit

Rotary International Convention


Who is Derrick? Why should he go to Portugal? 

  • A Marketer and Entrepreneur by trade. Professionally, these are my two passions.
  • By day, I work at a non-profit hospital in the Kansas City,MO area. I was one of the driving forces behind creation, ideation and execution of a Mobile Market, a re-purposed bus designed to sell fresh produce in areas with little access. Find out more here. 
  • I consult others. Mainly in Marketing, Sales, Strategy, Content, Editing, Branding  and more. Find out more about the services I offer. Hint: It's a perk offer as well. 
  • I'm working with some local and not so local start ups in the area focused around Education, Health, Entertainment and Student Loans. All focused around Marketing and Business Development. 
  • My goal for the summit is to learn more about Rotary and Rotary's mission, gain some vauable lifelong connections and gain more leadership skills along with learning about Rotary's involvment in water and sanitation and other global initiatives. 

What is needed & What You Get

I need an additional $1100 to make Portugal a successful trip! I'll be in Lisbon, Portugal for 9 days so some things are going to add up! 

The flight and some other items for the trip has already been covered. Why? Because I won it! I won a scholarship to cover some costs of the trip. Before I tell you what I need your help with, let me first share what I have done to cover parts of the trip thus far. 

  • As mentioned above, I secured $1770 in scholarship funds to pay for the flight.
  • I'm not above "strapping up my boots" either. From speaking with my network, I have secured housing for the period of time I will spend in Portugal in order to save more than $700 to stay in a hotel.

Now I need your help to cover things like transportation, food,  etc. 

  • $50 per day for travel.
  • $50 per day for food.
  • Miscellanious fees like registration for the conferences ($100) 

Perks: 

Look to your right! There are some pretty awesome ones. 

 

If the goal is not reached, any available funds will go towards my attendance and participation of the conference. If there are funds over the goal amount, the funds will go to the Rotaract Kansas City group so they can make an impact in the Kansas City, Missouri area.

The Impact

Other than clean air and food, each and every one of us needs water to survive. It can't help if it's too contaminated to consume. Attending these conferences will help grow my knowledge about the water we all need and how I can ultimately get more involved to create more change in the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? I understand. We all can contribute in multiple ways! 

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

Want to find out more about who I am? Click on the links below and connect with me!

Rotaract Kansas City

Linkedin

Facebook

Far From Idle

story:
PLEASE HELP US CHANGE THIS!!

 My name is Christine Tessman and I am a life-long Berlin/ Kensington resident and a mother of 4 children.  I am on the Advisory Board for the Hungerford Park. My oldest is 28 and my youngest is 9 and my grandson is 4.  My children have enjoyed the Hungerford Park a decade now and my youngest (Allie-9) has gone to Mr. Nick's Summer Science program 3 years in a row and her fondest memories are of the Huckleberry Finn Style of rafting around the Pond at Hungerford Park and collecting and studying wildlife and of course returning it to the pond. Frogs, turtles, fish and insects are so interesting to children as they are learning about nature. The reason I've started this campaign is that the Pond at the Hungerford Park in Kensington Is Dying... It has been increasingly over-run by a very dangerous algae that has taken over the pond completely this year and is killing all the wildlife.

 

The algae layer on the top is at least a foot thick and the Huckleberry Finn ride is over.... and not only does it sadden me and my children, but it has become an unsightly eyesore to neighbors and passers-by. Everyone says, "well the winter months will kill the algae".. but, not true.. what happens is that when the pond ices over, the algae uses up all the oxygen left in the water in order to survive and then drops to the bottom. This kills the ponf life and in the spring, we have what is called a FISH KILL, and all the dead animals, frogs, fish, turtles etc, all float to the top creating a terrible environment in the spring that then needs to be dealt with as well. 

 

Clearing up the algae could cost up to $9000 over the course of the next few years and then to maintain its clarity for continued use by the children in our Youth Programs each and every summer.. It is the highlight for most of the children to go out on the pond and explore. 

Please help us reach our goal of just $5000 to keep these programs alive for our Connecticut children as well as our Fish and Pond wildlife..

Don't let them die this winter.. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute in this manner, please call the Hungerford Park and Volunteer your time to help feed and care for our Rehabilitating Animals or our other In-house fundraising Projects throughout the year

Thank you all so much, in advance, for your help!!!!

story:
Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (SETAC)

Student members of SETAC residing in Africa are faced with unique challenges: inadequate funding, volatile economies, and unreliable infrastructure. SETAC is a nonprofit, scientific society with a goal to bring researchers across continents, sectors, and disciplines to solve urgent environmental problems. We have set up travel grants to help subsidize the cost of attending scientific conferences in Africa for students, where they have the opportunity to present their research, get valuable feedback from experts in their field, make important connections and attend training courses. Unfortunately, the grants don't go far enough – we need your support.

Who You Are Helping

We'd like to introduce you to a couple of students that are willing to share their research and stories. Donations to this fund will help these young scientists, and others like them, travel to Langebaan, South Africa for a conference designed to "Identify Knowledge Gaps and Research Priorities in Africa." The conference takes place 5-8 October, so time is short! Before we do, some clarifying remarks:

  • $6000 (USD) is our goal, but all proceeds, whether they fall short or exceed expectation will go into the student travel fund for SETAC Africa
  • Funds will support direct travel costs (tickets for airfare, hotel) - we cover the cost of the meeting registration
  • Students awarded these travel supports are nominated by professors at leading research institutions based on their academic performance

Adeyemi and Electronic Waste

Do you know where your old electronics go when you toss them out?  A report from United Nations University found that the world produced 41.8 million metric tons of e-waste in 2014 – an amount that would fill 1.15 million 18-wheel trucks. Lined up, those trucks would stretch from New York to Tokyo and back. Most of this ends up in developing countries – such as Nigeria – where Adeyemi Adewale studies for his master of science degree in public and environmental health. When discussing his research, Adeyemi said, "Informal e-waste recycling practices in Nigeria, such as open burning to recover metals, dumping, or stockpiling, are frequent due to lack of national management strategies." The hazardous waste from discarded personal computers and televisions concern him – they may contain heavy metals and organic compounds that pose risks to the environment, humans, and to sustainable economic growth. His studies assess the physical and chemical characteristics of e-waste, as well as technicians' knowledge and e-waste management practices in Lagos. He hopes to further investigate the effects of electronic waste burning on the handlers and the environment, and to work towards developing more sustainable disposal methods. (Top row photos above show e-waste facilities and workers.)

Adeyemi (2nd from left, above) has conducted his research over the course of 11 years, despite the numerous financial challenges. He has been able to attend one conference previously, and he writes, "I sold some of my belongings to enable me to raise some funds. I risked attending the conference with no assurance of a place to stay. Luckily, Professor Beatrice Opeolu was magnanimous enough to give me a roof over my head for the duration of the conference." When asked if it was worth the risk he assured us that, "It gave me the opportunity to network with other scientists from different parts of the world, it enhanced the scope of my research activities, and the critiques and suggestions that resulted from my presentations enhanced my research options.

Nkwatoh Therese and Pesticides

UNEP reported in 2012 that the estimated potential cost of pesticide-related illnesses in sub-Saharan African between 2005 and 2020 is about $90bn. Nkwatoh Therese Ncheuveu studies in Cameroon, where agricultural practices have relied heavily on fertilizers and pesticides for generations. Few farmers in the Ndop rice paddy fields – a major staple crop and the main support for 13 villages in the area –  have been trained on pesticide handling or respect the required dosage. Their limited knowledge of the health and environmental risks the chemicals pose result in over application and a failure to protect themselves. Nkwatoh Therese explained to us that "during the growing seasons, paddy fields are flooded and the pesticides run through the fields into canals that empty into local streams." Her concern for the exposed fish (another staple for local survival), people exposed directly to the pesticide-laden water due to limited water treatment facilities, and for the consumers further up the food chain (people!), prompted her research. Her goal is to establish baseline information to help "generate sustainable agriculture and proper environmental monitoring, safeguard public health and provide an important tool for environmental management." (Bottom row photos above show the Ndop rice paddy fields.)

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone is in the position to donate financially, but every little bit helps! We also encourage you to share these stories through your lab family trees, professional networks, and social media outlets.

Thank you so much for your time and generous support!
story_txt:
Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (SETAC)
Student members of SETAC residing in Africa are faced with unique challenges: inadequate funding, volatile economies, and unreliable infrastructure. SETAC is a nonprofit, scientific society with a goal to bring researchers across continents, sectors, and disciplines to solve urgent environmental problems. We have set up travel grants to help subsidize the cost of attending scientific conferences in Africa for students, where they have the opportunity to present their research, get valuable feedback from experts in their field, make important connections and attend training courses. Unfortunately, the grants don't go far enough – we need your support.
  Who You Are Helping
 We'd like to introduce you to a couple of students that are willing to share their research and stories. Donations to this fund will help these young scientists, and others like them, travel to Langebaan, South Africa for a conference designed to "Identify Knowledge Gaps and Research Priorities in Africa." The conference takes place 5-8 October, so time is short! Before we do, some clarifying remarks:  $6000 (USD) is our goal, but all proceeds, whether they fall short or exceed expectation will go into the student travel fund for SETAC Africa  Funds will support direct travel costs (tickets for airfare, hotel) - we cover the cost of the meeting registration
Students awarded these travel supports are nominated by professors at leading research institutions based on their academic performance
 
   Adeyemi and Electronic Waste
Do you know where your old electronics go when you toss them out?  A report from United Nations University found that the world produced 41.8 million metric tons of e-waste in 2014 – an amount that would fill 1.15 million 18-wheel trucks. Lined up, those trucks would stretch from New York to Tokyo and back. Most of this ends up in developing countries – such as Nigeria – where Adeyemi Adewale studies for his master of science degree in public and environmental health. When discussing his research, Adeyemi said, "Informal e-waste recycling practices in Nigeria, such as open burning to recover metals, dumping, or stockpiling, are frequent due to lack of national management strategies." The hazardous waste from discarded personal computers and televisions concern him – they may contain heavy metals and organic compounds that pose risks to the environment, humans, and to sustainable economic growth. His studies assess the physical and chemical characteristics of e-waste, as well as technicians' knowledge and e-waste management practices in Lagos. He hopes to further investigate the effects of electronic waste burning on the handlers and the environment, and to work towards developing more sustainable disposal methods. (Top row photos above show e-waste facilities and workers.) 
Adeyemi (2nd from left, above) has conducted his research over the course of 11 years, despite the numerous financial challenges. He has been able to attend one conference previously, and he writes, "I sold some of my belongings to enable me to raise some funds. I risked attending the conference with no assurance of a place to stay. Luckily, Professor Beatrice Opeolu was magnanimous enough to give me a roof over my head for the duration of the conference." When asked if it was worth the risk he assured us that, "It gave me the opportunity to network with other scientists from different parts of the world, it enhanced the scope of my research activities, and the critiques and suggestions that resulted from my presentations enhanced my research options.
  Nkwatoh Therese and Pesticides
UNEP reported in 2012 that the estimated potential cost of pesticide-related illnesses in sub-Saharan African between 2005 and 2020 is about $90bn. Nkwatoh Therese Ncheuveu studies in Cameroon, where agricultural practices have relied heavily on fertilizers and pesticides for generations. Few farmers in the Ndop rice paddy fields – a major staple crop and the main support for 13 villages in the area –  have been trained on pesticide handling or respect the required dosage. Their limited knowledge of the health and environmental risks the chemicals pose result in over application and a failure to protect themselves. Nkwatoh Therese explained to us that "during the growing seasons, paddy fields are flooded and the pesticides run through the fields into canals that empty into local streams." Her concern for the exposed fish (another staple for local survival), people exposed directly to the pesticide-laden water due to limited water treatment facilities, and for the consumers further up the food chain (people!), prompted her research. Her goal is to establish baseline information to help "generate sustainable agriculture and proper environmental monitoring, safeguard public health and provide an important tool for environmental management." (Bottom row photos above show the Ndop rice paddy fields.)
  Other Ways You Can HelpNot everyone is in the position to donate financially, but every little bit helps! We also encourage you to share these stories through your lab family trees, professional networks, and social media outlets.
 Thank you so much for your time and generous support!

story:
Short summary

I co-founded an organization called Frack Free Colorado which has been part of the movement to stop fracking in Colorado. We are also supporting multiple efforts to accelerate the replacement for coal and natural gas: renewable energy. As part of these efforts, we have created a crowd-sourced film called Dear Governor Hickenlooper, addressed to Colorado's governor, to enlighten people on the dangers of fracking as well as our ability to move to clean energy today. 

Dear Governor Hickenlooper provides new perspectives on fracking and clean energy through the eyes of scientists, entrepreneurs, artists, and families. The film introduces audiences to an ex-gas worker turned whistle blower, Aaron Milton; Cornell’s Professor of Engineering, Anthony Ingraffea, who sheds new light on gas well failures; Dr. Theo Colburn who provides new science on how fracking affects our children’s health; a family whose dreams are broken when the gas company moves in next door. Shane Davis, AKA “The Fractivist”, is Dear Governor Hickenlooper’s protagonist, taking the audience from one story to the next while elucidating well site visits and statistics from the Colorado Oil and Gas Commission’s own accident data.

Dozens of filmmakers submitted short films, including the team that made Chasing Ice, Pete McBride (Chasing Water and The Water Tower), Emmy Award winner, Deia Schlosberg, among many others. Our goal with this film is to shape how people vote in November 2014 when there will be likely be fracking and renewable energy related ballot initiatives, and when Governor Hickenlooper will be running for re-election. 

The film itself has been funded and is completed. We have a coalition of 19 organizations lined up to organize and promote screenings across the state, including Food & Water Watch, Citizens for a Healthy Community, Sierra Club and others. We now need funding to promote screenings across the state through the creation of localized digital and printed materials. 

The impact

Your support will shape the future of energy in the state of Colorado and across the U.S. Help us get the latest science on how fracking affects our air, water, and health out to the public, empowering them to decide whether or not they want to allow fracking in their communities. Help us encourage new legislation that accelerates renewable energy.

If Colorado, with its long history in oil and gas extraction, stops fracking and leads the way toward renewable energy, the rest of the U.S. will follow. Help us make this future a reality by supporting the distribution of our film in theaters and across the web!

How we will use funds:

  • $4,000 to design and print localized posters to advertise screenings across Colorado and beyon
  • $1,700 to buy ads in local papers to promote screenings
  • $3,300 to buy 2 Blu Ray players that will travel to screenings to play the film
  • $1,000 to produce DVDs to send to individuals and groups to host screenings and to key government leaders across Colorado
  • Additional funds beyond the above will be used to buy newspaper advertising to promote screenings across the state

Other Ways You Can Help

If you'd like to host a screening of the film, or if you'd like to volunteer in your local community to help with efforts to stop fracking or grow renewable energy, reach out to contact@deargovernorhickenlooper.com. 

Thank you!!!

story:
My name is Dennis Reed and I live in Fergus Ontario, a small town north of Guelph on the Grand River in Canada.  

I'm going on a short-term mission trip to a small village in Honduras at the beginning of November 2014 (that's me above in Haiti!). This mission trip is going to involve drilling a freshwater drinking well from start to finish.

As we all know here in North America fresh drinking water is the foundation for a healthy life and I am grateful to be part of this faith based organization called Living Water International.

 My last trip with Living Water International was in Haiti in November 2012. We drilled a well for a small village that served approximately 600 people within the community. As part of our trip we demonstrate what it is to be good stewards both of the land and water.

This trip costs $2200 with the flights, food etc.  and I would so appreciate your assistance financially so that I can go.

In return, I offer you some awesome perks as I am a metal craftsman making great things for your home and am also a motorcycle specialist!
Please share this  with your friends and family if you think they might enjoy some metal/motorbike perks!

story:
I'm just one College Student, but with your help, we can

Change the Future of Food.

 

For years, experts have been showing the instability of a new style of Agriculture based on factory farms, poor planning, and the generous use of pesticides and other harmful chemicals. Not only do these practices harm our environment, but they endanger our health and the health of those around us. 

I've always been passionate about the importance of sustainable practices and buying organic and local food, but now I want to take it a step further: with your help, I'm traveling to Israel in order to learn (and work!) firsthand for a month on a family run eco-farm in Nir Moshe, a small community in the northwestern part of the Negev Desert in Israel. What do you get out of this? As a result of what I learn, I will be publishing photos and a set of articles educating others on how they can make a difference via The Times of Israel (where I already blog) , and plan on developing a business model to bring back to the United States. 

Here's How We Do It.  

I attend college in New York City. In order to get to Israel and make this all happen, I'll need a plane ticket and money to pay the ecofarm for training, food and lodging. 

The funds break down as follows:

1 month stay on the ecofarm: $1,000

Flight to Israel: $1,500

The Impact

Educated Entrepreneurs are our only hope of building a system of sustainable agriculture. With your help, I'll have the tools I need to educate others as well as hopefully start a business model of my own. 

Spread the word. 

Any amount makes a difference. Tell your friends, family, neighbors. Even if this project isn't fully funded, I plan on making it happen; that's how important this is to me.

story:
EDGE Philly is a group of activists & artists Encouraging Development of a Green Economy by Ending Dirty Gas Exploitation.

We work with frontline communities to engage in artful activism & push the boundaries of political engagement with direct action.

Our current focus is building coalitions and strategy for a ban on fracking in Pennsylvania. Philadelphia is poised to become a major energy hub, bearing the brunt of gas exploitation. EDGE works to build connections between harmed farmers in rural PA, and the income inequality and pollution of urban Philadelphia.

Pennsylvania fracking emissions contribute to global climate change. To avoid further devastation, we know we need to leave the majority of fossil fuels in the ground. This means reducing subsidies and demand for oil, coal, and gas while supporting economic initiatives to create green energy jobs in both urban and rural communities.

EDGE believes we are in a position to win a campaign to ban fracking in Pennsylvania. With the momentum created by similar bans in New York and Pittsburgh, as well as in many countries, (List of Bans) we are building a movement at the heart of Marcellus Shale. EDGE is pushing our new governor to act on the right side of history—to protect not just the citizens of Pennsylvania but all those affected by greenhouse gas emissions and poisoned water as a result of fracking.

Check out our Gallery and Updates pages to learn about what EDGE has been doing in recent months. 

All donations will be used to fund artful activism & training here in Philly & PA. All of our members come from frontline communities, either rural farmers whose land is being poisoned by wells or Philadelphia residents that will be baring the brunt of industry profiteering through the proposed Philly Energy Hub.
